questions.text: A patient is taking Clindamycin for a long period of time presented with diarrhea. Which of the following is causative organism for this? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CI. Difficile

 

Clostridium difficile (CI. difficile) is a bacterium that can cause a range of symptoms, from mild diarrhea to severe colitis. It is the most common cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, particularly following the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics such as clindamycin.

 

When antibiotics like clindamycin are taken for a long period of time, they can disrupt the normal gut flora. This disruption allows C. difficile to overgrow and produce toxins. The toxins produced by C. difficile (toxin A and toxin B) damage the intestinal lining, causing inflammation, diarrhea, and potentially severe complications such as pseudomembranous colitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium botulinum: Causes botulism, which is characterized by flaccid paralysis due to the production of botulinum toxin. It is not associated with antibiotic-induced diarrhea.

 

Option B. Clostridium tetani: Causes tetanus, presenting with muscle spasms and rigidity due to tetanospasmin toxin. It is not related to antibiotic use or diarrhea.

 

Option D. Clostridium perfringens: Causes gas gangrene and food poisoning but is not typically associated with antibiotic-induced diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clostridium difficile is the primary cause of antibiotic-associated diarrhea, particularly with the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics like clindamycin. Prompt recognition and appropriate treatment are essential to prevent severe complications such as pseudomembranous colitis.

 

C. Difficile-Associated Diarrhea (CDAD):

 

  • CDAD is a significant concern in patients using antibiotics like clindamycin.
  • If not treated in a timely manner, CDAD can lead to pseudomembranous colitis.
  • The treatment of choice (DOC) for C. difficile infection is fidaxomicin.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female presents to emergency following bleeding per vaginum, preceded by amenorrhea for 7 weeks. She's in hemodynamic shock with a positive serum beta hCG. On examination, a mass is palpable in the lower abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis in this scenario? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rupture ectopic pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

The above clinical scenario suggests a case of ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Following are the features:

 

  • Positive serum beta hCG: Indicates pregnancy.
  • History of amenorrhea for 7 weeks: Clinical manifestations of ectopic pregnancy typically appear six to eight weeks after the last normal menstrual period.
  • Unstable vitals (hemodynamic shock): Suggestive of hemoperitoneum, a serious complication often seen with ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • Mass palpable in the lower abdomen: Could be due to the ectopic pregnancy or associated hemoperitoneum.

 

The classic triad of symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy are:

 

  • Pain
  • Bleeding
  • Amenorrhea

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pyelonephritis: While pyelonephritis can cause abdominal pain and fever, it does not typically present with amenorrhea or positive serum beta hCG.

 

Option B. Gastrointestinal stromal tumor: This may cause abdominal pain but does not account for the positive beta hCG or amenorrhea.

 

Option C. Red degeneration of fibroid: This often occurs during pregnancy and can cause abdominal pain, but it is not typically associated with bleeding per vaginum and positive serum beta hCG in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classic triad of symptoms for ectopic pregnancy is pain, bleeding, and amenorrhea, with a positive beta hCG test and unstable vitals indicating a possible ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Page 212

choices.text: Measles virus
Polio virus
Mumps virus

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is presented with swelling on face and scrotum. Which of the following is causative agent? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mumps virus

 

In addition to salivary gland swelling, mumps can cause complications in some cases, particularly in adults. Complications of mumps can include meningitis, encephalitis, inflammation of the testicles or ovaries, and hearing loss.

 

  • ﻿﻿M/c presentation: B/I parotitis
  • ﻿﻿Sometimes parotitis preceded by meningoencephalitis
  • ﻿﻿After 1 or 2 weeks orchitis
  • ﻿﻿Vaccine strain; Jeryl lynn
  • ﻿﻿Negative sense Single stranded RNA virus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles virus: a member of the Paramyxoviridae family. Disease typically presents with a high fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and a characteristic maculopapular rash, but it does not cause facial or scrotal swelling.

 

Option B. Polio virus: An enterovirus, primarily affects the nervous system, leading to paralysis. It does not cause swelling of the face or scrotum.

 

Option D. Cox virus (Coxsackievirus): Coxsackieviruses, members of the Picornaviridae family, can cause a variety of illnesses including hand, foot, and mouth disease, herpangina, and myocarditis. They do not typically cause the combination of facial and scrotal swelling seen in mumps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mumps virus is the causative agent of mumps, which presents with bilateral parotitis (swelling of the parotid glands), and can also cause orchitis (swelling of the testicles) in males. This combination of symptoms—facial swelling and scrotal swelling—is characteristic of mumps infection.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought in a drowsy state from a PHC with complaints of fever, severe lower abdominal pain, and purulent vaginal discharge. Her friend revealed that she had had an unsafe abortion a week ago. On examination, her abdomen was distended, BP was 80/60 mmHg, PR was 140 bpm and RR was 36 /min. Which of the following is the most common causative agent of her present condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Escherichia coli

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario is indicative of septic abortion with endotoxic shock syndrome. Septic abortion is a serious infection of the uterus that can occur after an abortion, particularly if the abortion was performed under non-sterile conditions.

 

  • Escherichia coli (E. coli) is the most common organism responsible for septic abortion. It is a Gram-negative bacterium commonly found in the lower intestine of warm-blooded organisms. Its presence in the uterus can lead to severe infections, especially in cases of unsafe or incomplete abortions.

 

Septic abortion is typically characterized by:

 

  1. A rise in temperature of at least 100.4°F (38°C) for 24 hours or more.
  2. Offensive or purulent vaginal discharge.
  3. Other evidence of pelvic infection such as lower abdominal pain and tenderness.

 

The patient’s symptoms of fever, severe abdominal pain, purulent discharge, hypotension (BP 80/60 mmHg), tachycardia (PR 140 bpm), and increased respiratory rate (RR 36/min) are consistent with septic abortion and septic shock.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pyogenes: Although it can cause severe infections, it is not the most common organism responsible for septic abortions.

 

Option B. Clostridium perfringens: This bacterium can cause gas gangrene and other severe infections but is less commonly associated with septic abortion.

 

Option C. Clostridium sordelli: This organism can cause toxic shock syndrome associated with abortions, but it is not the most common cause of septic abortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

E. coli is the most common causative organism of septic abortion, characterized by fever, purulent vaginal discharge, and signs of systemic infection.

 

Ref: Page 194, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is the most abundant plasma protein? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Albumin

 

Albumin is the most abundant plasma protein. It is synthesized by the liver and plays a crucial role in maintaining oncotic pressure, transporting various substances (such as hormones and drugs), and contributing to the regulation of blood pH.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bence Jones protein: Bence Jones protein is a monoclonal immunoglobulin light chain and is associated with conditions like multiple myeloma. It is not a normal constituent of plasma proteins.

 

Option B. Globulin: Globulin is a diverse group of proteins, including immunoglobulins (antibodies) and other proteins involved in immune function. While globulins are present in the plasma, they are not a single protein and are not as abundant as albumin.

 

Option C. Fibrinogen: Fibrinogen is a plasma protein involved in blood clotting. It is present at lower concentrations compared to albumin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Plasma protein levels can be indicators of health and disease. For example, a decrease in albumin can indicate liver disease or malnutrition, while an increase in specific globulins can be seen in various infections or immune disorders.
  • Plasma protein measurement is a common laboratory test, often part of a liver function test or used in the diagnosis and monitoring of various diseases.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 637

questions.text: A nulliparous lady with a BMI of 23, presents with hirsutism. Ultrasonography was done and an image of the same is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Polycystic ovarian syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

This ultrasound image shows polycystic morphology, often referred to as the "necklace pattern," which is characteristic of Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS). PCOS is a common endocrine disorder in women of reproductive age and is diagnosed using the Rotterdam criteria, where at least 2 out of the following 3 criteria must be fulfilled:

 

  1. Ultrasound morphology of PCOS: This includes ovarian volume greater than 10 ml or the presence of 12 or more follicles measuring 2 to 9 mm in diameter in one or both ovaries.
  2. Clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism: This can present as hirsutism, acne, or elevated levels of androgens in the blood.
  3. Oligo or anovulation: This refers to infrequent or absent ovulation, leading to irregular menstrual cycles.

 

Given the patient's presentation with hirsutism and the ultrasound findings, PCOS is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubal block: Tubal block can be visualized by performing tests for tubal patency such as hysterosalpingography (HSG) or sono salpingography. It is typically associated with infertility but not with the ultrasound findings described here.

 

Option C. Multiple fibroids: Fibroids appear on ultrasound as hypoechoic (dark) concentric areas within the uterine wall. They do not present with the "necklace pattern" seen in the image provided.

 

Option D. Mesenteritis: Mesenteritis is an inflammation of the mesentery, the tissue that attaches the intestines to the abdominal wall. It does not present with ovarian cysts or the ultrasound findings described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is diagnosed based on the Rotterdam criteria, where at least 2 out of the following 3 criteria must be present: polycystic ovarian morphology, clinical or biochemical evidence of hyperandrogenism, and oligo or anovulation.

 

Ref: Williams Gynecology 3rd edition pg 387

choices.text: Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre
Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home

questions.text: A one-and-a-half year old child is brought to the hospital with a history of breathlessness, fever <37 degrees, cough, and cold. On examination, the respiratory rate was 46/min, and there were no chest retractions. Which is the most appropriate management? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer oral antibiotics, warn of danger signs, and send home


The clinical scenario described here is consistent with a diagnosis of pneumonia, but it is not classified as severe pneumonia or very severe disease based on the given symptoms. The child has a respiratory rate of 46/min, which, while elevated, does not show signs of severe distress (e.g., chest indrawing or general danger signs) that would necessitate immediate hospitalization or IV antibiotics.

 

In cases of pneumonia without severe symptoms, the appropriate management includes administering an oral antibiotic for 5 days, advising the mother on how to soothe the child’s throat and relieve the cough with a safe remedy, and warning about danger signs that would require immediate medical attention. The child should also have a follow-up in 2 days to ensure that the condition is improving.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer IV antibiotics and observe: This option would be appropriate for severe pneumonia or very severe disease, where the child shows signs of severe distress (e.g., chest indrawing, general danger signs). In this case, the child’s symptoms do not warrant such aggressive management.

 

Option B. Administer IV antibiotics and refer to higher centre: This management step would be necessary for very severe cases of pneumonia where immediate advanced care is needed. However, the child in this scenario does not meet the criteria for such a referral.

 

Option D. Administer only home remedies: While soothing remedies are recommended, relying solely on home remedies without antibiotics would not be appropriate for a case of pneumonia. Oral antibiotics are necessary to treat the infection.

 

Educational Objective:


For a child with pneumonia but without severe symptoms, the appropriate management includes administering oral antibiotics, advising on home care, and scheduling a follow-up to monitor progress.

questions.text: A man brings his father who became unconscious while working in a field in the hot sun at 42 degrees Celsius in May. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration. His serum electrolyte values were normal. The physician found that the body temperature was 106 F. Which of the following symptoms is least likely to be seen in this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sweating

 

In classic heat stroke, patients typically do not sweat. This differentiates it from exertional heat stroke and heat exhaustion. The patient is likely to exhibit symptoms like nausea, hypotension, and headache.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nausea: Common in heat stroke.

 

Option B. Hypotension: Can occur due to dehydration and vasodilation.

 

Option D. Headache: A common symptom of heat stroke.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In classic heat stroke, sweating is usually absent.

questions.text: Which part of the fallopian tube is most commonly involved in genital tuberculosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ampulla

 

The ampulla is the most common part of the fallopian tube to be involved in genital tuberculosis. Genital tuberculosis frequently affects the fallopian tubes, and the involvement is usually bilateral. The spread of the disease is typically hematogenous from a primary infective focus in the lungs.

 

In genital tuberculosis:

 

  • The ampulla is affected in 55% of cases.
  • The isthmus is involved in 25% of cases.
  • The infundibulum is affected in 18% of cases.
  • The interstitial part is least affected, with only 2% involvement.

 

The ampulla's susceptibility may be due to its anatomical and physiological properties, making it a common site for infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Infundibulum: Involved in 18% of genital tuberculosis cases, making it less commonly affected compared to the ampulla.

 

Option C. Isthmus: This part of the fallopian tube is involved in 25% of genital tuberculosis cases, which is also less common than the ampulla.

 

Option D. Interstitium: This part is the least affected by genital tuberculosis, with only 2% involvement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ampulla is the most commonly involved part of the fallopian tube in genital tuberculosis, with a prevalence of 55%.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition page 207, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition pg 162

questions.text: Identify the hormone present in the contraceptive shown in the image below: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nonoxynol 9

 

Explanation:

 

  • It is a contraceptive device that contains Nonoxynol 9. It is called “Today”.
  • It comes under barrier contraceptives
  • It is a polyurethane sponge. It is disposable and contains 1 g of nonoxynol-9.
  • It is 2 inches in diameter, 1.25 inches thick. It has loop for easy removal and is placed in vagina with concave side covering cervix. It is effective for 24 hours.
  • Mechanism of action- acts as mechanical barrier. It prevents the entry of sperm and also contains a spermicidal agent. It can be used only once.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Octoxynol 8 and Option C. Menfegol are also spermicidal agents like Nonoxynol 9 . They have surfactant properties and mostly cause sperm immobilization. They are available as cream, jelly or foam tablet form to be inserted high up in the vagina.

 

Option D. Levonorgestrel: It has many contraceptive applications.

 

  • LNG IUD (Mirena) contains 52 mg of LNG released at 20 mcg per day, replaced every 7 years.
  • COCPS contain combination of LNG (0.15 mg) and EE (30 mcg).
  • Norplant is an implant containing levonorgestrel.     
  • Emergency contraceptive pills contain LNG 0.75 mg two doses 12 hours apart or single dose 1.5 mg to be taken within 72 hours

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "Today" sponge is a barrier contraceptive containing 1 g of Nonoxynol 9, a spermicidal agent.

 

Ref: D. C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th Edition Page 478, 480,486,492, Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg 130

questions.text: A couple from a rural village in Rajasthan is expecting their first child and seeks to start regular health check-ups for the expectant mother at a nearby government health facility. What is the appropriate first point of contact for seeking medical care in their community? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Subcentre

 

Ideal first contact for people seeking medical care in a community is a Subcentre.

 

 

Levels of Primary Health Care System in India

 

  • Primary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘first level of contact between population and health care system’ in India
    • Health services are delivered through - Sub-centre and Primary Health Centre
  • Secondary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘First referral level of health care’ in India
    • Health services are delivered through: Community Health Centre
  • Tertiary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘Second referral level of health care’ in India
    • Health services are delivered through: Medical Colleges and Hospitals

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a couple in a rural village, a Subcentre is the most accessible and relevant first point of care, offering essential health services and initial check-ups for pregnant women, thus ensuring early and regular monitoring throughout pregnancy.

questions.text: What is the affinity of carbon monoxide to hemoglobin in comparison to oxygen? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 210

 

Carbon monoxide (CO) has 210 times greater affinity to bind to hemoglobin compared to oxygen.

 

When CO binds to hemoglobin, it forms a stable complex known as carboxyhemoglobin (COHb). This reduces the amount of hemoglobin available to bind with O2, leading to a decrease in oxygen delivery to the body's tissues. This can result in hypoxia, which can be life-threatening in severe cases.

 

CO poisoning occurs when a person inhales too much CO, leading to the formation of high levels of COHb in the blood. Symptoms of CO poisoning can include headache, dizziness, nausea, confusion, and loss of consciousness. In severe cases, it can lead to coma, permanent brain damage, and death.

 

It is important to note that even low levels of CO exposure over a prolonged period can have harmful effects on the body, particularly in vulnerable populations such as pregnant women, infants, and people with pre-existing cardiovascular or respiratory conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbon monoxide has a significantly higher affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen, 210 times greater, leading to the formation of carboxyhemoglobin and potentially causing severe oxygen deprivation and poisoning symptoms like headache, dizziness, and even death in extreme cases.

questions.text: The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Senile endometrial atrophy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Senile endometrial atrophy is the most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding. It occurs due to the thinning and atrophy of the endometrial lining, which can lead to spontaneous bleeding.
  • Other potential causes of post-menopausal bleeding include:
    • Endometrial cancer
    • Endometrial polyp
    • Endometrial hyperplasia
    • Exogenous estrogens from hormone replacement therapy or other sources.
  • It is crucial to rule out malignancy in cases of post-menopausal bleeding by performing endometrial sampling. This procedure can also be done on an outpatient basis using a Pipelle (endometrial sampler).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cervical cancer: Although a significant concern, it is not the most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding.

 

Option C. Endometrial cancer: While an important cause, it is less common than senile endometrial atrophy.

 

Option D. Hormone replacement therapy: Can cause bleeding but is less common than senile endometrial atrophy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most common cause of post-menopausal bleeding is senile endometrial atrophy.

 

Ref: D.C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology page 559

questions.text: A person came to emergency with snake bite 10 hours ago. He has already been given 10 vials of antivenom at local hospital. Which of the following is the next step, if patient does not recover and signs of neuro paralysis prevails? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Neostigmine + Atropine

 

Snake venom from neurotoxic snakes, such as cobras and kraits, contains toxins that block neuromuscular receptors, preventing acetylcholine (Ach) from acting at the neuromuscular junction. This blockade results in neuroparalysis. If the patient does not recover after receiving antivenom, the next step is to administer neostigmine and atropine.

 

  • Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. By inhibiting the enzyme acetylcholinesterase, neostigmine increases the concentration of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, thereby overcoming the blockade caused by the snake venom.

  • Atropine is used in conjunction with neostigmine to counteract the muscarinic side effects (such as bradycardia, salivation, and bronchial secretions) of increased acetylcholine levels due to neostigmine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Aspirin is an antiplatelet agent and pain reliever. It is not relevant to treating neuroparalysis caused by snake venom and would not be effective in this situation.

 

Option C. IV Hydrocortisone: IV Hydrocortisone is a corticosteroid used for its anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive properties. It does not have a direct role in reversing neuroparalysis caused by snake venom.

 

Option D. Anti-coagulation therapy: Anti-coagulation therapy is used to prevent or treat thromboembolic events. It is not relevant to the treatment of neuroparalysis caused by snake venom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of neuroparalysis following a snake bite from neurotoxic snakes such as cobras and kraits, if antivenom is insufficient, the administration of neostigmine (an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor) along with atropine (to counteract muscarinic side effects) is the appropriate next step.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old female patient presents with a 3-day history of fever, headache, ataxia, nausea, and vomiting. On examination neck rigidity is present and there is hip and knee flexion on passive flexion of the neck. A lumbar puncture was done and CSF findings are as shown below. (FMGE JUNE 2022)

 

Opening pressure – Increased,

 

Colour- Cloudy white,

 

WBCs – 7000 PMNs predominant,

 

Glucose 15 mg/dL,

 

CSF/serum glucose ratio - 0.2,

 

Protein 70 mg/dL.

 

What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial meningitis

 

The presence of high opening pressure, cloudy CSF, high WBC count (predominantly neutrophils), low glucose, and elevated protein is indicative of bacterial meningitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tubercular meningitis: Typically shows lymphocytic predominance.

 

Option C. Viral meningitis: Shows lymphocytic predominance and normal glucose.

 

Option D. Fungal meningitis: Shows lymphocytic predominance and can have a varied glucose level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial meningitis is characterized by high neutrophil count, low glucose, and elevated protein in CSF.

choices.text: First debridement then reconstruction and then resuscitation
First resuscitation then reconstruction and then debridement
First resuscitation, then debridement and then autograft + allograft

questions.text: A lady presented with burns from the neck to the lower back. Preferred sequence of treatment in this Lady? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) First resuscitation, then debridement and then autograft + allograft

 

The primary priority in managing a patient with severe burns is to address the risk of hypovolemic shock, which is the most common cause of early death in such patients. Therefore, the initial step is resuscitation, followed by debridement and then grafting the burned skin with autograft or allograft.

 

1. Resuscitation:

 

  • Purpose: To prevent hypovolemic shock.
  • Process: Severe burns lead to significant fluid loss due to leakage from blood vessels into tissues, causing swelling and decreasing effective circulating blood volume. Without prompt resuscitation, this can result in reduced blood flow to vital organs and potentially organ failure.

 

2. Debridement:

 

  • Purpose: To remove dead, damaged, or infected tissue, thereby improving the healing potential of remaining healthy tissue and preventing infection.
  • Process: Once the patient’s vital signs and fluid status are stabilized, debridement is performed to prepare the wound for grafting.

 

3. Autograft + Allograft:

 

  • Purpose: To promote healing of deep burns that penetrate beyond superficial skin layers.
  • Process: An autograft involves transplanting the patient’s own skin from an unburned area to the burned area. An allograft is the temporary placement of donor skin (usually from a cadaver) onto the burned area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. First debridement, resuscitation, then autograft: Incorrect because resuscitation must be the first step to prevent hypovolemic shock.

 

Option B. First debridement, then reconstruction and then resuscitation: Incorrect because resuscitation must be prioritized before debridement and reconstruction.

 

Option C. First resuscitation, then reconstruction and then debridement: Incorrect sequence, as debridement must precede reconstruction to remove damaged tissue and reduce the risk of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the management of severe burns, the primary priority is resuscitation to prevent hypovolemic shock, followed by debridement, and then grafting the burned skin with autograft or allograft.

questions.text: Which can cause condyloma acuminata? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. HPV 6,11

 

﻿Condyloma accuminata: Genital warts

 

 

﻿﻿HPV types 6 and 11 are the primary causative agents of condyloma acuminata, or genital warts. These types are considered low-risk HPV types because they are not associated with a high risk of cancer but are responsible for the majority of genital warts cases. HPV 6 and 11 can also cause laryngeal warts.

 

Note – HPV types 16 and 18 are high-risk HPV types associated with cervical and other anogenital cancers. HPV types 31 and 33 are also considered high-risk and are more commonly associated with precancerous changes and cancers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HPV types 6 and 11 are the primary causes of condyloma acuminata (genital warts) and can also cause laryngeal warts. High-risk HPV types like 16, 18, 31, and 33 are associated with cancer and not genital warts.

questions.text: A lady presented with foul smelling greyish white discharge and whiff test was positive. On examination following cells were seen as shown in image given below. Identify the causative organism and drug of choice? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gardnerella vaginalis, metronidazole

 

﻿﻿Amsel's criteria: Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed if any 3 of the following 4 findings are present

 

  1. Homogeneous white-gray vaginal discharge: Presence of a thin, milky discharge that adheres to the vaginal walls.
  2. Vaginal pH greater than 4.5: Measurement of vaginal pH using pH paper or pH indicator strips, with a value above 4.5 indicating an elevated pH associated with BV.
  3. Positive "whiff test" or amine odor: Characteristic fishy odor when a sample of vaginal discharge is mixed with 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH).
  4. Presence of clue cells on microscopic examination: microscopic visualization of vaginal epithelial cells covered with bacteria, which are called clue cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Candida, Fluconazole: Candida infections typically present with thick, white, "cottage cheese-like" discharge and intense itching. The cells would show budding yeast or pseudohyphae on microscopy, not clue cells.

 

Option B. Trichomonas, Metronidazole: Trichomonas vaginalis infection presents with frothy, yellow-green discharge and a strawberry cervix. The organism would appear as motile, flagellated protozoa on microscopy, not clue cells.

 

Option D. Gonococci, Doxycycline: Gonococcal infection (caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae) presents with purulent discharge and urethritis or cervicitis. Gram-negative intracellular diplococci would be seen on Gram stain, not clue cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial vaginosis is diagnosed by the presence of clue cells, a positive whiff test, homogeneous discharge, and elevated vaginal pH. The causative organism is Gardnerella vaginalis, and the treatment of choice is metronidazole.

questions.text: A 30-year-old worker named John presents with swollen lymph nodes in his left armpit. He recently got bitten by fleas while working in a wheat godown. The affected area is red and tender. To investigate the cause, a smear from his axillary lymph node is examined. Which is the most suitable stain for this examination? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Giemsa

 

Solution

 

﻿﻿Diagnosis: Plague

 

﻿Done by: Yersinia pestis

 

﻿﻿Lab diagnosis

 

﻿﻿Tissue Biopsy + Giemsa stain/Wayson stain shows Bipolar stained appearance (safety pin appearance)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gram stain: While Gram stain can be used to identify gram-negative bacteria like Yersinia pestis, it is not as specific as Giemsa stain for showing the characteristic bipolar staining.

 

Option C. Acid fast: Acid-fast stains are used primarily for mycobacteria, such as Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and are not suitable for Yersinia pestis, which is not acid-fast.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For suspected cases of plague caused by Yersinia pestis, the Giemsa stain is the most suitable stain for identifying the characteristic bipolar staining of the organism in clinical specimens.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury shown in the picture below: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lacerated wound

 

A laceration is a wound that is produced by the tearing of soft body tissue. This type of wound is often irregular and jagged.

 

Tissues are torn as a result of the application of blunt force. Tissues may be skin, mucous membrane, muscles or internal organs.

 

Floor of laceration shows following features:

 

  • Tissue bridges Crushed
  • Less hemorrhage because of crushed blood vessels
  • Foreign particles like mud may be seen embedded in the wound, which gives clue about the scene of crime.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abrasion: This is a superficial injury caused by friction, scraping away the surface layer of the skin.

 

Option B. Incised Wound: This type of wound is caused by a sharp object, such as a knife, resulting in clean, straight edges.

 

Option D. Stab Wound: This is a deep wound caused by a sharp, pointed object, such as a knife or a spear, which penetrates the body more deeply than an incised wound.

 

Educational Objective

 

The image shows a lacerated wound, characterized by irregular and jagged edges, tissue bridging, less hemorrhage, and possibly embedded foreign particles.

questions.text:
The normal placenta is: (FMGE JUNE 2022)

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Discoid
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Hemochorial
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Deciduate
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

 

Explanation:

 

The human placenta is characterized by the following features:

 

  • Discoid: The placenta has a disk-like shape, which is typical in humans.
  • Hemochorial: This term indicates that the chorion (the outer fetal membrane) comes in direct contact with maternal blood. The majority of the placenta is derived from vessels.
  • Deciduate: This means that the placenta is shed or expelled during parturition (childbirth).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Discoid: While it is true that the placenta is discoid, this option alone does not cover all characteristics of the normal placenta.

 

Option B. Hemochorial: Although the placenta is hemochorial, this option alone is incomplete.

 

Option C. Deciduate: The placenta is deciduate, but this option alone is insufficient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The human placenta is discoid in shape, hemochorial in nature, and deciduate, meaning it is shed at parturition.

 

Ref: D C Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition Page 32

questions.text: The phenomenon shown in the given image is seen in which of the following disorders?(FMGE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Obsessive compulsive disorder

 

The image suggests a compulsion, specifically around handwashing. Compulsions are repetitive behaviors performed in response to an obsession.

 

Characterized by obsessions (unwanted, intrusive thoughts) and compulsions (repetitive actions to neutralize the thoughts). The image aligns best with this disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD): Involves excessive and chronic worry about various topics, but not specific compulsions.

 

Option C. Adjustment Disorder: Occurs in response to a specific stressor and leads to emotional or behavioral symptoms, but not specific obsessions or compulsions.

 

Option D. Panic Disorder: Involves recurrent panic attacks, but not compulsive behaviors like hand-washing.

 

Based on the emphasis on hand-washing in the image, OCD is the most fitting diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

OCD is characterised by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3 % and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 421-422.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant female presents to dermatology OPD with the given condition. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Chloasma

 

The woman here is presenting with chloasma or mask of pregnancy. The same facial melanosis in non-pregnant women is called melasma. Only the terms used differ.

 

Clinical Image depicting Chloasma / Melasma:

 

 

  • The third trimester of pregnancy is when chloasma is most prevalent and is most noticeable in brunettes.
  • It results from elevated levels of estrogen and progesterone stimulating melanocyte activity.
  • Histopathology shows no increase in number but hyper-functional naturally.
  • The most frequent cause of chronic facial melanosis is melasma.
  • Hyperpigmented macules that are more pronounced after exposure to sunlight are its primary symptom.
  • Upper lip, malar, forehead, and chin are the main areas of the body affected by this hyper melanosis. Women between the ages of 20 and 40 are more likely to have it.

 

 

It resolves on its own after pregnancy.

 

It is frequently seen in women on OCPs.

 

Woods lamp examination is useful to differentiate various types of Melasma, level of pigmentation & treatment response:

 

 

Melasma is more chronic & requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:

  1. Kligman’s triple combination - Topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + steroid compound cream (first line)
  2. Hydroquinone (Reduces tyrosinase activity)
  3. Kojic acid (Tyrosinase inhibitor)
  4. Chemical peels

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE):

  • SLE is an autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue.
  • Its cutaneous manifestation, called the "butterfly rash", affects the malar region (cheeks and nose) but can also cause various other skin lesions.
  • Other systemic symptoms include joint pain, fatigue, and organ involvement.
  • Why it might not be the Ans. If the patient solely has a skin condition and lacks other systemic symptoms, it's less likely to be SLE.

 

Option C. Rosacea:

  • Rosacea is a chronic, inflammatory skin condition which principally affects the face.
  • Symptoms include redness, pimples, swelling, and dilated blood vessels.
  • It tends to worsen over time if left untreated but is not particularly associated with pregnancy.
  • Why it might not be the Ans. If the skin condition of the patient looks like hyperpigmentation, it's less likely to be rosacea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chloasma is a pigmentation disorder characterized by dark, irregular facial patches, which is commonly observed during pregnancy due to hormonal changes and sun exposure.

 

References: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition, Page no 68.11, 75.19, 88.9, 88.10

questions.text: Which grade is assigned to glioblastoma in the WHO tumor classification system? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grade 4

 

Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is classified as Grade 4, indicating its highly aggressive nature and poor prognosis. It is most commonly seen in adults or older individuals and typically located in the cerebral cortex.

 

 

WHO tumour classification grades:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is classified as a Grade 4 tumor in the WHO tumor classification system, indicating its high malignancy and aggressive behavior.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency causes tingling sensation, pallor & ataxia:( FMGE 2022 )
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Folic Acid

 

Deficiency of folic acid can lead to megaloblastic anemia, which could cause pallor (due to reduced hemoglobin levels), tingling sensation, and ataxia.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Deficiency of riboflavin can lead to ariboflavinosis, which is characterized by symptoms such as sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, cracked lips, and skin disorders. It does not typically cause tingling sensation, pallor, or ataxia.

 

Option B. Vitamin B1 (Thiamine): While thiamine deficiency can lead to serious neurological problems (like Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and beriberi), the classic symptoms are confusion, difficulty with coordination (ataxia), and problems with memory. Peripheral neuropathy (tingling sensation) can be a symptom but is not the most prominent feature, and pallor is not typically associated with thiamine deficiency.

 

Option D. Niacin (Vitamin B3): Niacin deficiency leads to pellagra, which is characterized by the "three Ds": dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. Tingling sensation, pallor, and ataxia are not typical features of niacin deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid (also known as folate) is a B-vitamin that is essential for many bodily functions, including DNA synthesis, cell division, and the production of red blood cells. Deficiency in folic acid can lead to a range of symptoms, including:

 

  1. Fatigue and weakness, Pale skin, Shortness of breath
  2. Headaches, Irritability
  3. Reduced appetite and weight loss
  4. Tongue swelling and inflammation
  5. Numbness or tingling in the hands and feet
  6. Difficulty concentrating or remembering things
  7. Depression or anxiety, Irritability
  8. Birth defects in babies born to women who are deficient during pregnancy.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 546

questions.text: A patient found roadside in an unconscious state having pin point pupil, HR 54/min and BP 90/50 mmHg. His history reveals he is a drug addict. Which of the following drug he must have consumed? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Morphine

 

Morphine is an opioid, and opioid poisoning can present with a characteristic set of symptoms, including:

 

  • Bradycardia (HR 54/min): Opioids like morphine slow the heart rate.

  • Respiratory depression: One of the most dangerous effects of opioid overdose is the suppression of the respiratory drive.

  • Hypotension (BP 90/50 mmHg): Opioids can cause a drop in blood pressure.

  • Pinpoint pupils (miosis): This is a classic sign of opioid overdose, distinguishing it from other types of drug intoxication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cocaine: Acute intoxication with cocaine typically presents with symptoms such as euphoria, agitation, tachycardia, chest pain, mydriasis (dilated pupils), hypertension, and seizures. Chronic cocaine abusers might have additional features like tactile hallucinations and septal perforation. Cocaine does not cause pinpoint pupils and bradycardia.

 

Option C. Amphetamine: Amphetamines are CNS stimulants. Intoxication with amphetamines can lead to violent behavior, psychosis, choreiform movements, and paranoid hallucinatory syndrome. Symptoms also include tachycardia, hypertension, and dilated pupils (mydriasis), which are the opposite of the symptoms seen with morphine overdose.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is a typical antipsychotic that acts by blocking dopamine D2 receptors. Side effects of haloperidol include extrapyramidal symptoms like dystonia, akathisia, and Parkinson-like features. It does not cause the triad of bradycardia, hypotension, and pinpoint pupils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Morphine and other opioids can cause a characteristic triad of symptoms in overdose: bradycardia, hypotension, and pinpoint pupils. These signs are critical for diagnosing opioid toxicity.

choices.text: Hb value

questions.text: A child brought to hospital with complains of severe fatigue, lethargy, pallor and irritation. He is diagnosed with IDA. He is on oral iron supplements. After reviewing the child doctors are planning to start with IV iron supplementation. What is the next step? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ferritin

 

The most sensitive and specific marker for Iron Deficiency Anemia (IDA) is ferritin. Ferritin levels are typically low as iron stores are depleted in IDA. Checking ferritin levels before initiating IV iron supplementation helps confirm the diagnosis of IDA and assess the severity of iron deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TIBC (Total Iron-Binding Capacity): TIBC measures the blood's capacity to bind iron with transferrin. While TIBC can be elevated in IDA, it is not as specific as ferritin for confirming iron deficiency.

 

Option C. Hb value (Hemoglobin): The Hb value indicates the level of hemoglobin in the blood, which is often low in anemia, but it does not directly assess iron stores or confirm IDA.

 

Option D. Hematocrit: Hematocrit measures the proportion of red blood cells in the blood. It is a useful indicator of overall blood volume and can be low in anemia, but it is not specific for diagnosing iron deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ferritin is the most sensitive and specific marker for diagnosing Iron Deficiency Anemia and should be measured before initiating IV iron supplementation.

questions.text: Dr. Raghav, a young infectious disease specialist, is posted at a busy ICTC clinic in New Delhi. An anxious 30-year-old man walks in after being diagnosed HIV positive. He recalls a close contact having TB a year ago and is worried about his own health. Remembering the NACO guidelines, Dr. Raghav decides to counsel the patient and screen him for TB before symptoms manifest. This proactive approach by Dr. Raghav falls under which category of prevention? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Primary, secondary

 

Here in the above question, counselling for a disease comes under primary prevention. Simultaneously screening for a specific disease comes under secondary prevention.

 

PRIMARY PREVENTION:

 

It is an action taken prior to the onset of disease which removes the possibility that a disease will ever occur.

 

Modes:

 

  • Health promotion like health education, environmental modifications, lifestyle and behavioural changes.
  • Specific protection like contraception, Vaccinations.

 

This is applied when risk factors are present but disease has not yet taken place.

 

SECONDARY PREVENTION:

 

It halts the disease progress and prevents Complications.

 

Modes:

 

  • Early diagnosis example sputum smear exam for AFB.
  • Treatment example DOTS, MDT.

 

It is applied when disease has possibly set in and it arrests the process of progression.

 

This dual approach ensures that the patient is both informed about preventive measures and assessed for early signs of TB, addressing risks before they manifest into more serious health issues.

 

Other Option:

 

TERTIARY PREVENTION: It includes disability limitation/prevention of further disability or death. his type of prevention aims to manage clinical diseases in order to slow or stop disease progression, reduce complications and restore function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The integration of primary and secondary prevention methods offers a holistic approach to patient care, especially in managing health in patients with complex needs like those living with HIV. This strategy not only seeks to prevent the onset of new diseases (like TB) but also to manage potential health issues proactively before they develop into more serious conditions.

questions.text: During a health visit at a local school, you come across a child exhibiting delayed speech development. An otoscopic examination of the ear reveals the appearance shown below. Additionally, audiometric tests indicate a hearing loss of 20 dB. What would be your diagnosis for the child? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Serous otitis media

 

The provided clinical scenario, combined with the otoscopy image displaying air-fluid levels, indicates a diagnosis of serous otitis media.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES IN SEROUS OTITIS MEDIA

 

  • Hearing Loss is the presenting symptom. It is insidious in onset and rarely the only symptom.
  • Delayed development of speech
  • Mild earache

 

OTOSCOPIC FINDINGS IN SEROUS OTITIS MEDIA

 

  • Tympanic membrane is dull and opaque with loss of light reflex.
  • It may appear yellow, grey or bluish in color.
  • Thin leash of blood vessels may be seen along the handle of malleus or at the periphery of tympanic membrane and differs from marked congestion of acute suppurative otitis media.
  • Tympanic membrane may show varying degree of retraction. Sometimes, it may appear full or slightly bulging in its posterior part due to effusion.
  • Fluid level and air bubbles may be seen when fluid is thin and tympanic membrane transparent
  • Mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute suppurative otitis media is an acute inflammation of middle ear by pyogenic organisms. Tympanic membrane is retracted with handle of malleus assuming a more horizontal position, prominence of lateral process of malleus and loss of light reflex. A cart-wheel appearance can be appreciated in later stages.

 

 

Option C. Chronic suppurative otitis media means long-standing infection of middle ear with discharge and permanent perforation.

 

Option D. Glomus tumor patients presents with hearing loss & tinnitus (pulsatile, swishing, synchronous with pulse).

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serous otitis media is a common cause of conductive hearing loss in children and can significantly impact speech development if untreated. It typically resolves spontaneously, but persistent cases require intervention to prevent long-term speech and language complications.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 69

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman consults the doctor for the presence of a skin lesion as shown in the image below. The lesions were initially small but have now spread to the entire limb and abdomen. Despite anticoagulation therapy, she has a history of long-standing diabetes and recurrent episodes of deep vein thrombosis. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glucagonoma

 

Glucagonoma is characterized by the presence of necrolytic migratory erythema (skin lesions), diabetes, and recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The skin rash and the patient’s history are indicative of this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Insulinoma: Presents with hypoglycemia.

 

Option B. Gastrinoma: Associated with Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, causing refractory peptic ulcers.

 

Option D. VIPoma: Presents with watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria (WDHA syndrome).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glucagonoma presents with necrolytic migratory erythema, diabetes, and recurrent DVT.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient with diabetes arrived at the clinic with a concerning issue - a black, malodorous discharge originating from her nose. Upon examination, it was discovered that the nasal cavity contained a dark necrotic mass, which had caused erosion of both the septum and hard palate. What could be the most likely diagnosis for this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mucormycosis

 

The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of Mucormycosis.

 

It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal. It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.

 

PATHOLOGY – From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain. The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES – Black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.

 

DIAGNOSIS – Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.

 

Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast MRI.

 

TREATMENT – Amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspergillosis: While Aspergillosis can also present with sinus involvement, it generally does not cause the rapidly progressive and destructive changes typical of mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Foreign Body: Would not typically lead to rapid tissue necrosis unless secondarily infected, and does not generally produce the black necrotic tissue associated with fungal infections.

 

Option D. Rhinosporidiosis: Caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi; presents with polypoid masses in the nasal passage, distinct from the necrotic presentation of mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mucormycosis should be considered a medical emergency in immunocompromised patients presenting with signs of rapid, invasive sinus infection. Early diagnosis and aggressive treatment are crucial to improve survival rates in affected individuals.

questions.text: All of the following shows Koebner's phenomenon, except? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Herpes

 

Herpes does not show Koebner's phenomenon.

 

Koebner or isomorphic phenomenon:

  • It is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have iso(same) & morphic (morphology) as existing lesions.
  • Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

 

 

  • The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Vitiligo: Exhibits true Koebner phenomenon where new depigmented patches form at the sites of skin trauma.

 

Option C. Lichen Planus: Shows Koebner's phenomenon where linear or annular lesions appear following skin trauma.

 

Option D. Psoriasis: Frequently demonstrates Koebner's phenomenon, with new psoriatic plaques forming along scratch marks or other traumatic injuries to the skin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Some rare causes of true Koebner phenomenon are:

Dariers disease, hailey hailey disease, EMF erythema multiforme, Kaposi’s sarcoma & lichen nitidus.

 

Reverse Koebner phenomenon or Renbeok phenomenon:

Seen in psoriasis. The area of psoriasis clears & heals following injury (trauma)

 

Reference:

Harrison’s principles of internal medicine 19th edition Page no 347

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with first trimester pregnancy comes to you in hospital with high level of T3 and T4. Which of the following drug is most appropriate to use? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Propylthiouracil

 

In a pregnant patient with hyperthyroidism, particularly in the first trimester, the choice of antithyroid medication is crucial to avoid teratogenic effects. Propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred during the first trimester because it has a lower risk of causing congenital anomalies compared to methimazole or carbimazole.

 

  • Propylthiouracil (PTU) is considered the drug of choice for managing hyperthyroidism during the first trimester of pregnancy. This is because PTU has a lower risk of causing congenital anomalies compared to carbimazole or methimazole, which can lead to aplasia cutis (a congenital absence of skin) if used during the first trimester.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carbimazole: Carbimazole is typically avoided in the first trimester of pregnancy because it can cause congenital malformations, such as aplasia cutis. It may be used in the second and third trimesters when the risk of teratogenicity is lower.

 

Option C. Potassium iodine: Potassium iodine is not typically used as a first-line treatment for hyperthyroidism during pregnancy. It is more commonly used in preparation for thyroid surgery or in radiation emergencies to block thyroid uptake of radioactive iodine.

 

Option D. Propranolol: Propranolol is a beta-blocker used to manage the symptoms of hyperthyroidism, such as tachycardia and tremors, but it does not treat the underlying condition. It is not an appropriate choice as a primary antithyroid medication during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ﻿Anti-thyroid DOC in first trimester: PTU
  • ﻿Anti-Thyroid DOC in 2nd and 3rd trimester: Methimazole/ Carbimazole- they can lead to Aplasia cutis if used in the first trimester.
  • ﻿Overall, if trimester is not mentioned in the question, then the antithyroid drug of choice in pregnancy is Propylthiouracil.

questions.text: Which of the following is the causative agent for acne fulminans? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Propionibacterium

 

Cutibacterium acnes (previously known as Propionibacterium acnes)

 

  • It is the causative agent for acne fulminans/Acne Maligna.
  • Acne fulminans is a severe destructive form of acne. It is predominantly seen in white, adolescent males.
  • The exact etiopathogenesis of this disease is unknown. Propionibacterium aces infection and the presence of elevated testosterone levels have been linked, though.

 

Clinical presentation:

 

  • Numerous hemorrhagic and ulcerative nodules suddenly appear on the face, back, and trunk. Additionally, various indicators of systemic inflammation, such as fever and arthralgia, may coexist with the lesions.

 

Below image depicts erosive crusting lesions on the back of a young male with acne fulminans.

 

 

Mild to moderate acne that has been present for six months to two years, along with antimicrobial treatment failure is frequently an important clue in the history given by the patients of acne fulminans.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bifidobacterium is a genus of gram-positive bacteria that is part of the normal flora of the human gut and does not cause acne.

 

Option C. Mobiluncus is a genus of bacteria that can be associated with bacterial vaginosis but is not a cause of acne.

 

Option D. Actinomyces is a genus of bacteria that can cause actinomycosis, which typically presents as chronic progressive suppurative disease, not acne.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cutibacterium acnes (formerly k/a Propionibacterium acnes) is the bacteria associated with the pathogenesis of acne, including severe forms such as acne fulminans.

 

Features of Acne Fulminans:

 

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 90.50, 154.10

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is cosmetically preferred for appendectomy? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lanz

 

The Lanz incision is the most cosmetically preferred incision for an appendectomy. It is made along the skin crease, resulting in a less noticeable scar.

 

Gridiron or McBurney incisions are muscle-splitting incisions centered at McBurney's point. They are traditional incisions used for appendectomy but may result in more visible scars compared to the Lanz incision.

 

Rutherford Morrison incision is a muscle-cutting incision that provides adequate exposure during appendectomy, especially for more complicated cases. However, it is less cosmetically appealing due to the larger scar it leaves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gridiron: This incision is centered at McBurney's point and involves splitting the muscles, which can leave a more noticeable scar.

 

Option B. Rutherford Morrison: This is a muscle-cutting incision that provides good exposure for appendectomy but results in a larger, less cosmetic scar.

 

Option D. McBurney: Similar to the Gridiron incision, it is centered at McBurney's point and involves splitting the muscles, leading to a more visible scar compared to the Lanz incision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Lanz incision is cosmetically preferred for appendectomy due to its alignment along the skin crease, resulting in a less noticeable scar compared to other traditional incisions.

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents with a history of low-grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain and amenorrhea for six months. On examination, a pelvic mass is felt on the left side and signs of ascites are positive. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Genital tuberculosis

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of genital tuberculosis. The following features support this diagnosis:

 

  • Amenorrhea: Genital tuberculosis can affect the menstrual cycle, often leading to amenorrhea.
  • Palpable abdominopelvic mass:BIn genital tuberculosis, the mass is typically a tubo-ovarian mass that is adherent to the omentum and adjacent structures.
  • Fever, weight loss, and abdominal pain: These are classic systemic symptoms of tuberculosis.
  • Ascites: The presence of ascites can be associated with advanced cases of genital tuberculosis.
  • Low-grade fever: The presence of a classic low-grade fever helps to differentiate genital tuberculosis from other conditions listed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Submucous fibroid: Submucous fibroids are benign tumors of the uterus that can cause abnormal uterine bleeding and pelvic pressure but are not typically associated with systemic symptoms like fever and weight loss.

 

Option B. Ovarian malignancy: Ovarian malignancy can present with a pelvic mass and ascites but is less likely to be associated with low-grade fever and the classic history of tuberculosis symptoms.

 

Option C. Ectopic pregnancy: Ectopic pregnancy typically presents with acute abdominal pain and bleeding, not with chronic symptoms like weight loss and low-grade fever. Additionally, the presence of ascites is unusual in ectopic pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Genital tuberculosis should be suspected in patients with a history of amenorrhea, systemic symptoms such as low-grade fever, weight loss, and abdominal pain, along with a palpable abdominopelvic mass and ascites.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Page 137

questions.text: A patient aged 45 years presents with swelling in MCP joints and his serum uric acid levels were found to be elevated. His physician prescribed a drug which is considered as the first line agent in the management of this condition. What is the mechanism of this drug? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Xanthine oxidase inhibitor

 

The clinical presentation of this patient is suggestive of gout, characterized by swelling in the MCP joints and elevated serum uric acid levels. Allopurinol is generally considered the first-line urate-lowering agent for gout. It works by inhibiting xanthine oxidase, an enzyme involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and then to uric acid. By inhibiting this enzyme, allopurinol reduces the production of uric acid, thereby lowering serum urate levels and preventing gout flares.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Inhibitor of neutrophil recruitment: Is Colchicine. It is indicated in Acute gout but is not considered as a first line drug as it can cause refractory diarrhea.

 

Option C. Uricosuric drugs: Are those which increase the excretion of uric acid in urine. These drugs are indicated in chronic gout. Examples include Lesinurad, Probenecid, Sulfinpyrazone etc.

 

Option D. Pyrimidine antimetabolite: Is a class of drugs used in cancer treatment. These drugs are structural analogs of pyrimidine nucleotides, which are essential building blocks for DNA and RNA synthesis. Examples include 5-Fluorouracil, Capecitabine, Cytarabine etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Allopurinol, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, is the first-line agent for lowering urate levels in the management of gout.

choices.text: NK cells
T cells
B cells
Plasma cells

questions.text: Which cell responsible for cellular graft rejection? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T cells

 

T cells are predominantly responsible for graft rejection.

 

Graft rejection occurs when the immune system of a recipient recognizes a transplanted organ as foreign and mounts an attack against it. There are three types of graft rejection:

 

  1. Hyperacute rejection: this occurs within minutes to hours of transplantation and is caused by pre-existing antibodies against the donor organ. The antibodies activate complement and cause endothelial cell damage, leading to thrombosis of the blood vessels supplying the organ.
  1. Acute rejection: this occurs within days to weeks of transplantation and is caused by T cell-mediated immune responses against the donor organ. The immune response leads to infiltration of the organ by lymphocytes and macrophages, resulting in tissue damage and dysfunction.
  2. Chronic rejection: this occurs months to years after transplantation and is characterized by a gradual decline in organ function. The exact mechanisms of chronic rejection are not fully understood, but it is believed to be caused by a combination of immune and non-immune factors.

 

Prevention of graft rejection involves the use of immunosuppressive drugs, such as calcineurin inhibitors, corticosteroids, and antimetabolites. However, these drugs also increase the risk of infection and malignancy. Close monitoring of transplant recipients is necessary to detect and manage graft rejection early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NK cells: Natural Killer cells play a role in the innate immune response but are not primarily responsible for graft rejection.

 

Option C. B cells: B cells produce antibodies and play a role in humoral immunity but are not the main cells responsible for graft rejection.

 

Option D. Plasma cells: Plasma cells are derived from B cells and produce antibodies, contributing to humoral immunity, but are not the primary cells involved in graft rejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

T cells are primarily responsible for graft rejection, particularly acute rejection, through cell-mediated immune responses against the donor organ.

choices.text: Breast cancer in the opposite breast

questions.text: A patient with unilateral breast cancer is started on tamoxifen. This will increase the risk of: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) that is used in the treatment and prevention of breast cancer. While it acts as an anti-estrogen on breast tissue, it has a partial estrogen agonist effect on the endometrium. This effect increases the risk of endometrial cancer by 1-2%.

 

Women on tamoxifen therapy are advised to undergo regular transvaginal ultrasounds (TVS) to monitor for endometrial thickening, which can be an early sign of endometrial hyperplasia or cancer.

 

Risk factors for endometrial cancer include:

 

  • Obesity
  • Use of unopposed estrogen
  • Tamoxifen use
  • Prior family history or personal history of endometrial cancer
  • Endometrial hyperplasia
  • Uterine fibroids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ovarian cancer: Tamoxifen use does not increase the risk of ovarian cancer.

 

Option C. Breast cancer in the opposite breast: Tamoxifen is actually used to reduce the risk of breast cancer recurrence and the development of new breast cancers.

 

Option D. Cervical cancer: Tamoxifen does not increase the risk of cervical cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tamoxifen therapy in breast cancer patients increases the risk of endometrial cancer. Regular monitoring with transvaginal ultrasound is recommended to detect early signs of endometrial pathology.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Page 355

questions.text: During a complex surgical procedure in an operating theatre (OT) of a tertiary care hospital, a significant amount of blood is spilled onto the floor. To ensure proper disinfection of the spilled blood and mitigate risks associated with blood-borne pathogens, which compound should be used for effective cleaning? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Chlorine compound

 

Sodium hypochlorite, a chlorine compound, is the best disinfectant for cleaning blood spills. It effectively neutralizes blood-borne pathogens, ensuring a sterile environment in the OT. For a blood spill, a 1% hypochlorite solution should be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phenolic compound: Not as effective for blood spills.

 

Option B. Alcoholic compound: Ineffective for large blood spills as it may not fully neutralize pathogens.

 

Option C. Quaternary ammonium compounds: Less effective against blood-borne pathogens in spills.

 

Educational Objective:


For disinfecting blood spills, a 1% sodium hypochlorite solution is the most effective compound to ensure proper disinfection and safety.

choices.text: Hep B
Hep C
Hep A

questions.text: Which of the following is not tested during blood transfusion? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hep A

 

Hepatitis A (Hep A) has no role in blood transfusion screening as it spreads through the fecal-oral route rather than through blood. Blood transfusion screenings commonly test for infections that are bloodborne.

 

Additional Information

 

 

Diagnostic markers for Hepatitis D:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HIV 1, 2: These are routinely screened in blood transfusions to prevent the transmission of HIV.

 

Option B. Hep B: Hepatitis B virus is screened in blood transfusions as it is a bloodborne pathogen.

 

Option C. Hep C: Hepatitis C virus is also screened in blood transfusions due to its bloodborne nature.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis A is not tested during blood transfusions as it spreads through the fecal-oral route and is not a bloodborne pathogen.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. He also complains of excessive fatigability towards the end of the day which improves with rest. Placing an ice pack over his eyes significantly decreases the ptosis. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myasthenia gravis

 

Myasthenia gravis is characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness, worsening with activity and improving with rest. The ptosis (drooping of eyelids) improving with rest and with the application of an ice pack (ice pack test) is a classical presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Huntington chorea: Presents with classic triad of dementia, chorea, and psychiatric symptoms.

 

Option C. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis: Presents with both upper and lower motor neuron signs, such as spasticity and muscle wasting.

 

Option D. External ophthalmoplegia: Typically involves paralysis of the eye muscles, but ptosis with diurnal variation is more indicative of myasthenia gravis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Myasthenia gravis is diagnosed with fluctuating muscle weakness, ptosis, and positive ice pack test.

questions.text: Which vitamin deficiency leads to given clinical condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Niacin

 

Niacin (Vitamin B3) Deficiency: This is Casal’s Necklace shown in the figure which occur due to Niacin deficiency (Pellagra).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B.  Vitamin B12 Deficiency: This can cause megaloblastic anemia and neurological disorders. The anemia is characterized by large, immature red blood cells, while neurological symptoms may include numbness and tingling in the hands and feet, difficulty walking, and memory loss.

 

Option C.  Vitamin B5 (Pantothenic Acid) Deficiency: Deficiency in vitamin B5 is very rare but can lead to a syndrome known as "burning feet syndrome." Other symptoms might include fatigue, insomnia, depression, irritability, vomiting, stomach pains, and upper respiratory infections.

 

Option D.  Thiamin (Vitamin B1) Deficiency: This leads to beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome. Beriberi can manifest as either wet beriberi (affecting the cardiovascular system) or dry beriberi (affecting the nervous system). Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is a serious condition typically seen in chronic alcoholics and involves severe neurological disturbances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symptoms of Niacin deficiency (pellagra): 3Ds

 

  • Dermatitis: In early stages, bright red erythema occurs in feet, ankles and face. Increased pigmentation around the neck is known as Casal’s necklace.
  • Dementia
  • Death

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 542

questions.text: Which of the following drugs does not reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF)? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Digoxin


Digoxin does not reduce mortality in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). While digoxin can improve symptoms and reduce hospitalizations due to its positive inotropic effects (increasing the force of heart muscle contractions) and modulation of the autonomic nervous system, it has not been shown to have a significant impact on overall survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate: This combination has been shown to reduce mortality, particularly in African American patients with HFrEF. Hydralazine decreases afterload through arterial dilation, and isosorbide dinitrate decreases preload through venous dilation.

 

Option B. Beta blockers: Beta blockers (such as carvedilol, metoprolol succinate, and bisoprolol) are proven to reduce mortality in HFrEF patients by improving heart function, reducing the heart rate, and decreasing the workload on the heart.

 

Option C. ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors (such as enalapril, lisinopril) reduce mortality in HFrEF by blocking the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), which decreases blood pressure and reduces the strain on the heart, thereby slowing the progression of heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with HFrEF are :

 

  • Beta blockers

  • ACE inhibitors

  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)

  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists

  • Angiotensin receptor-neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI)

  • Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate

questions.text: Bitot’s spots are seen in deficiency of:(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Vitamin A: This is the correct answer. Bitot's spots are a classic sign of Vitamin A deficiency. They are characterized by the buildup of keratin debris in small, foamy patches on the conjunctiva of the eyes. Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining a healthy epithelium and is also essential for proper vision, particularly in low-light conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D3: Deficiency of Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) can lead to bone-related issues such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, but it is not associated with Bitot's spots. Vitamin D is primarily involved in calcium and phosphate metabolism.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: While Vitamin E is an important antioxidant, its deficiency typically manifests in neurological problems and immune system issues rather than eye changes like Bitot's spots.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Deficiency of Vitamin C leads to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms related to poor collagen synthesis, such as bleeding gums, bruising, and poor wound healing. It does not cause Bitot's spots.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bitot’s spot occurs due to vitamin A deficiency. There is build-up of keratin located superficially in conjunctiva. This can be oval, triangular or irregular in shape. This is also associated with conjunctival xerosis.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 393

questions.text: For what condition is the Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) utilized? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Congenital external auditory atresia

 

Bone Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA) is utilized in congenital external auditory canal atresia.

 

Bone-Anchored Hearing Aid (BAHA)

 

It has 3 parts. The titanium screw is fitted into skull bone behind mastoid and left for 6 months for osseous integration to occur. The processor is fitted into this screw with help of abutment. Suits better for people with canal problems or congenital aural atresia.

 

Indications for BAHA

 

  1. When air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:
    1. Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment.
    2. Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment.
    3. Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.
  2. Conductive or mixed hearing loss, e.g., otosclerosis and tympanosclerosis where surgery is contraindicated.
  3. Single-sided hearing loss.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sensorineural hearing loss: BAHA can be used for single-sided sensorineural hearing loss but is not typically the first choice for bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option B. Acoustic neuroma: While BAHA may help restore hearing on the side affected by an acoustic neuroma, this is not the primary indication.

 

Option D. Otitis media: Chronic otitis media can be an indication for BAHA if traditional hearing aids cannot be used due to recurrent infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

BAHA is a valuable hearing solution for patients with congenital external auditory atresia or other conditions where traditional hearing aids are impractical. It provides an alternative auditory pathway by directly stimulating the cochlea via bone conduction, effectively bypassing problems in the outer or middle ear.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 136, 137

questions.text: Which of the following scenarios would contribute the most to the demographic burden in a country? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Increased old age dependency ratio

 

Demographic burden is represented by age dependency ratio. Increase in old age dependency ratio majorly contribute to demographic burden.

 

Demographic bonus is a condition in which the productive age population is more than the non-productive population. When we have a higher number of economically productive population, it is called as a demographic bonus. It is achieved when we can see a decline in the dependency ratio.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An increased old age dependency ratio contributes significantly to the demographic burden in a country with a growing elderly population.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presented to the surgery OPD. On examination, his left scrotal sac is empty. On clinical examination the left testis was found in the superficial inguinal pouch. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Left ectopic testis

 

The given condition with left testis being in ectopic location (superficial inguinal pouch) is ectopic testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryptorchidism and Option B. Left undescended testis: In undescended testis there is both abnormal development and abnormal location of testis but along the normal path of Descent. It may get spontaneously resolved within 3 months. Till then, the best step should be to wait and watch. Best age for orchidopexy is 6 months and should not be delayed beyond 12 months.

 

Option D. Retractile Testis: Retractile testis has completed the descent but found in groin due to overactive cremasteric reflex, it requires no Treatment and resolves on its own.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ectopic testis refers to a testis that has deviated from the normal path of descent and is located in an abnormal position outside the inguinal canal and scrotum.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man from a rural area presents with acute diarrhea, knee swelling, and abdominal distension after his family began using mustard oil for cooking. Which condition is most likely causing these symptoms? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Epidemic dropsy

 

Epidemic dropsy is caused by the adulteration of mustard oil with argemone oil, which contains the toxic compound sanguinarine. This toxin interferes with metabolic processes, leading to symptoms like acute diarrhea, bilateral swelling (edema), abdominal distension, and in severe cases, cardiac complications and glaucoma. The presence of these symptoms following the introduction of a new cooking oil strongly suggests epidemic dropsy.

 

Other characteristics of Epidemic Dropsy:

 

  • Epidemic dropsy may occur in all ages except breast – fed infants
  • The mortality of epidemic dropsy varies from 5-50%
