  • Edema in epidemic dropsy occurs due to proteinuria (specifically loss of albumin).
  • Argemone oil may be detected by following tests:
    • Nitric acid test
    • Paper chromatography test: Most sensitive test

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endemic ascites: Caused due to toxin Pyrrolizidine in millets when adulterated with Crotolaria seeds. It is hepatotoxic.

 

Option C. Aflatoxicosis: Caused by Aflatoxin secreted by Aspergillus Flavus affecting the stored food items like grains, nuts and rice. It leads to Cirrhosis

 

Option D. Lathyrism: Caused by Beta Oxalyl Amino Alanine in Khesari Dal. It leads to neurological features like inability to walk, clumsy gait, jerky steps etc.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food Adulteration Diseases

questions.text: A newborn had hypoplasia of the mandibles and zygomatic bones, malformed external ears, and slanted palpebral fissures. Abnormality in the development of which of the following pharyngeal arches will most likely lead to the given condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pharyngeal arch 1

 

Explanation     

 

The term "first arch syndrome" refers to a group of congenital conditions and anomalies that are associated with developmental issues affecting structures derived from the first pharyngeal arch during embryonic development (due to the failure of the neural crest cells to migrate into the 1st pharyngeal arch).

 

 

Treacher Collins Syndrome (mandibulofacial dysostosis) this condition involves underdevelopment of the cheekbones, lower jaw, and ears. Individuals with Treacher Collins syndrome may have facial deformities, hearing loss, and other craniofacial abnormalities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pharyngeal arch 2:  The second pharyngeal arch contributes to the formation of the Reichert's cartilage, which gives rise to several structures in the ear and throat. Conditions such as anomalies of the stapes bone can lead to conductive hearing loss, facial weakness or paralysis, Brachial arch cyst and Goldenhar syndrome.

 

Option C. Pharyngeal arch 3:  anomalies related to third pharyngeal arch are: Branchio-oto-renal (BOR) Syndrome: This syndrome affects the development of structures derived from the first, second, and third pharyngeal arches. Common features include branchial arch anomalies (e.g., branchial cleft cysts), hearing loss, and kidney abnormalities.

 

Velocardiofacial Syndrome (VCFS): involves the deletion of a portion of chromosome 22. It is associated with a wide range of symptoms, including cardiac defects, cleft palate, characteristic facial features, and developmental issues related to the third and fourth pharyngeal arches.

 

DiGeorge Syndrome: DiGeorge syndrome is caused by a deletion in chromosome 22 and is characterized by congenital heart defects, immunodeficiency, and hypoparathyroidism. It can also involve craniofacial abnormalities related to the pharyngeal arches.

 

Option D. Pharyngeal arch 4:  Anomalies related to the fourth pharyngeal arch are relatively rare compared to those associated with the first and second arches. It includes laryngeal and pharyngeal anomalies, cardiovascular anomalies and respiratory distress & failure. It could me related to thyroid abscess and thyroiditis. 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Grievous hurt is defined as severe body pain in which an individual is unable to follow ordinary pursuits for at least ------ : (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 days

 

Explanation:

 

Grievous hurt is legally defined in several jurisdictions based on specific criteria, including the duration of incapacitation. One such criterion is severe body pain or injury that renders the individual unable to pursue ordinary pursuits for at least 20 days.

 

Grievous Hurt (Defined in 320 IPC)

 

  1. Emasculation
  2. Permanent privation of sight of either eye
  3. Permanent privation of hearing of either ear.
  4. Privation of any member of joint
  5. Destruction or permanent impairment of power of any member or joint.
  6. Permanent disfiguration of head or face.
  7. Fracture or dislocation of bone or tooth.
  8. Any hurt which

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 14 days: This is insufficient to meet the criteria of grievous hurt.

 

Option B. 18 days: This is shorter than the defined period.

 

Option D. 26 days: This exceeds the required duration and is not the legal benchmark.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The legal definition of grievous hurt often hinges on the duration of incapacity, and understanding this is crucial for both legal and medical professionals in assessing and documenting injuries accurately.

questions.text: In a health survey from a diverse district near Pune, the data shows a wide range of values due to different urban and rural populations. Which measure of central tendency is most appropriate for summarizing this data given its variability? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median

 

The median is the most appropriate measure of central tendency for this data because it is not affected by extreme values or outliers. In a dataset with a wide range of values, such as one from a diverse district, the median provides a better summary of the central value by focusing on the middle point, thereby mitigating the impact of extremes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mean: The mean is the average of all values and can be skewed by extreme values, making it less representative in this case.

 

Option C. Mode: The mode is the most frequently occurring value but may not reflect the central tendency in a dataset with a wide range of values.

 

Option D. Mean deviation: Mean deviation measures dispersion, not central tendency, and thus does not summarize the central value effectively.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The median is the best measure of central tendency for datasets with a wide range of values or outliers, as it is unaffected by extremes.

choices.text: Antibody mediated
Immune complex mediated
IgE mediated

questions.text: A young female went for camping with her boyfriend. She had a bee sting which resulted in edema, redness on face and difficulty in breathing. What is the type of mechanism responsible for this type of reaction? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgE mediated

 

IgE antibody is responsible for type 1 hypersensitivity. IgE is responsible for mast cell sensitization. Histamine release is responsible for increased vascular permeability, increased vasodilation and contraction of smooth muscle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibody mediated: This is a broad term and could refer to types II, III, or IV hypersensitivity, but not specifically type I which is IgE-mediated.

 

Option B. Immune complex mediated: This refers to type III hypersensitivity, which involves antigen-antibody complexes and is not related to the immediate reaction seen in type I hypersensitivity.

 

Option C. Cell mediated: This refers to type IV hypersensitivity, which involves T cells and is a delayed-type reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

IgE-mediated reactions are responsible for type 1 hypersensitivity reactions, such as those triggered by bee stings, leading to symptoms like edema, redness, and difficulty breathing due to mast cell degranulation and histamine release.

questions.text: A pediatrician discusses the measles vaccination schedule for a 7-month-old who received an early dose during an outbreak. The mother is unsure about the timing of the next dose. What is the recommended age for administering the next standard measles vaccine dose? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 9 months

 

In case of disasters, measles vaccine given before 9 months is considered as zero dose and 1st dose will be given as per vaccination schedule at 9 months again.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Administering an early measles vaccine dose during an outbreak does not alter the standard immunization schedule. The next dose should still be given at 9 months to ensure effective and lasting immunity against measles.

questions.text: Absent P waves is a feature of which of the following? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Atrial fibrillation

 

In atrial fibrillation, the atria do not contract effectively, leading to the absence of P waves on the ECG. The rhythm is irregularly irregular, and there is NO A wave in the JVP, NO p wave in ECG, NO fourth heart sound, and NO pre-systolic accentuation in mitral stenosis (4 NO’s).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular tachycardia: Characterized by wide QRS complexes and not the absence of P waves.

 

Option B. Focal atrial tachycardia: Will still show P waves, but they may be abnormal in appearance.

 

Option C. Ventricular fibrillation: Presents with a chaotic, irregular waveform without identifiable QRS complexes, P waves, or T waves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of P waves and an irregularly irregular rhythm on an ECG are characteristic of atrial fibrillation.

questions.text: The perversion that involves sexual gratification by inflicting pain on the partner is known as? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sadism

 

Sexual perversions, also known as paraphilias, are patterns of sexual arousal or behavior that involve unusual objects, activities, or situations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Masochism: Obtaining sexual pleasure from receiving pain, suffering, or humiliation.

 

Option C. Voyeurism: Achieving sexual arousal by observing unsuspecting people, typically engaging in sexual activity.

 

Option D. Exhibitionism: Achieving sexual gratification by exposing one's genitals to an unsuspecting person.

 

In this scenario, the correct answer is sadism since it specifically involves sexual pleasure from inflicting pain on a partner.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sadism is deriving sexual pleasure from inflicting pain, suffering, or humiliation on another person. It is more commonly seen in males.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 597.

questions.text: Which perspective provides the clearest view of the frontal sinus? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Caldwell’s view

 

The Caldwell view is a caudally angled radiograph, with its posteroanterior projection allowing for minimal radiation to the orbits.

 

The rays pass from behind the head and are angled at 15-20° to the radiographic plate. It is commonly used to get better view of the ethmoid and frontal sinuses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Towne's View: Primarily used for examining the foramen magnum at the base of the skull, not ideal for sinus examination.

 

Option C. Law's View: Typically used for visualizing the mastoid air cells, not the frontal sinuses.

 

Option D. Stenver's View: Used for imaging the internal auditory canal and cochlea, not related to sinus imaging

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

  • Stenver’s view is done for cochlear implants.

 

 

  • Law’s view is used to assess mastoid air cells.

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 493, 494

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presents with low back ache for 20 days. CE-MRI is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?  (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Pott’s spine

 

The given spine sagittal T2W MRI shows paradiscal involvement of the spine with destroyed IV disc and a component of epidural abscess which is suggestive of Pott's spine.

 

MC site of TB spine: Thoracic vertebrae

 

MC pattern: Paradiscal

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Multiple myeloma:  Multifocal non-contiguous vertebral involvement. MRI would show a mini-brain appearance in plasmacytoma (solitary MM).

 

Fig: Mini-brain appearance

 

Option B. Ankylosing spondylitis: Fusion of vertebrae - Typically X-ray or CT would be given to show bamboo spine.

 

Fig: Ankylosing spondylitis - Bamboo spine

 

Option C. Pyogenic spondylitis: Involves multiple contiguous vertebrae.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pott's spine should be considered in patients presenting with back pain and MRI findings of disc destruction and epidural abscess, particularly in regions where tuberculosis is common.

questions.text: What is the best investigation for GERD? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring

 

GERD has triad of retrosternal heart burn, epigastric pain and regurgitation. Investigation of choice for GERD: 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Upper GI endoscopy: While it can visualize the damage or inflammation caused by GERD (like esophagitis or Barrett's esophagus), it doesn't provide direct evidence of acid reflux. It's useful for assessing complications or when GERD symptoms are severe.

 

Option C. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): Beneficial in evaluating hiatus hernias.

 

Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): It doesn't directly measure acid reflux or its effects on the esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice for diagnosing GERD (Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease) is 24-hour ambulatory pH monitoring.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis of the ECG given below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypothermia

 

The ECG shows long QT interval and J waves (Osborn waves), which are characteristic of hypothermia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: Shows tall T waves, widened QRS complexes, and absent P waves.

 

Option C. Hypokalemia: Shows prominent U waves, flattened T waves, and ST depression.

 

Option D. Hypocalcemia: Shows prolonged QT interval but no J waves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothermia is diagnosed with an ECG showing J waves and prolonged QT interval.

choices.text: Criggler Najar syndrome
Dubin Johnson syndrome
Rotor syndrome
Gilbert syndrome

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with a history of multiple episodes of jaundice. On examination, mild hepatosplenomegaly is noted, along with the presence of unconjugated bilirubin (UCB) normal LFT and scleral icterus. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gilbert syndrome

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common, mild liver disorder in which the liver doesn't properly process bilirubin. Bilirubin is produced by the breakdown of red blood cells. Gilbert syndrome is often characterized by transient episodes of mild jaundice (yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes) due to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the bloodstream.

 

  • Decreased production of glucuronyl transferase: This enzyme is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin in the liver. In Gilbert syndrome, the production of this enzyme is reduced, leading to increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin in the blood.
  • More common in men, occurring in 2-3% of the male population.
  • Usually asymptomatic hyperbilirubinemia with normal liver function tests: Despite the elevated bilirubin, liver function tests remain normal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Crigler-Najjar syndrome: This is a more severe inherited disorder where there is a very low activity of the enzyme glucuronyl transferase. It leads to severe hyperbilirubinemia in neonates, complicated by kernicterus and early death.

 

Option B. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: This condition involves a defect in the transfer of conjugated bilirubin into the biliary canaliculi, leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Option C. Rotor syndrome: Similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome but with milder symptoms and without liver cell pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome is characterized by mild, recurrent jaundice due to elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin with normal liver function tests.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy brought to OPD, born from consanguineous couple, complains of change of colour of urine. Mother gives history that she noticed a dark colour on diapers when her baby was few months old. Which enzyme deficiency is present in the given patients?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Homogentisic acid dioxygenase

 

Homogentisic Acid Dioxygenase: Deficiency in homogentisic acid dioxygenase leads to a condition known as alkaptonuria. One of the hallmark symptoms of alkaptonuria is that urine becomes dark or black when exposed to air. This occurs due to the accumulation and oxidation of homogentisic acid, a compound that is normally broken down by this enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Phenylalanine Hydroxylase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes phenylketonuria (PKU). PKU typically presents with elevated levels of phenylalanine in the blood and various neurological symptoms, such as developmental delays, but it does not cause urine to darken upon exposure to air.

 

Option C.  Tyrosine Aminotransferase: Deficiency in this enzyme can lead to tyrosinemia, which has different types, but none are typically characterized by darkening of the urine upon exposure to air. Tyrosinemia can cause liver and kidney problems and affects amino acid metabolism.

 

Option D.  Pyruvic Acid Dioxygenase: There is no enzyme by this exact name. However, disorders in pyruvate metabolism (involving enzymes like pyruvate dehydrogenase) can lead to various metabolic problems, but they do not cause urine to darken upon exposure to air.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark color diaper of child indicates deficiency of enzyme Homogentisic acid dioxygenase which is required for catabolism of tyrosine metabolite homogentisic acid, a condition known as Alkaptonuria. The urine which contain this acid turns black on exposure to air due to oxidation of this acid.

 

Over the years, homogentisic acid gets polymerized to form alkapton bodies which gets deposited in connective tissues causing bluish-black discoloration of skin.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 296

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with no comorbidities presented with numbness and paresthesia of the fingers along with the characteristic finding as shown in the image below. She has no other illnesses and she says these episodes occur when she is under excess stress or during cold temperatures. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Primary Raynaud's phenomenon

 

Primary Raynaud's phenomenon is characterized by episodic vasospasm of the fingers  (thumbs spared) triggered by stress or cold, leading to pallor, cyanosis, and redness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Secondary Raynaud's phenomenon: Usually associated with underlying conditions like scleroderma and involves the thumb.

 

Option C. Cold sores: Caused by herpes simplex virus, presenting as vesicular eruptions.

 

Option D. Scleroderma: Can cause Raynaud's phenomenon but usually presents with skin thickening and other systemic symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary Raynaud's phenomenon presents with episodic vasospasm of the fingers without an underlying disease.

questions.text: A male patient with a history of chronic smoking presents with the complaint of dysphagia. Out of the following, which type of lung cancer is most likely to be found in this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Squamous cell carcinoma

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is strongly associated with smoking. It can produce paraneoplastic syndromes, such as hypercalcemia due to PTH-related peptide secretion, and often presents with cavitating lung lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenocarcinoma: More commonly seen in non-smokers and peripherally located in the lungs.

 

Option C. Large cell carcinoma: Less common and not as strongly associated with smoking.

 

Option D. Merkel cell carcinoma: A rare skin cancer not associated with lung cancer or smoking.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is strongly linked to smoking and may present with hypercalcemia and cavitating lung lesions.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of tingling sensation in hands and feet, generalised weakness, easy fatigability, pallor, and ataxia. Deficiency of which vitamin causes these symptoms? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to both hematological and neurological manifestations.

 

Hematologically, it causes megaloblastic anemia, which is why patients may experience weakness, easy fatigability, and pallor.

 

Neurologically, it causes peripheral neuropathy, leading to tingling sensations in the hands and feet. It also affects the spinal cord, causing subacute combined degeneration due to demyelination of the posterior columns and corticospinal tracts, resulting in sensory ataxia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1: Deficiency causes beriberi, which can be wet (causing cardiac failure) or dry (causing peripheral neuropathy). In severe alcoholics & malignancy patients, it can cause Wernicke's encephalopathy and Korsakoff psychosis.

 

Option C. Vitamin B2: Deficiency leads to riboflavin deficiency, causing cheilitis, glossitis (magenta colored tongue), and mouth sores.

 

Option D. Vitamin B3: Niacin Deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the 4D’s: diarrhea, dementia, dermatitis & death, which appears as a rash in sun-exposed areas, known as Casal’s necklace.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause megaloblastic anemia and neurological issues such as peripheral neuropathy and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord.

questions.text: A tourist aged 45 years with a travel history to India presents with complaints of abdominal pain and multiple episodes of watery diarrhea. He reports having food at a local restaurant the previous night. Which of the following antidiarrheal agents is used in this condition? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Rifaximin

 

The clinical scenario is suggestive of Traveler’s diarrhea. Out of the options mentioned above, Rifaximin can be used. It is used in infective diarrheas along with ORS or IV fluids in order to control the symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Octreotide: Is a somatostatin analog effective in treating severe secretory diarrhea that occurs due to hormone-secreting tumors in the GIT and pancreas. Its use is limited in traveler's diarrhea.
 

Option C. Mosapride: Is a 5HT4 agonist. It is a prokinetic drug.


Option D. Bismuth subcitrate: Is used as an ulcer protective drug in peptic ulcer disease. It is not preferred in Traveler’s diarrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rifaximin is the preferred antidiarrheal agent for treating Traveler’s diarrhea due to its effectiveness against non-invasive strains of E. coli, commonly responsible for this condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old demographer describes the demographic transition of a European nation currently in the 5th stage of its demographic cycle. Which of the following statements best describes the country's demographic characteristics in this stage? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Birth rate < Death rate

 

In the context of the demographic transition model, the 5th stage is characterized by a situation where the birth rate falls below the death rate. This leads to a natural decrease in population size.

 

Demographic Cycle:

 

Stage 1: (high stationary): High birth rate & high death rate

 

Stage 2: (early expanding): Birth rate unchanged & death rate decrease

 

Stage3: (late expanding): Birth rate: decreases &death rate: decreases

 

Stage 4: (late stationary): Br: low & dr: low

 

Stage 5: (declining): Br < dr/ population decreases

 

 

Minimum demographic gap: Stage 1 & stage 4

 

Maximum demographic gap: Late part of stage 2

 

India is in: Stage 3 (late expanding stage)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Birth rate is unchanged: This does not characterize any specific stage of demographic transition accurately.

 

Option B. Death rate declines: This typically occurs in the early stages (Stage 2 and 3) of the demographic transition.

 

Option D. Positive demographic gap: This indicates a situation where the birth rate is higher than the death rate, leading to population growth, typical of Stage 2 and early Stage 3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Stage 5 of the demographic transition, the birth rate falls below the death rate, leading to a natural decrease in population.

questions.text: The highest incidence of ureteric injury is seen in? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Wertheim's hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ureteric injury is most commonly associated with Wertheim hysterectomy than other hysterectomies due to the radical nature of the procedure.
  • But the most common cause of ureteric injury is still ABDOMINAL hysterectomy as this is the most commonly done type of hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic hysterectomies are also associated with a high incidence of ureteric injuries (After radical hysterectomyP
  • Overall incidence of ureteric injury is 0.5 -1 percent of all pelvic operations.

 

Wertheim’s hysterectomy: As mentioned is a radical surgery involving extensive dissection and hence the chance of injury is most likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. Abdominal hysterectomy: Ureteric injury may occur during complex cases with distortion of anatomy such cervical fibroids, broad ligament fibroids, endometriosis etc

 

Option A. Vaginal hysterectomy: Ureter may also be injured in a vaginal hysterectomy although rare.

 

Option D. Emergency Caesarean section: It is a rare complication (1 in 1000) and occur in cases while trying to control bleeding when there is a lateral extension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ureteric injury is most commonly associated with Wertheim's hysterectomy due to its radical nature, involving extensive dissection around the ureters.

 

Ref: D. C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition page 425

questions.text: A patient who has just recovered from COVID-19 infection visits your OPD with black discoloration material in nose and posterior part of buccal cavity. He also gives history of using high dose steroid therapy during his treatment of COVID-19. Which of the following is most suitable drug for his treatment? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Amphotericin B

 

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of mucormycosis, an opportunistic fungal infection that has become more common following COVID-19, particularly in patients who have received high-dose steroids. Mucormycosis is characterized by black necrotic lesions in the nose and posterior part of the buccal cavity, hence the term "black fungus."

 

Amphotericin B is the drug of choice (DOC) for mucormycosis. It is a potent antifungal agent that binds to ergosterol in the fungal cell membrane, creating pores that lead to cell death. This makes it effective against the Mucorales species responsible for mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fluconazole: Fluconazole is not effective against Mucorales species. It is typically used for treating Candida and Cryptococcus infections but not for mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Itraconazole: Itraconazole has antifungal properties but is not considered the first-line treatment for mucormycosis. It is used for infections caused by Aspergillus and dermatophytes but does not have the efficacy needed for mucormycosis.

 

Option D. Griseofulvin: Griseofulvin is used to treat dermatophyte infections of the skin, hair, and nails. It is ineffective against the fungi causing mucormycosis and is not relevant to this patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The drug of choice for treating mucormycosis, especially in patients who have received high-dose steroid therapy following COVID-19, is Amphotericin B. Mucormycosis presents with black necrotic lesions, hence the name "black fungus." Other effective drugs for mucormycosis include Posaconazole and Isavuconazole.

questions.text: Which inhalational anaesthetic agent uses a special Vaporizer? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Desflurane

 

Explanation:

 

Desflurane is an inhalational anesthetic agent that requires a special vaporizer due to its unique physical properties. Here’s why:

 

  • Boiling Point and Vapor Pressure: Desflurane has a very low boiling point of 22.8°C (73°F), which means it is close to its boiling point at room temperature. This gives it a high vapor pressure, making it highly volatile.
  • Control of Vaporization: Traditional vaporizers, which rely on the flow of carrier gas through a liquid anesthetic, are unsuitable for desflurane because of its high volatility. There is a risk of administering too high a concentration, leading to overdose.
  • Special Vaporizer: The special vaporizer for desflurane, known as the "Tec 6" vaporizer, is electrically heated to maintain a constant temperature. This ensures consistent vaporization of the liquid desflurane into its vapor form, despite fluctuations in room temperature or operating room conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sevoflurane: Sevoflurane can be used with standard vaporizers and does not require a special vaporizer like desflurane.

 

Option C. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is used with conventional vaporizers and does not necessitate a specialized vaporizer.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane is also used with standard vaporizers and does not require a unique vaporizer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desflurane requires a special vaporizer, such as the Tec 6, due to its high volatility and low boiling point. This specialized equipment ensures safe and accurate administration of desflurane in clinical settings.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 588

questions.text: Which one is most common macrocytic anemia in India? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alcohol related

 

Chronic alcoholism is the most common cause of macrocytic anemia in India. The following mechanisms contribute to the development of macrocytic anemia in chronic alcoholics:

 

  1. Vitamin B12 deficiency: Alcohol interferes with the absorption and metabolism of vitamin B12, leading to deficiency.
  2. Folate deficiency: Alcohol consumption leads to poor dietary intake and absorption of folate, resulting in deficiency.
  3. Alcohol toxicity: Alcohol is directly toxic to the bone marrow, leading to abnormal erythropoiesis (the production of red blood cells).
  4. Megaloblastic anemia: Due to deficiencies in vitamin B12 and folate, which are essential for DNA synthesis in red blood cell production, resulting in the characteristic megaloblastic changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sideroblastic anemia: A less common type of anemia caused by defects in heme synthesis, leading to the accumulation of iron in mitochondria.

 

Option B. Thalassemia: A genetic disorder resulting in abnormal hemoglobin production, more commonly associated with microcytic anemia rather than macrocytic anemia.

 

Option D. Chronic infection: Typically associated with anemia of chronic disease, which is usually normocytic or microcytic, not macrocytic.

 

Educational Objective

 

Chronic alcoholism

 

  1.  Vitamin B12 deficiency
  2. Folate deficiency
  3. Alcohol –toxic to marrow, abnormal erythropoiesis
  4. Megaloblastic anemia

questions.text: A young lady presented with abdominal pain. After necessary investigations, she was operated upon, and the material shown in the image was retrieved from her stomach. The patient should be advised to consult which of the following specialists to prevent the recurrence of such a condition?(FMGE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Psychiatrist

 

A trichobezoar is a hairball found in the stomach due to the ingestion of hair, linked with trichophagia. Trichophagia is often associated with the psychiatric disorder trichotillomania.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatologist: A dermatologist would treat skin and hair conditions, but not the underlying behavioral issue.

 

Option B. Cardiologist: A cardiologist  addresses heart conditions, 

 

Option D. Neurologist: Neurologist treats neurological disorders, both unrelated to hair ingestion.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Trichotillomania is a psychiatric disorder which involves recurrent pulling of one’s own hair leading to significant hair loss, accompanied by unsuccessful attempts to decrease or stop the behaviour.It can lead to complications like trichobezoars when associated with trichophagia.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 432.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and jaundice. Upon evaluation, an ultrasound of the abdomen was performed. Based on the image provided, which structure likely represents a choledochal cyst? Identify the choledochal cyst in the image below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III

 

The image depicts a choledochocele, which is a Type III choledochal cyst. Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the biliary ducts and are more common in females. These cysts can lead to recurrent abdominal pain and jaundice due to bile duct obstruction.

 

  • Type I (MC): Dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree.
    • Type Ia: Cystic dilation (most common type).
    • Type Ib: Focal segmental dilation.
    • Type Ic: Fusiform dilation.
  • Type II: Diverticular dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree.
  • Type III: Cystic dilation of the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct, known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: Dilation of both the extrahepatic and intrahepatic biliary tree.
  • Type IVB: Dilation of multiple sections of the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V: Dilation confined to the intrahepatic bile ducts, also known as Caroli’s disease.
  • Type VI: Cystic dilation of the cystic duct (not included in Todani’s modification).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type I: Represents dilation of the extrahepatic biliary tree. It is the most common type but does not correspond to the image provided.

 

Option C. Type IV: Involves dilation of both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts. The image does not show such extensive dilation.

 

Option D. Type V: Known as Caroli's disease, involves dilation confined to the intrahepatic bile ducts, which is not depicted in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Choledochal cysts are classified into several types based on the location and nature of the biliary dilation. Type III choledochal cysts, or choledochocele, involve cystic dilation of the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct.

questions.text: A man is brought to the emergency department after falling from a height with his hand outstretched. X-ray shows a clavicular fracture. Which part of the clavicle is most likely to be fractured? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Middle third of the clavicle

 

Explanation

 

The middle third of the clavicle is most likely to be fractured. The clavicle is often fractured, commonly by indirect forces, as a result of a violent impact to the hand or shoulder. The break is usually at the junction of the lateral and intermediate thirds, where the curvature changes, for this is the weakest part of the bone

 

The most common fracture of the clavicle (collarbone) is known as a midshaft clavicular fracture. It usually occurs at the junction of the lateral 2/5th and medial 3/5th where transition from antecurve to retrocurve occurs and the bone changes in cross-sectional shape from its flatter lateral part to an atubular medial part.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Junction of medial 2/3rd and lateral 1/3rd :  These fractures can result from various causes, including direct trauma to the clavicle, falls onto the shoulder or outstretched hand, and sports-related injuries..

 

Option B. Junction of medial 1/3rd and lateral 2/3rd : due to convexity of the medial 1/3rd it is not very likely to get fractured.

 

Option C. Junction of middle 1/3rd and medial 1/3rd : due to convexity of the medial 1/3rd it is not very likely to get fractured.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Allman classification/ Allman system, is a classification system used to categorize fractures of the clavicle (collarbone) based on their location. It was developed by Dr. Fred Allman in 1967 and is a simple way to describe clavicle fractures anatomically. The classification consists of three types:

 

Type I: Middle Third Fracture

 

This type involves a fracture in the middle portion (shaft) of the clavicle. It is the most common type of clavicle fracture, accounting for the majority of cases. Type I fractures are often caused by direct trauma to the clavicle or a fall on the shoulder.

 

Type II: Lateral Third Fracture

 

Type II fractures occur in the outer third (lateral third) of the clavicle, closer to the shoulder joint. These fractures are less common than Type I fractures and are often the result of direct impact to the shoulder or a fall on an outstretched arm.

 

Type III: Medial Third Fracture

 

Type III fractures are located in the inner third (medial third) of the clavicle, closer to the sternum (breastbone). These fractures are the least common among the three types and can occur due to indirect forces transmitted to the clavicle, such as a blow to the chest or a fall on the back of the shoulder.

questions.text: Identify the type of joint shown in the given image? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Syndesmosis

 

Explanation

 

The type of joint shown in the given image is syndesmosis. These joints have slightly more flexibility and are connected by longer connective tissue fibers.

Example - Radioulnar joint of forearm or Tibiofibular syndesmosis in the lower leg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Symphysis: they are connected by fibrocartilage and allow for limited movement. The pubic symphysis and intervertebral discs in the spine are examples.

 

Option C. Synchondrosis: These joints are connected by hyaline cartilage and are typically immovable. An example is the epiphyseal plate in growing bones, vertebrae.

 

Option D. Synostosis: this term refers to the fusion of bones usually at cartlilaginous or fibro-osseous connections. It can be physiological or pathological.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency
Alcoholic hepatitis
Acute hepatitis

questions.text: An already known case of diabetic patient came to the hospital with pigmentation of skin over the arms. He also found out to be suffering from micro nodular cirrhosis. On biopsy, iron deposits are seen. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hemochromatosis

 

Hemochromatosis is a condition characterized by excessive absorption and accumulation of dietary iron in various organs, leading to tissue damage. The clinical presentation often includes skin pigmentation (bronze diabetes), hepatomegaly, cirrhosis, arthritis, diabetes, and hypogonadism.

 

  • Most common - cirrhosis
  • Most common organ involved - kidney
  • Earliest organ - micronodular cirrhosis leads to HCC.

 

 

  • Prussian blue stain used:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha 1 antitrypsin deficiency: This genetic disorder results in lung and liver disease but does not typically present with iron deposits or skin pigmentation.

 

Option C. Alcoholic hepatitis: This condition is associated with liver inflammation due to excessive alcohol consumption and does not present with iron deposits or skin pigmentation.

 

Option D. Acute hepatitis: This is characterized by liver inflammation, usually due to viral infections, and does not involve iron deposition or skin pigmentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron accumulation leading to skin pigmentation, cirrhosis, and diabetes, and is confirmed by identifying iron deposits using Prussian blue stain.

questions.text: Identify the condition given in the image below: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Placenta previa

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows placenta previa.

 

The grades of placenta previa are:

 

  • ﻿﻿Type I (Low-lying): A major part of the placenta is attached to the upper segment and only the lower margin encroaches onto the lower segment but not up to the internal os.
  • ﻿﻿Type II (Marginal): The placenta reaches the margin of the internal os but does not cover it. This can be anterior or posterior
  • ﻿﻿Type III (Incomplete or partial central: The placenta covers the internal os partially (covers the internal os when closed but does not entirely do so when fully dilated).
  • ﻿﻿Type IV (Central or total): The placenta completely covers the internal os even after it is fully dilated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vasa previa: Blood vessels traversing through membranes overlying the internal os in front of the presenting part may be present in a velamentous placenta. Bleeding occurring due to rupture of membranes in such a case is of fetal origin.

 

Option C. Placenta accreta: It is a form of adherent placenta where placenta is directly adherent to myometrium.

 

Option D. Abruptio placenta: It refers to premature separation of a normally situated placenta.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta previa is a condition where the placenta is implanted in the lower segment of the uterus, partially or completely covering the cervix, which can lead to complications such as bleeding during pregnancy and delivery.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition page 284

questions.text: A chronic smoker starts having pain in the calf on walking a distance of 400 meters. Gradually he starts developing pain on walking a distance of as less as 200 meters only. Currently he even gets pain in his calf while lying down. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rest pain

 

History of a chronic smoker with intermittent claudication followed by continuous calf pain even at rest is indicative of Rest Pain. This is seen in Peripheral Arterial Occlusive Diseases (PAD) like Buerger’s disease or atherosclerosis. Rest pain is typically experienced in the feet or toes and can be so severe that it awakens the patient from sleep. Chronic smoking is a significant risk factor for PAD.

 

The progression of symptoms described – from pain with walking decreasing distances to pain even while at rest – fits the pattern of advancing PAD and critical limb ischemia. This patient's history of chronic smoking further aligns with the likelihood of PAD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Venous claudication:

 

  • Definition: Pain in the limbs due to venous insufficiency, which is caused by problems with the valves in the veins or venous hypertension.
  • Pain Characteristics: In venous claudication, pain typically gets worse on prolonged standing.
  • Suitability: The patient's pain occurs even at rest and while lying down, which is not characteristic of venous claudication.

 

Option B. Neurological claudication:

 

  • Definition: Pain that results from nerve compression, often due to lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • Pain Characteristics: The pain tends to be aggravated by standing or walking and is relieved by sitting or leaning forward.
  • Suitability: The pain from neurological claudication wouldn't typically manifest when the patient is lying down, as described in the scenario. Further, it begins immediately on walking.

 

Option C. Sciatica:

 

  • Definition: Pain radiating down the leg from the lower back, typically due to a herniated disc pressing on a nerve.
  • Pain Characteristics: The pain is often sharp and can be accompanied by numbness or tingling.
  • Suitability: Sciatica doesn't fit the pattern of pain that worsens with specific walking distances and occurs at rest, as described in the scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rest pain in the context of chronic smoking and intermittent claudication progression indicates Peripheral Arterial Occlusive Disease (PAD).

questions.text: What is used to diagnose the condition given in the below image? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Wood’s lamp examination

 

The given image shows sharply demarcated hypopigmented macules coalescing into patches over the trunk, pointing to a likely diagnosis of tinea versicolor or pityriasis versicolor.

  • Chest and trunk having hypopigmented macules with fine scaling around follicles which coalesced to form large sheets.
  • Woods lamp examination →Yellow fluorescence.

 

Etiology:

  • Malassezia globosa > M. furfur, M. sympodialis.
  • Since it’s a lipophilic fungus it colonizes seborrheic and perifollicular areas.

 

Clinical features:

  • Asymptomatic Hypopigmented (due to Azelaic acid), sometimes Hyperpigmented (due to abnormally large melanosomes)

 

 

  • Besnier's sign (coup d'ongle sign or scratch sign or stroke of the nail): When the fine scales are not visible, an important diagnostic clue may be the loosening of barely perceptible scales with a fingernail, which is called the scratch sign. The most commonly affected site is the upper trunk.

 

PITYRIASIS VERSICOLOR IS NOT A DERMATOPHYTIC INFECTION.

 

Basic diagnostic techniques for tinea versicolor

  • KOH
  • Culture
  • Woods light

Investigation: Woods lamp examination →Yellow fluorescence.

The image below shows the pale-yellow fluorescence of Tinea versicolor under Wood's lamp.

 

Wood’s lamp examination – Pityriasis versicolor

  • Done at wavelength of 360-364nm shows yellow florescence (Pteridine & Pityrialactone)

 

 

10% KOH mount in Pityriasis Versicolor: Short hyphae + round spores, giving a Spaghetti & Meatball appearance

 

 

First-line treatment:

  • ﻿﻿Topical azoles twice daily for 2-3 weeks
  • ﻿﻿Terbinafine 1% cream twice daily for 2-3 weeks

 

Second-line treatment: Oral itraconazole, 200 mg daily for 5 days

Pityriasis Versicolor is a disease where recurrence is common even after complete treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Culture:

 

  • Culture can be used to grow and identify microbes from a sample.
  • While culture can technically be used to diagnose fungal infections, it is not the primary method to diagnose pityriasis versicolor since the organism (Malassezia) is lipophilic and does not readily grow in standard fungal media.

 

Option C. Gram staining:

  • Gram staining is a method used to determine bacterial morphology and is useful in diagnosing bacterial infections.
  • Pityriasis versicolor is caused by fungi (Malassezia species), not bacteria.
  • Gram staining is not appropriate for diagnosing fungal skin infections like pityriasis versicolor.

 

Option D. Patch test:

  • A patch test is used to identify substances that might be causing allergic contact dermatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wood's lamp examination is used to diagnose skin conditions with hypopigmented patches and scaling, such as tinea versicolor, which fluoresce under the ultraviolet light with yellow colour.

questions.text: A young man presents with a sudden onset of severe headache, dizziness, breathlessness, and blurring of vision while trekking on a mountain at an altitude of 5000 meters. He is unable to climb any further. Which of the following indicates the development of high-altitude cerebral edema? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Altered mental status

 

High-altitude cerebral edema (HACE) is characterized by symptoms such as altered mental status, ataxia, and possibly coma. These symptoms indicate severe altitude sickness requiring immediate descent and possibly medication like dexamethasone.

 

Detailed protocol for managing severe high altitude-related illnesses, specifically High Altitude Pulmonary Edema (HAPE) and High Altitude Cerebral Edema (HACE):

 

  • Immediate Descent: The primary and most effective treatment for HAPE and HACE is to descend to a lower altitude as soon as possible. This is critical because it directly addresses the cause of the symptoms by reducing altitude exposure.
  • Portable Hyperbaric Bags: If immediate descent is not feasible due to terrain or other factors, portable hyperbaric bags are the next best alternative. These simulate a lower altitude environment and can stabilize the patient while descent is arranged.
  • Medications:
    • Dexamethasone: Effective for both HAPE and HACE, this medication can reduce inflammation and cerebral swelling.
    • Nifedipine: Recommended specifically for HAPE, as it helps reduce pulmonary artery pressure but is not effective for HACE.
    • Oxygen and CPAP (Continuous Positive Airway Pressure): These are additional treatments for HAPE to improve oxygenation, though the discussion of their use is noted as beyond the scope of the current conversation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Desaturation: More indicative of high-altitude pulmonary edema (HAPE).

 

Option C. Increase in blood pressure: Not specific to HACE.

 

Option D. Retinal hemorrhage: Can occur at high altitudes but is not a primary indicator of HACE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Altered mental status is a key indicator of high-altitude cerebral edema.

questions.text: A patient aged 55 years with hyperglycemia and positive ketone bodies in urine comes to you in hospital with altered sensorium. Which of the following drug therapy is most suitable to start? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Insulin and IV fluid

 

The given case is indicative of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a serious complication of diabetes characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis. The management of DKA involves:

 

  • Insulin and IV fluids: The mainstay of therapy in DKA is the correction of dehydration by administering IV fluids and the correction of hyperglycemia and acidosis by giving IV regular insulin. Insulin helps to reduce blood glucose levels and shift potassium back into cells, while IV fluids address dehydration and help to dilute blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metformin: Metformin is an oral antihyperglycemic agent used primarily in the management of type 2 diabetes. It is not appropriate for the acute management of DKA, which requires immediate correction of severe hyperglycemia and acidosis.

 

Option B. Potassium chloride: Potassium chloride may be necessary during the treatment of DKA if hypokalemia develops, as insulin therapy can cause a shift of potassium into cells, leading to low blood potassium levels. However, it is not the primary treatment; insulin and IV fluids are the initial and most critical interventions.

 

Option D. Ringer lactate: Ringer lactate is a type of IV fluid that can be used to treat dehydration, but it is not the fluid of choice in DKA due to its lactate content, which can potentially worsen acidosis. Normal saline is typically preferred initially to correct dehydration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Management of DKA

 

  • The mainstay of therapy in DKA is correction of dehydration by giving IV fluids and correction of hyperglycemia and acidosis by giving IV Regular Insulin.

  • If there is development of hypokalemia during infusion of insulin , then Inj. Potassium Chloride can be given.

  • Sometimes, Sodium Bicarbonate can be used to correct the acidosis (if pH <7.1).

  • It is also important to look for the underlying precipitating factor like infections, myocardial infarction etc.

questions.text: A health economist aims to compare the overall well-being and life expectancy between two countries. He uses a specific index which considers life expectancy, education, and per capita income. Which of the following measures has he most likely utilized for his comparison? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. HDI

 

HDI (Human Development Index) is used to compare life expectancy between two countries because HDI has life expectancy as one of its components.

 

HDI is a composite index comprising of 3 dimensions: 

 

  • Knowledge

 

 

  • Income
  • Longevity

 

HDI is Geometric mean of 3 dimension indices

 

HDI values range: 0 to + 1

 

HDI India is 0.644 (Rank 134 out of 189 countries)

 

Human poverty index [HPI] is complementary to HDI

 

Other Options:

 

HPI (Human Poverty Index), QALY (Quality adjusted life years), DALY (Disability Adjusted Life Years) does not have life expectancy in its components.

 

Option B. HPI (Human Poverty Index): HPI is a measure that was introduced by the United Nations to assess the standard of living in a country. It considers variables such as the probability of not surviving past age 40, adult illiteracy rate, and lack of access to clean water and health services. While it does give information about well-being, it does not directly compare life expectancies. HDI is a measure of development, whereas HPI is a measure of its deprivation

 

Option C. DALY (Disability-Adjusted Life Year): DALY is a measure used to assess the overall disease burden in a specific population. It considers both years of life lost due to premature death and years lived with disability. It doesn't compare life expectancies between countries but rather assesses the impact of specific diseases.

 

Option D. QALY (Quality-Adjusted Life Year): QALY is a measure used in health economics to assess the value of medical interventions. It combines both the quality and the quantity of life lived. It's used to assess the cost-effectiveness of a specific medical treatment but not to compare life expectancies between countries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The HDI is a vital tool for comparing holistic human development levels across countries, incorporating health, education, and income, thus providing a multidimensional view of societal progress.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamins is breast milk deficient in? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vitamin K

 

Vitamin K is deficient in breast milk. So, the newborn will receive a shot of Vit K to prevent the Hemorrhagic disease of new born.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Breast milk contains adequate amounts of Vitamin A, which is important for vision, immune function, and cell growth.

 

Option B. Vitamin C: Human milk is rich in Vitamin C, with levels ranging from 5 to 15 mg per 100 calories. It provides sufficient Vitamin C to meet the nutritional needs of the infant.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: Breast milk also contains sufficient Vitamin E, an important antioxidant that helps protect cells from damage.

 

Educational Objective:


Breast milk is deficient in Vitamin K, which is why newborns receive a Vitamin K injection at birth to prevent Hemorrhagic Disease of the Newborn.

questions.text: In analyzing the demographic data of a nation as depicted in a population pyramid, which statement incorrectly reflects the implications of birth rates and life expectancy shown in the pyramid? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Developed countries

 

The pyramid shows a broader base indicating a higher proportion of young people, which is characteristic of developing countries with higher birth rates and typically shorter life expectancies. This contradicts the assumption that it represents a developed country.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased Population: This could potentially be true for a developing country with high birth rates, but the statement itself does not align directly with the pyramid's implications without additional demographic growth rate data.

 

Option B. More young Population:  This is true as the broader base indicates a larger proportion of young individuals.

 

Option C. Developing Countries: This is a correct identification, aligning with the pyramid's shape, which reflects typical characteristics of developing countries (broader base, younger population).

 

Additional Information

 

Utility of Population pyramid:

 

  • Shape of population pyramid indicates fertility pattern
    • Broad base, Narrow top (upright triangle): High proportion of younger population (developing countries)
    • Bulge in Middle, Spindle shape: High proportion of adults (developed countries)
  • Span (height) of population pyramid indicates life expectancy
    • Taller pyramid: Higher life expectancy (developed countries)
    • Shorter pyramid: Lower life expectancy (developing countries)
  • Symmetry of population pyramid indicates sex ratio
    • Symmetric pyramid: ideal sex ratio (developed countries)
    • Asymmetric pyramid: unfavourable sex ratio <1000 (developing countries)

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed fungal infection in the maxillary sinus among the options listed below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aspergillosis

 

Aspergillosis and Mucormycosis are the most common fungal infections that involve the maxillary sinuses.

 

Aspergillosis in the sinus typically manifests as either a non-invasive form (sinus aspergilloma or fungal ball) or an invasive form, which is more severe and occurs primarily in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Treatment - Surgical debridement of the involved tissues and antifungal drugs like Amphotericin-B. Repeated irrigation of the involved area with application of 1% solution of gentian violet is also useful.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blastomycosis: Typically affects the lungs and skin more frequently than the sinuses. It is more common in regions around the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys.

 

Option C. Candidiasis: While Candida species can infect mucosal surfaces, they rarely cause sinus infections compared to Aspergillus.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: Like blastomycosis, histoplasmosis primarily affects the lungs and is endemic to certain areas in the United States. It is not commonly seen in the sinuses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspergillosis is the most prevalent fungal infection of the maxillary sinus among the choices provided. Recognizing the form of aspergillosis (non-invasive vs. invasive) is crucial for effective management, which can range from local care and antifungals to more aggressive surgical interventions depending on the case severity and patient's immune status.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man is presenting with the following clinical features: Hypercalcemia, features consistent with renal insufficiency, markedly decreased red blood cell (RBC) count on complete blood count (CBC), Multiple lytic lesions observed on x-ray. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple Myeloma

 

Multiple myeloma is a hematologic malignancy characterized by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells, which produce monoclonal immunoglobulins and can lead to bone destruction, hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, and anemia.

 

Multiple myeloma – CRAB criteria

 

  • HyperCalcemia
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Anemias
  • Multiple Bony lytic lesions

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperthyroidism: Typically presents with symptoms such as weight loss, heat intolerance, palpitations, and does not typically cause lytic bone lesions or hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Grave’s disease: An autoimmune disorder leading to hyperthyroidism, not associated with lytic bone lesions or hypercalcemia.

 

Option D. Renal tubular acidosis: A disorder affecting acid-base balance in the kidneys, not associated with lytic bone lesions or hypercalcemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by hypercalcemia, renal insufficiency, anemia, and multiple lytic bone lesions, fulfilling the CRAB criteria.

questions.text: A patient has swelling in metacarpophalangeal joints. Serum uric acid levels were raised. Doctor prescribed medicine for same. The medicine act by inhibiting which enzyme:(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xanthine oxidase

 

Xanthine oxidase is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid, the final step in purine catabolism. Inhibitors of xanthine oxidase, such as allopurinol or febuxostat, are commonly prescribed to lower serum uric acid levels in conditions like gout, which is likely the diagnosis in this patient scenario.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thymidylate Synthase: Thymidylate synthase is an enzyme involved in the synthesis of thymidine monophosphate, a nucleotide necessary for DNA synthesis. Inhibitors of this enzyme, such as 5-fluorouracil, are used in chemotherapy treatments and are not indicated for conditions involving elevated uric acid levels or joint inflammation.

 

Option C. ADA (Adenosine Deaminase): ADA is involved in the purine salvage pathway and its deficiency is associated with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). ADA inhibitors have therapeutic use in specific cases like certain leukemias but are not used for the treatment of conditions related to elevated uric acid.

 

Option D. HGPRT (Hypoxanthine-Guanine Phosphoribosyltransferase): HGPRT is also part of the purine salvage pathway. A deficiency in this enzyme leads to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, characterized by hyperuricemia, but HGPRT is not a target for gout treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased uric acid occur due to deficiency of xanthine oxidase which converts xanthine to uric acid during the catabolism of purine in our body. In a patient presenting with joint swelling and hyperuricemia, a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, such as allopurinol, is prescribed to reduce uric acid levels. This treatment approach is aimed at managing conditions like gout, where excess uric acid leads to crystal deposition in joints and tissues. Thymidylate synthase, ADA, and HGPRT are not related to the treatment of hyperuricemia or gout.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 334-335

questions.text: What is the most common cause of seizures in a 2-year-old child? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Febrile seizures


Febrile seizures are the most common cause of seizures in children aged 6 months to 5 years, particularly in those around 2 years old. They are defined by the following criteria:

 

  • They occur in association with a fever, specifically at a body temperature of 38°C (100.4°F) or higher.
  • They are not caused by central nervous system infections, such as meningitis, or by metabolic imbalances.
  • They occur in the absence of a prior history of afebrile seizures (seizures without fever).

 

The initial management of febrile seizures includes the administration of benzodiazepines such as lorazepam, midazolam, or diazepam to stop the seizure. Hydration and the use of antipyretics to control fever are also essential components of treatment. In cases where febrile seizures last longer than five minutes, rectal diazepam is recommended as a rescue medication that can be administered at home.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Trauma to the head: While head trauma can cause seizures, it is not the most common cause in a 2-year-old child. Trauma-related seizures would typically be associated with a recent injury or noticeable neurological symptoms, which are not indicated in this scenario.

 

Option B. Malnutrition: Malnutrition can lead to seizures due to electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypoglycemia or hypocalcemia, but it is not the most common cause in a child of this age. Febrile seizures are more prevalent.

 

Option D. Neurological deficit: Seizures can result from underlying neurological conditions, but these are less common compared to febrile seizures in a healthy child of this age group.

 

Educational Objective:


Febrile seizures are the most common cause of seizures in children between 6 months and 5 years of age, particularly around the age of 2 years.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked below:(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pons

 

Explanation

 

The structure marked in the MRI scan is the Pons.

 

Located in the anterior portion of the brainstem, between the midbrain superiorly and the medulla oblongata inferiorly. The pons has a ventral surface that faces anteriorly and a dorsal surface that faces posteriorly.

 

It participates in several vital functions including the regulation of breathing, communication between different parts of the brain, and sensations such as hearing, taste, and balance.

 

 It is divided into two main parts by the transverse fibers of the pontine nuclei:

 

  1. Basilar Part: The basilar part of the pons forms the ventral aspect of the structure and is slightly convex. It contains various important structures, including the basilar artery (a major blood vessel), the corticospinal tracts
  2. Tegmentum: The tegmentum is the dorsal part of the pons and is more rounded and swollen compared to the basilar part. It consists of various nuclei and structures involved in sensory processing, sleep regulation, and motor coordination.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain:  It traverses the hiatus in the tentorium cerebelli, and connects the pons and cerebellum with the forebrain. It is the shortest brain stem segment, not more than 2 cm in length, and most of it lies in the posterior cranial fossa.

 

Option C. Medulla oblongata:  It extends from just above the first pair of cervical spinal nerves to the lower border of the pons. The ventral surface of the medulla is separated from the basilar part of the occipital bone and apex of the dens by the meninges and occipito-axial ligaments. The ventral and dorsal surfaces of the medulla  possess a longitudinal median fissure and sulcus, respectively, which are continuous with their spinal counterparts.

 

Option D. Spinal cord: It lies within the vertebral canal. It is continuous rostrally with the medulla oblongata, just below the level of the foramen magnum and it terminates caudally as the conus medullaris, which is continuous with the filum terminale and is anchored to the dorsum of the coccyx.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Pons is a key structure in the brainstem that connects the midbrain to the medulla and plays critical roles in autonomic function and coordination of movements. It is also a pivotal area for cranial nerve nuclei and pathways related to facial and auditory sensations.

choices.text: Lupiprostone + Mifepristone
Mifepristone + Misoprostol
Lubiprostone + Misoprostol
Alprostadil + Misoprostol

questions.text: Which of the following drug combination is preferred for medical termination of pregnancy? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Mifepristone + Misoprostol

 

For medical termination of pregnancy, the preferred drug combination involves the use of medications that induce uterine contractions and facilitate the expulsion of the uterine contents.

 

Mifepristone + Misoprostol: This combination is the standard and most commonly used regimen for medical abortion. Mifepristone is an antiprogestogen that works by blocking the action of progesterone, a hormone crucial for the continuation of pregnancy. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin analogue, is used to induce contractions of the uterus to expel its contents. This combination is known for its high efficacy and safety profile in terminating early pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lupiprostone + Mifepristone: Lupiprostone is not used in the medical termination of pregnancy. It is actually used in the treatment of chronic constipation and is unrelated to pregnancy termination.

 

Option C. Lubiprostone + Misoprostol: Lubiprostone, like lupiprostone, is used for the treatment of chronic constipation and is not used in the termination of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Alprostadil + Misoprostol: Alprostadil is a drug used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction and certain cardiovascular disorders, not in pregnancy termination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of Mifepristone and Misoprostol is the preferred regimen for medical termination of pregnancy due to its high efficacy and safety in inducing uterine contractions and expelling the contents of the uterus.

questions.text: During a trial of a case in high court examination of a witness is being carried out by the opposing party lawyer. The lawyer is questioning the accused and is trying to prove that the evidence was biased, inaccurate, inconsistent. This procedure can be done by the lawyer during? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross examination

 

Cross examination is a critical stage in the trial process where the lawyer of the opposing party (usually the defense lawyer) questions the witness brought by the other party. The main objectives of cross examination are to challenge the credibility of the witness, expose any inconsistencies or inaccuracies in their testimony, and weaken the evidence presented.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Examination: This is the initial questioning of the witness by the lawyer who called them. It focuses on eliciting facts without leading questions.

 

Option C. Physical Examination: This refers to the medical or physical examination of a person, not applicable in this context.

 

Option D. Court Room Examination: This is a general term and not specific to any particular stage of questioning in a trial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

RECORDING EVIDENCE IN COURT

 

  1. Oath (except Person <12yrs, oath not required)

 

Religious- Religious book (Bhagavat Gita , Quran)

 

Atheist – “I solemnly affirm whatever I say will be the truth”

 

  1. Examination in chief (Direct Examination)- By lawyer who summoned the witness (Mostly public prosecutor). Only facts stated, leading questions not allowed.
  2.  Cross examination – By layer of opposite party (mostly the defence lawyer). Leading questions allowed. There is no time limit for cross examination. The lawyer tries to weaken the evidence of the witness by showing that his details are inaccurate, conflicting, contradictory and untrustworthy.
  3. Re-examination (Re-Direct Examination)– By lawyer who summoned witness. If something was missed in examination in chief, that is asked in re-examination. Leading questions not allowed. It helps to clear any doubts that may have arisen during
  4. Questions by judge / court questions – can be done any time

questions.text: Which of the following is the most significant side-effect of tamoxifen? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Endometrial hyperplasia

 

Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM). It is used in the treatment of ER +ve Breast cancers in pre-menopausal women. It has an estrogen antagonistic action in the breast but an agonistic action on the endometrium. Therefore, the most significant side effect of tamoxifen is endometrial hyperplasia, which is in turn a risk factor for the development of endometrial cancer. Hence, it is not used in post-menopausal women.

 

The other side effects of Tamoxifen include: -

 

  • Hot flushes

  • Thrombosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cancer in the opposite breast: Tamoxifen is actually beneficial in reducing the incidence of cancer in the opposite breast due to its estrogen antagonistic action in breast tissue, which inhibits the proliferation of breast cancer cells.

 

Option B. Osteoporosis: Tamoxifen has a protective effect against osteoporosis because of its estrogen agonistic action on bone. It helps maintain bone density and reduce the risk of fractures in post-menopausal women.

 

Option D. Infertility: Tamoxifen does not cause infertility. On the contrary, it can sometimes be used in fertility treatments to stimulate ovulation due to its partial estrogen agonist effects on the hypothalamus, which increases gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) secretion and subsequently stimulates ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most significant side effect of tamoxifen is endometrial hyperplasia, which is a risk factor for the development of endometrial cancer due to its estrogen agonistic action on the endometrium.

questions.text: Under which legal doctrine does a situation where a patient dies solely due to a doctor's negligence, with no contributory factors from the patient's end, fall under? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Res ipsa loquitor

 

Res ipsa loquitor - Res Ipsa Loquitur is a Latin phrase that means ‘the thing speaks for itself’. Res ipsa loquitor means facts are sufficient to prove negligence of doctor with no contributory negligence from patients.

 

Example: A case where a surgical swab had been left inside a patient's body.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Patient negligence: This is when a patient's actions lead to their own harm. For instance, if a patient doesn't follow the doctor's instructions for taking medication and their condition worsens, their negligence might affect the doctor's liability.

 

Option C. Volenti non-fit injuria: If a person willingly participates in a risky activity and gets hurt, they might not be able to blame someone else. For instance, if someone joins a dangerous sports event and gets injured, they might not have a case against the event organizers.

 

Option D. Respondeat superior/Novus actus interveniens:

 

  • Respondeat superior: Employers can be responsible for their employees' actions at work. If a nurse makes a mistake while giving medication, the hospital could be held liable.
  • Novus actus interveniens: If a new, unforeseeable event breaks the chain of events, the original wrongdoer might not be fully responsible. For instance, if a person injures someone in a car accident and then a lightning strike causes more harm, the lightning might be considered a new intervening event.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The doctrine of res ipsa loquitur is applied when a patient's injury or death is clearly due to the negligence of a healthcare provider, with no contributory negligence from the patient.

questions.text: A 25-year-old P1L1 woman is planning for her second child. She has been recently diagnosed with Grave's disease. Which of the following is the antithyroid drug to be used in early gestation? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Propylthiouracil

 

Propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred during the first trimester of pregnancy due to the risk of teratogenic effects from methimazole and carbimazole, such as aplasia cutis.

 

Methimazole or carbimazole can be used in the second and third trimesters.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Methimazole and C. Carbimazole: Not preferred in the first trimester due to teratogenic risks.

 

Option D. Radioactive Iodine: Absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy & lactation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Propylthiouracil is the preferred antithyroid drug during early gestation (first trimester).

questions.text: Upon examining the CT image provided, a patient with a prior history of trauma is exhibiting symptoms such as diplopia, epistaxis, and limited eye movements. Given this clinical presentation, what would be your diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blow out fracture

 

The image displayed above depicts a fractured floor of the left orbit.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Le-Fort Fracture: Involves complex fractures of the midface but usually presents with more extensive facial deformity and mobility.

 

Option B. Fracture Maxilla: This would involve more of the upper jaw and would likely present with significant swelling, malocclusion, and possibly involvement of the nasal septum and upper teeth.

 

Option C. Fracture Zygomatic: Involves the cheekbone; while it can cause eye symptoms due to proximity, it would typically also present with cheek deformity and pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with diplopia, limited eye movements, and epistaxis following facial trauma, a blow out fracture should be strongly considered. Early diagnosis using CT imaging and appropriate surgical consultation are critical to manage the condition effectively to prevent long-term visual and sensory complications.

questions.text: A mother complains that her child is reluctant when it comes to taking feeds appropriately. Her child, a 15-month-old boy has a length-for-age s-2 SD below the median. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Moderate stunting


Stunting is defined as a low height or length for age and is a sign of chronic malnutrition. In this case, the child's length-for-age is 2 SD below the median, which indicates moderate stunting. Stunting occurs due to long-term insufficient nutrient intake and/or frequent infections, and it typically reflects persistent malnutrition. It is an important marker for chronic malnutrition and is commonly used to assess the nutritional status of children in relation to their age.

 

The fact that the child is reluctant to take feeds appropriately further suggests that he may not be receiving adequate nutrition, leading to stunted growth over time. Stunting is associated with various adverse outcomes, including delayed cognitive development and reduced physical capacity.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Acute malnutrition: Acute malnutrition, also known as wasting, is characterized by a low weight-for-height/length, which was not indicated in this case. The key indicator provided is the length-for-age, which points toward stunting rather than wasting.

 

Option B. Severely wasting: Severe wasting is identified by a weight-for-height/length that is more than 3 SD below the median, indicating severe undernourishment. However, the child’s length-for-age is the concern here, not the weight-for-height/length.

 

Option C. Moderately underweight: Being underweight is indicated by low weight-for-age, which could be a sign of both acute and chronic malnutrition. The case provided does not mention weight-for-age, so this option does not apply to the described scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


A length-for-age that is 2 SD below the median in a child indicates moderate stunting, which is a sign of chronic malnutrition.

questions.text: What does the following X-ray depict? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pleural effusion

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given X-ray depicts left-sided pleural effusion.
  • There is opacity of the left hemithorax with a meniscus sign/ Ellis S curve.
  • Earliest sign on CXR: Blunting of CP angle
  • Most sensitive Xray: I/L lateral decubitus
  • Most sensitive Investigation: USG

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Emphysema: Typically presents with hyperinflated lungs, flattened diaphragms, and decreased vascular markings on X-ray, not with opacity or a meniscus sign.

 

Option. B. Tension pneumothorax: Characterized by a collapsed lung with mediastinal shift to the opposite side and absence of lung markings, which is not seen in the provided X-ray.

 

Option. D. Bronchiectasis: Shows bronchial wall thickening and dilation, often with a "tram-track" appearance, which is not consistent with the X-ray findings of pleural effusion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pleural effusion is identified on an X-ray by the opacity of the hemithorax and the presence of a meniscus sign, with the most sensitive investigation being ultrasound (USG).

questions.text: Which of the following second messenger is mainly involved in the mechanism of gastric acid secretion? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. cAMP

 

cAMP serves as the primary second messenger in the mechanism of gastric acid secretion, particularly through its interaction with gastrin. Gastrin significantly enhances the secretion of gastric acid by increasing cAMP levels within the gastric parietal cells, thus promoting the release of hydrogen ions into the stomach.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cGMP: This second messenger is primarily involved in processes associated with dilation and relaxation, such as the actions of nitric oxide and natriuretic peptides, rather than gastric acid secretion.
