Option C. CCK-B receptor: While CCK-B receptors do interact with gastrin to contribute to gastric acid secretion, they function through secondary messengers like IP3 and increased intracellular calcium, which play a relatively minor role compared to cAMP.

 

Option D. IP3-DAG: The IP3-DAG pathway, though significant in various cellular functions, is not the main mediator of gastric acid secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

cAMP is the crucial second messenger in the mechanism of gastric acid secretion, primarily mediated through its enhancement by gastrin, which leads to increased acid production in the stomach.

questions.text: Interpret the finding of the ECG given below. (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Supraventricular tachycardia

 

The ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with regular rhythm and no visible P waves before the QRS complexes, which is characteristic of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT). SVT includes conditions like AVNRT (atrioventricular node reentry tachycardia) and AVRT (atrioventricular reentry tachycardia).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ventricular fibrillation: Shows a chaotic, irregular waveform without recognizable QRS complexes.

 

Option B. Atrial fibrillation: Shows an irregularly irregular rhythm without distinct P waves.

 

Option D. Ventricular tachycardia: Presents as a wide complex tachycardia, not narrow complex.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Supraventricular tachycardia presents as a narrow complex tachycardia with regular rhythm and absence of visible P waves.

choices.text: Deviated tongue to the contralateral side
Deviated tongue to the same side
Loss of taste in posterior 1/3rd of the tongue

questions.text: A patient underwent a left submandibular gland excision during which the hypoglossal nerve was injured. Which of the following deficits would be seen in this case? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Deviated tongue to the same side

 

Explanation

 

A hypoglossal nerve injury would damage all muscles of the tongue except the palatoglossus resulting in deviation of the tongue to the same side. Since, the left hypoglossal nerve is injured in the above scenario, the tongue will deviate to the left side.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deviated tongue to the contralateral side: This is not a typical presentation of hypoglossal nerve injury. The hypoglossal nerve innervates the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue on the same side of the injury. Therefore, if the hypoglossal nerve were injured on the left side, the tongue would typically deviate to the left side, not the contralateral side.

 

Option C. Inability to protrude tongue: While hypoglossal nerve injury can affect tongue protrusion, it typically doesn't lead to a complete inability to protrude the tongue. Instead, it results in weakness or difficulty in protruding the tongue, especially on the side of the injury.

 

Option D. Loss of taste in posterior 1/3rd of the tongue: Taste sensation in the posterior one-third (posterior portion) of the tongue is primarily mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), not the hypoglossal nerve. Therefore, hypoglossal nerve injury is not associated with taste deficits in this region.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Damage to the hypoglossal nerve will result in the tongue deviating towards the side of the damage due to paralysis or weakening of the tongue muscles on that side. Recognizing this clinical sign is crucial for diagnosing and assessing the extent of nerve damage in related facial surgeries or injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following change is not mediated by Estrogen? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hair growth

 

Hair growth is not mediated by Estrogen.

 

Androgen like Testosterone is responsible for hair growth

 

Estrogen is produced primarily by the ovaries, but also by the adrenal glands and fat cells.

 

Function of Estrogen –

 

  • Secondary sexual characteristics
  • Development and regulation of the female reproductive system
  • Breast development (ductal growth)
  • Regulate menstrual cycle (follicular phase)
  • Antagonize the degrading actions of parathyroid hormone (bone friendly hormone)

 

Estrogen also helps in regulating cholesterol levels, supporting cardiovascular health, and affecting mood and cognition.

 

There are three main types of Estrogen: estradiol, estriol, and estrone. Estradiol is the most potent and predominant form of estrogen in premenopausal women, while estriol is most abundant during pregnancy, and estrone is the primary form of estrogen in postmenopausal women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cervical mucus secretion: Estrogen influences the secretion of cervical mucus, making it more conducive to sperm transport during the fertile phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Option B. Menstruation: Estrogen plays a significant role in regulating the menstrual cycle, particularly during the follicular phase where it stimulates the growth of the uterine lining.

 

Option D. Secondary sexual characteristics: Estrogen is crucial for the development of female secondary sexual characteristics, including breast development and the distribution of body fat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Estrogen does not mediate hair growth; this is primarily influenced by androgenic hormones like testosterone. Estrogen's roles include regulating the menstrual cycle, supporting the development of female reproductive tissues, and maintaining secondary sexual characteristics.

questions.text: Which type of hypersensitivity reaction in myasthenia gravis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type 2

 

Myasthenia gravis is an example of a type 2 hypersensitivity reaction. In type 2 hypersensitivity reactions, IgG or IgM antibodies target cell surface antigens or extracellular matrix proteins, leading to cellular destruction, functional loss, or damage to tissues. In myasthenia gravis, autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction impair neuromuscular transmission, leading to muscle weakness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type 1: IgE-mediated reactions, such as allergies and anaphylaxis.

 

Option C. Type 3: Immune complex-mediated reactions, such as post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis and systemic lupus erythematosus.

 

Option D. Type 4: T-cell-mediated delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions, such as contact dermatitis and type I diabetes mellitus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Type 2 HSR examples

 

  • Myasthenia gravis
  • Blood transfusion reaction
  • Good Pasteur syndrome
  • Graves’ disease
  • Insulin dependent DM, immune hemolytic anemia
  • Rh disease of newborn
  • Pemphigus vulgaris

questions.text: A 26-year-old male patient, an accident victim started developing difficulty in breathing. On examination, his BP was 80/40 mmHg and pulses were feeble. JVP was found to be elevated with an absent y descent, and heart sounds were muffled. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cardiac tamponade

 

Cardiac tamponade presents with Beck's triad: hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated JVP. The absence of y descent in JVP and the history of trauma further support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Constrictive pericarditis: Presents with Kussmaul's sign and pericardial knock.

 

Option C. Acute pericarditis: Presents with chest pain and a pericardial friction rub.

 

Option D. Cardiac failure: Presents with dyspnea, orthopnea, and peripheral edema but does not typically show absent y descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cardiac tamponade is diagnosed with Beck's triad and an absence of y descent in JVP, especially in trauma settings.

questions.text: Granuloma inguinale is caused by? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Klebsiella granulomatis

 

  • ﻿﻿Granuloma inguinale(donovanosis) is caused by: Calymmatobacterium granulomatis (gram-negative bacillus)
  • Clinically - well-defined, single or multiple, painless ulcers with beefy and red granulation tissue at the base and elevated, rolled, serpiginous, or hyperplastic borders form the primary lesion. The ulcer may heal with prominent fibrosis. Lymphedema with eventual elephantiasis of the penis and scrotum can result in chronic disease. Subcutaneous nodules (pseudobuboes) can simulate lymph node involvement. Lesions may be nodular, hypertrophic, cicatricial, and ulcerovegetative.

 

 

  • Microscopically - there is prominent granulation-type tissue with an inflammatory infiltrate including plasma cells, neutrophils, and histiocytes that contain 0.6- to 2-µm Donovan bodies, which are encapsulated rods with bipolar granules. Pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia may be prominent. The gram-negative coccoid to bacillary bacteria may be difficult to identify, requiring Wright/Giemsa, toluidine blue, or Warthin-Starry stains.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T. pallidum: Treponema pallidum is the causative agent of syphilis, which presents with primary, secondary, and tertiary stages, including painless chancre and systemic manifestations.

 

Option B. Chlamydia: Chlamydia trachomatis is responsible for various conditions, including trachoma, lymphogranuloma venereum, and nongonococcal urethritis, but not granuloma inguinale.

 

Option C. Herpes simplex: Herpes simplex virus causes genital herpes, characterized by painful vesicular and ulcerative lesions on the genitalia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Granuloma inguinale (donovanosis) is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless ulcers and characteristic beefy red granulation tissue. Diagnosis may require special staining techniques to identify Donovan bodies.

questions.text: What is the use of the instrument given below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hysterosalpingography

 

  • The above image shows Leech-Wilkinson cannula which is used for injecting dye in hysterosalpingography.
  • It is inserted into the cervix. The grooved edges fit into the cervix and allow for easy installation of the dye without extravasation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Myomectomy: It is removal of fibroids. May be performed laparoscopically Or by laparotomy based on size, number, location of fibroids

 

Option C. Endometrial biopsy: It is useful for patients with AUB. It can be performed by EB curette or endometrial sampling using pipelle may be used.

 

Option D. Conization of cervix: It can be performed using cold knife or laser. It refers to excision of the ectocervix and a small portion of the endocervical canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Leech-Wilkinson cannula is used for injecting dye during hysterosalpingography to investigate the shape and patency of the uterine cavity and fallopian tubes.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg 38

questions.text: A woman presented with sudden onset of dysphagia, dysarthria and gait ataxia. MRI revealed an acute infarct in the right dorsolateral medulla. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Wallenberg syndrome

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Wallenberg syndrome. The symptoms of dysphagia and dysarthria are due to the involvement of nucleus ambigus.

 

Ataxia is a feature of inferior cerebellar peduncle involvement.

 

Wallenberg syndrome, also known as lateral medullary syndrome, is a neurological condition that results from damage to the lateral medulla oblongata in the brainstem. This area of the brain is responsible for controlling many vital functions such as breathing, heart rate, swallowing, and coordination of movements.

 

 

The symptoms of Wallenberg syndrome can vary depending on the extent and location of the brain damage, but can include:

 

  1. Difficulty swallowing
  2. Hoarseness or loss of voice
  3. Dizziness or vertigo
  4. Nausea and vomiting
  5. Numbness or weakness on one side of the face or body
  6. Loss of pain and temperature sensation on one side of the face or body
  7. Horner's syndrome (a group of symptoms that includes drooping eyelids, small pupils, and decreased sweating on one side of the face)

 

The most common cause of Wallenberg syndrome is a blockage or clot in the vertebral or posterior inferior cerebellar artery, which reduces blood flow to the lateral medulla.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dejerine's Anterior Bulbar Syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by bilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) facial nerve palsies (bilateral facial weakness) due to bilateral lesions of the cranial nerve VII (facial nerve) nuclei in the lower medulla. It typically presents with bilateral facial weakness and sparing of other brainstem functions. The symptoms mentioned in the case (dysphagia, dysarthria, and gait ataxia) are not consistent with Dejerine's Anterior Bulbar Syndrome.

 

Option C. Babinski-Nageotte Syndrome: Babinski-Nageotte syndrome is not a well-recognized medical syndrome. It is not commonly referred to in medical literature or clinical practice, and there is no specific set of symptoms or findings associated with it.

 

Option D. Weber Syndrome: Weber syndrome typically involves damage to the cerebral peduncles in the midbrain due to a lesion in the area of the oculomotor nerve. This condition results in symptoms like ipsilateral third nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy) and contralateral hemiparesis (weakness of one side of the body). It does not typically cause the combination of symptoms described in the case

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wallenberg syndrome is caused by an infarct or lesion in the lateral part of the medulla, often due to occlusion or ischemia in the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA).

 

Common symptoms include dysphagia, dysarthria, hoarseness, facial pain and temperature sensory loss on the ipsilateral (same) side of the face, and contralateral (opposite) body pain and temperature sensory loss, along with gait ataxia.

 

Additional Information

Stroke Symptoms

Rule of 4’s

 

  1. 4 Cranial nerves originated above pons (2 in midbrain), 4 in pons, 4 in medulla
  2. 4 Midline cranial nerves (CN 3,4 6, 12) (divide equally into 12 except 1 and 2)
  3. 4 Midline structures that begin with M:
  • 4 medial structures
    1. Motor pathway (aka corticospinal tract)
    2. Medial lemniscus
    3. Medial longitudinal fasciculus
    4. Medial cranial nerves (CN 3,4,6,12)

4. 4 structures to the side that begin with S:

  • 4 side (lateral) structures
  1. Spinocerebellar pathway (ipsilateral ataxia of arm and leg)
  2. Spinothalamic pathway
  3. Sensory portion of CN V
  4. Sympathetic pathway

questions.text: A patient underwent surgical resection for a pathology in the left lung. Pre-operatively the left lung collapsed. After the surgery the lung has expanded. What can be the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left pneumothorax

 

The given radiograph shows a distinct left pleural line with absent bronchovascular markings, indicative of a collapsed lung on the left side. These features are characteristic of a pneumothorax. A pneumothorax occurs when air enters the pleural space, causing the lung to collapse. The surgical intervention likely addressed the underlying cause of the pneumothorax, leading to the re-expansion of the lung post-operatively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right pneumothorax: A right pneumothorax involves air accumulating in the pleural space of the right lung, causing it to collapse. In this case, the pathology and the collapse were observed in the left lung, making a right pneumothorax an unlikely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Cardiac tamponade: Cardiac tamponade is a condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardial space, compressing the heart and impairing its function. While it can affect lung function due to decreased cardiac output, it does not directly cause a lung to collapse. Thus, it is not a likely diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Option D. Pneumonia: Pneumonia is an infection that inflames the air sacs in the lungs, which can fill with fluid or pus. Although pneumonia can lead to respiratory symptoms and affect lung expansion, it does not directly cause a lung to collapse like a pneumothorax. Pneumonia typically presents with signs such as consolidations or ground-glass opacities on a radiograph.

 

Educational Objective:


A pneumothorax is characterized by the presence of a distinct pleural line and absence of bronchovascular markings, indicating a collapsed lung.

choices.text: C. diphtheria

questions.text: A child presented with complaint of dysphagia cough, and greyish white membrane over the tonsils. Which of the following is causative organism? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) C. diphtheria

 

The presentation of dysphagia, cough, and a greyish white membrane over the tonsils is characteristic of diphtheria, which is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.

 

﻿﻿Faucial diphtheria: Toxin elicits and inflammatory response that leads to necrosis of the epithelium and exudate formation leading to formation of pseudomembrane (tough leathery greyish white coat composed of an inner band of fibrin surrounded by neutrophiles, RBCs and bacteria) Bleeds on removal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clostridium: Incorrect. Clostridium species are associated with other conditions, such as tetanus and botulism, but not with the formation of a greyish white membrane over the tonsils.

 

Option C. Candida: Incorrect. Candida species can cause oral thrush, which appears as white patches in the mouth and throat, but these do not form a tough pseudomembrane that bleeds upon removal.

 

Option D. Pneumococcus: Incorrect. Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) is primarily associated with pneumonia, meningitis, and otitis media, and does not cause a pseudomembrane on the tonsils.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae causes diphtheria, characterized by the formation of a greyish white pseudomembrane over the tonsils, which can bleed upon removal. This is due to the toxin produced by the bacteria, leading to necrosis and exudate formation.

questions.text: A woman who underwent dilatation and curettage following a missed abortion now presents with amenorrhoea. Urine pregnancy test is negative Hysterosalpingography shows the findings seen in the image below. What is your diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Asherman syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • The diagnosis is Asherman syndrome. The HSG film shows a moth-eaten appearance.
  • The above clinical characteristics, history, and hysteroscopic findings are suggestive of Asherman syndrome.
  • Asherman syndrome involves intra-uterine adhesions, which usually occur following a D & C.
  • Clinical Features: Hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea, and infertility.
  • Diagnosis:
    • HSG: Shows a moth-eaten appearance or honeycomb appearance.
    • Hysteroscopy: Used for confirmation.
  • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis is the standard treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sheehan syndrome: This is described as pituitary necrosis following blood loss or postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), resulting in amenorrhoea (low FSH, LH), hypothyroidism, hypoprolactinemia, etc.

 

Option B. Endometriosis: This is the presence of ectopic endometrium outside the uterine cavity. It may also cause extensive pelvic adhesions.

 

Option D. Pyometra: This refers to the presence of a pus-filled uterine cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Asherman syndrome is characterized by intra-uterine adhesions, typically following dilatation and curettage (D&C), presenting with hypomenorrhea, secondary amenorrhoea, and infertility. It is diagnosed via HSG and hysteroscopy and treated with hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

 

Ref: D.C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology Page 459

choices.text: Dark field

questions.text: Which of the following methods would be the most cost-effective for testing syphilis in a village with limited resources? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark Field

 

Dark field microscopy is the most cost-effective method for diagnosing syphilis, especially in resource-limited settings. It allows direct visualization of the Treponema pallidum spirochetes in samples taken from lesions, such as chancres or condylomata lata. This method is relatively inexpensive and can be performed with minimal laboratory infrastructure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immunofluorescence: Incorrect. While immunofluorescence is a sensitive method for detecting Treponema pallidum, it requires specialized equipment and reagents, making it less cost-effective and impractical for use in resource-limited settings.

 

Option C. Culture: Incorrect. Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, cannot be cultured in artificial media. Therefore, culture is not a viable option for diagnosing syphilis.

 

Treponema can be grown by serial intratesticular passage in rabbit testes.

 

Option D. Simple microscopy: Incorrect. Simple microscopy, such as using a light microscope, is not sufficient for detecting Treponema pallidum because the spirochetes are too thin to be seen without specialized techniques like dark field microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dark field microscopy is the most cost-effective method for diagnosing syphilis in resource-limited settings, allowing for direct visualization of Treponema pallidum spirochetes from lesion samples.

questions.text: What is the average duration of lochia discharge in a puerperal woman? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24-36 days

 

Explanation:

 

The average duration of lochial discharge in a puerperal woman is about 24-36 days. Lochia is the vaginal discharge that occurs for the first few weeks during the puerperium, the period following childbirth when the mother's body, including hormone levels and uterus size, returns to a non-pregnant state. The discharge originates from the uterine body, cervix, and vagina and is a mix of blood, mucus, and uterine tissue.

 

Lochia has a peculiar offensive fishy smell and an alkaline reaction that tends to become acidic towards the end of the discharge period. Depending on the color variation of the discharge, it is categorized as follows:

 

  • Lochia rubra (red): Occurs during the first 1-4 days postpartum and is primarily composed of blood, making it bright red in color.
  • Lochia serosa: Occurs from days 5-9 postpartum, with the color transitioning to yellowish, pink, or pale brownish due to the decreasing amount of blood and increasing mucus and leukocytes.
  • Lochia alba (pale white): Occurs from days 10-15 postpartum and consists mainly of white blood cells, mucus, and epithelial cells, giving it a pale white appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 5-15 days: This duration is shorter than the average period of lochial discharge, which generally extends beyond 15 days.

 

Option B. 10-20 days: This duration is also shorter than the typical 24-36 days for lochial discharge.

 

Option D. 36-42 days: While some women may experience lochial discharge for this duration, it is longer than the average duration of 24-36 days.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The average duration of lochia discharge in a puerperal woman is about 24-36 days.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Page170

questions.text: A substance abuser was found on the roadside with a low respiratory rate and with pinpoint pupils. Which of the following should be suspected in this drug abuser? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Morphine

 

Pinpoint pupils are typically caused by opioids and organophosphates. Along with respiratory depression, the pinpoint pupil is diagnostic of opioid poisoning, so the answer is Morphine.

 

Opioids are depressant drugs, and hence most body functions are depressed. Typically, there is clinical triad of:

 

  • CNS depression (coma)
  • Respiratory depression: Most characteristic
  • Pupil size depression (Miosis, pinpoint pupil)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cocaine: It is a stimulant, not a depressant. So, the effects will be the opposite. Cocaine poisoning will have dilated pupils. Breathing is rapid and shallow in cocaine but slow and shallow in opium poisoning.

 

Option C. Alcohol: Alcohol is also a CNS depressant, but the depressive effects are less severe as compared to opium poisoning. The pupils are usually dilated in alcohol poisoning; they become contracted only in late stages of alcohol poisoning.

 

Option D. Cannabis: Cannabis typically causes mild symptoms only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pinpoint pupils and respiratory depression are strongly indicative of opioid poisoning, with morphine being a common opioid responsible for such symptoms.

questions.text: IUCD having the longest life span is: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CuT 380 A

 

Explanation:

 

  • CuT 380 A has the longest life span.
  • It is named CuT 380 A because the surface area of copper is 380 mm.
  • Its higher surface area is responsible for its greater efficacy.
  • CuT 380 A maybe replaced after 10 years

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progestasert: It is a progesterone (38 mg) containing IUD, which is no longer manufactured. It had a shorter lifespan.

 

Option C. Mirena: It is a LNG containing IUD (52 mg LNG released at the rate of 20 mg per day). It is replaced every 7 years.

 

Option D. Nova T: It is similar to Copper containing IUD but additionally it has a silver core.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The CuT 380 A intrauterine contraceptive device has the longest life span, which can be used for up to 10 years.

 

Ref: D. C Dutta’s textbook of Gynecology 6th Edition page 480, Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg 109

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the newborn baby as shown in the image? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Imperforate anus

 

The given investigation is invertogram. It is done 6-12 hours after birth. It is done for anorectal malformations (ARM). Gap between the gas and coin measured, if it is >2 cm we suspect abnormalities proximal to pelvic floor, like rectal atresia (high ARM). If gap is < 2cm, the ARM is low, and restricted only to anal defects.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Meningocele is a type of neural tube defect that occurs during fetal development. It is attributed to the maternal folic acid deficiency. It involves protrusion of the meninges through a defect in the skull or vertebra. It is asymptomatic and mainly presents with a tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region.

 

Option B. Congenital Mega-colon is also known as Hirschsprung disease. It is congenital condition that occurs due to absence of ganglion cells in the colonic segment. The affected segment fails to relax, while the portion proximal to it becomes dilated.

 

Option D. Pyloric stenosis is a condition that affects the newborn and infants. It involves the hypertrophy of the pylorus leading to gastric outlet obstruction. The patient presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting with dehydration and hypochloremic hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with paradoxical aciduria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An invertogram performed 6-12 hours after birth is used to diagnose anorectal malformations in newborns by measuring the distance between a gas bubble in the rectum and a coin marker on the perineum.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly seen after bariatric gastric bypass surgery? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Iron deficiency anemia

 

Roux-en-Y gastric bypass is a common bariatric surgery, second to sleeve gastrectomy. The most common deficiency observed after this procedure is iron deficiency anemia. This occurs because the stomach, which plays a role in converting dietary iron to its absorbable form, is partially bypassed. Reduced stomach acid production post-surgery also impairs iron absorption. This is particularly concerning for menstruating women, who are at higher risk for iron deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficiency of vitamin D: After a Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, there's a reduced absorptive surface area and altered gut flora, leading to decreased absorption of fat-soluble vitamins, including vitamin D. However, this deficiency is less common compared to iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option B. Deficiency of calcium: Reduced stomach acid production post-gastric bypass can affect the solubilization of calcium salts, leading to decreased calcium absorption. This deficiency is often associated with vitamin D deficiency but is not as common as iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option C. Protein-calorie malnutrition: After bariatric surgery, especially gastric bypass, the reduced stomach size can lead to decreased food intake. If protein intake is not adequate, it can lead to protein-calorie malnutrition, particularly in the early post-operative period. However, this is less common compared to iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iron deficiency anemia is the most common deficiency observed after Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery.

questions.text: Rh-ve mother had Rh+ve child. This Rh incompatibility is which type of hypersensitivity reaction? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cytotoxic

 

  • Rh incompatibility is an example of Type II hypersensitivity, also known as cytotoxic hypersensitivity. In this type of reaction, the body's immune system produces antibodies (IgG or IgM) against antigens that are part of the cell surface, such as those on red blood cells in the case of Rh incompatibility. When an Rh-negative mother carries an Rh-positive fetus, her immune system may produce antibodies against the Rh antigen. These antibodies can cross the placenta and attack the fetal red blood cells, leading to hemolytic disease of the newborn.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anaphylactic (Type I Hypersensitivity): Incorrect. Anaphylactic reactions involve IgE antibodies and occur immediately after exposure to an allergen. Examples include allergic reactions to pollen, insect stings, or certain foods.

 

Option C. Immune Complex Mediated (Type III Hypersensitivity): Incorrect. Type III hypersensitivity involves the formation of immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) that deposit in tissues, causing inflammation and tissue damage. Examples include systemic lupus erythematosus and rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Option D. Delayed (Type IV Hypersensitivity): Incorrect. Delayed hypersensitivity reactions involve T cells and occur 48-72 hours after exposure to the antigen. Examples include contact dermatitis and the tuberculin skin test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rh incompatibility, where an Rh-negative mother has an Rh-positive child, is an example of Type II (cytotoxic) hypersensitivity reaction, where antibodies produced by the mother attack the fetal red blood cells.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child, known to be underweight and experiencing difficulty seeing in low light, presents with significant dryness in the eyes. The child's diet is primarily carbohydrate-based with minimal intake of green vegetables and meat. What is the WHO grading for the child's ocular condition related to malnutrition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1A

 

In this case:

 

  • Child presents with dryness of eye, that is Conjunctival Xerosis (X1A)
  • The symptom is consistent with early-stage Vitamin A deficiency caused by a malnourished diet.

 

Deficiency of Vitamin A leads to dryness of eyes or Xerophthalmia.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 1B (X1B): Represents Bitot's spots, which are more advanced than night blindness.

 

 

Option C. 2A (X2): Corneal xerosis, a later stage involving corneal dryness.

 

Option D. 2B (X3A): Involves corneal ulceration <1/3, indicating severe deficiency.

 

Educational Objective :

 

WHO Grading of Vitamin A Deficiency:

questions.text: Identify the organism seen in the image below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) P. falciparum

 

﻿﻿Image shows banana shaped gametocyte which is a feature of plasmodium falciparum

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. P. vivax: Enlarged erythrocyte, Schaffner’s dots, and 'Ameboid' trophozoite are characteristic of P. vivax but it does not have banana-shaped gametocytes.

 

Option C. P. Knowlesi: P. knowlesi exhibits features similar to P. malariae but is not commonly recognized by banana-shaped gametocytes.

 

Option D. P. malariae: P. malariae shows compact parasites and merozoites in a rosette formation but lacks the characteristic banana-shaped gametocytes of P. falciparum.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A pregnant lady is diagnosed to have bipolar disorder. Which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient? (FMGE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lithium

 

Lithium is associated with an increased risk of Ebstein's anomaly when taken during pregnancy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: Lamotrigine is an antiepileptic also used for bipolar disorder and has a safer profile in pregnancy.

 

Option C. Risperidone and Option D. Haloperidol are antipsychotics, and while they have their own considerations in pregnancy, they're not as notably teratogenic as lithium.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The teratogenic risks of mood stabilizers: Lithium is linked to cardiac malformations like Ebstein's anomaly; lamotrigine has a mild association with oral clefts; valproate is associated with neural tube defects and other congenital abnormalities (most teratogenic mood stabiliser); carbamazepine is linked to neural tube defects; and oxcarbazepine has similar risks as carbamazepine, though less defined.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 690.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with confusion, difficulty walking, and memory problems. His wife reports that he has been a heavy drinker for the past 20 years. On examination, he has a wide-based gait and horizontal nystagmus. Laboratory tests reveal macrocytic anemia. Which of the following is the most likely deficiency causing his symptoms? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Thiamine

 

The patient’s symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (as indicated by nystagmus) along with a history of chronic alcohol use suggest Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is caused by thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency. Chronic alcohol consumption impairs thiamine absorption and utilization, leading to neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12:  While vitamin B12 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms and macrocytic anemia, it typically presents with subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which is characterized by different symptoms such as paresthesias, ataxia, and weakness, without the triad seen in Wernicke's encephalopathy.

 

Option C. Folate: Folate deficiency can also lead to macrocytic anemia, but it does not typically cause the neurological deficits seen in this patient. Folate deficiency is more often associated with megaloblastic anemia without the specific neurological presentation.

 

Option D. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is associated with bone diseases such as rickets and osteomalacia. It does not cause the neurological symptoms observed in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency, resulting in Wernicke's encephalopathy. The classic triad of symptoms includes confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Early recognition and treatment with thiamine are crucial to prevent progression to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rasburicase

 

Rasburicase is a recombinant uricase enzyme used to break down uric acid, thereby preventing the complications of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). It is highly effective in rapidly reducing uric acid levels in patients at risk of or experiencing TLS.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rituximab: An anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody used primarily in certain lymphomas and autoimmune diseases.

 

Option C. Gemtuzumab: A monoclonal antibody used in acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Option D. Alemtuzumab: A monoclonal antibody used in chronic lymphocytic leukemia and multiple sclerosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rasburicase is used in the management of tumor lysis syndrome due to its effectiveness in reducing uric acid levels.

questions.text: What is the best-recommended management in a case of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both A & B

 

Explanation:

 

Vault prolapse, which involves the descent of the vaginal vault (the apex of the vagina) often accompanied by cystocele (prolapse of the bladder into the vagina) and rectocele (prolapse of the rectum into the vagina), requires a comprehensive surgical approach to repair both the anterior and posterior vaginal walls.

 

  • Anterior colporrhaphy involves the repair of the anterior vaginal wall to correct the cystocele.
  • Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy involves the repair of the posterior vaginal wall and perineum to correct the rectocele.

 

This dual approach effectively addresses both components of the prolapse, providing better anatomical and functional outcomes.

 

Other treatment options for vault prolapse:

 

  • Site-specific repairs: Involves both anterior and posterior colporrhaphy.
  • Sacrospinous fixation: Suturing the vaginal vault to the sacrospinous ligament to provide support.
  • Abdominal or laparoscopic sacro-colpopexy: Considered the gold standard for vault prolapse, this involves attaching the vaginal vault to the sacrum using a mesh.
  • Colpocleisis (Le Fort repair): A procedure that closes off the vaginal canal and is usually reserved for women who are no longer sexually active.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior colporrhaphy only: This would address the cystocele but not the rectocele.

 

Option B. Posterior colpoperineorrhaphy only: This would address the rectocele but not the cystocele.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: While a hysterectomy removes the uterus, it does not address the prolapse of the vaginal vault, cystocele, or rectocele. Additional repairs are still necessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The management of vault prolapse with cystocele and rectocele typically involves both anterior colporrhaphy and posterior colpoperineorrhaphy to effectively repair both the anterior and posterior vaginal walls.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition Page 211

choices.text: Hand over patient to advanced cardiac support and leave
Ask them to apply the paddles while he continues CPR
Stop CPR and give water to the patient
Continue 3 round of CPR and then use defibrillator

questions.text: A person who is out for a morning walk sees a man who has collapsed on the road. He starts CPR and soon the ambulance arrives. What should be his next step? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ask them to apply the paddles while he continues CPR

 

This is the most appropriate action. By continuing CPR while the ambulance team prepares the defibrillator, there is no interruption in blood flow to the vital organs. The defibrillator can then be used immediately once ready.

 

During a cardiac arrest, the immediate priority is to ensure continuous and effective chest compressions to maintain blood circulation. When advanced cardiac support arrives, the transition should be smooth to avoid any interruption in chest compressions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hand over patient to advanced cardiac support and leave: This is not the best initial step as it might lead to an interruption in the chest compressions. The goal is to ensure a seamless transition without stopping the compressions.

 

Option C. Stop CPR and give water to the patient: Stopping CPR to give water is not recommended as it can lead to aspiration and does not address the underlying issue of cardiac arrest. Continuous chest compressions are critical.

 

Option D. Continue 3 rounds of CPR and then use defibrillator: If a defibrillator is available, it should be used as soon as possible if a shockable rhythm is present. Waiting for 3 rounds of CPR might delay necessary defibrillation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cardiac arrest situations, continuous chest compressions should be maintained until advanced cardiac support can take over. If a defibrillator is available, it should be used promptly to increase the chances of survival.

questions.text: While taking history from a patient in the psychiatry OPD, the patient keeps on repeating the questions that have been asked by the examiner. What is the term used for this phenomenon? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Echolalia

 

In this scenario, the patient is repetitively echoing or repeating the questions asked by the examiner. This phenomenon is characteristic of echolalia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Echopraxia: Echopraxia involves the imitation or repetition of another person's movements or gestures. It is not applicable to the repetition of spoken words or questions, which is the case in this scenario.

 

Option C. Perseveration: Perseveration refers to the persistent repetition of the same response, beyond point of relevance. While it involves repetition, it's different from the repetition of questions seen in echolalia.

 

Option D. Posturing: Posturing involves spontaneous maintenance of posture for long periods of time. It is unrelated to the repetition of spoken words or questions.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is A) Echolalia, as it specifically describes the repetitive echoing of words or questions, which is the behavior exhibited by the patient in the psychiatry OPD.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Echolalia refers to mimicking the examiner's speech often seen in autism spectrum disorder, Tourette's syndrome, and certain forms of schizophrenia, especially catatonic schizophrenia.

 

Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 4th edition, Page No 93.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child is brought to the OPD with cramping abdominal pain. On examination, she is found to have rashes on the back of her legs, buttocks and the extensor surface of her forearms. Laboratory analysis reveals proteinuria and microscopic hematuria. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Henoch-Schoenlein purpura

 

Henoch-Schoenlein purpura is described in this clinical situation.

 

Henoch-Schoenlein purpura (HSP) characteristics:

 

It is a small vessel vasculitis.

 

Henoch-Schoenlein Purpura (HSP) is a systemic vasculitis mediated by IgA and characterized by the clinical triad of non-thrombocytopenic palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and arthritis. In addition, there may be varying degrees of renal involvement. It is the most frequent vasculitis in children.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic lupus erythematosus: SLE will have a butterfly rash mainly over the face (nasolabial folds)

 

Option C. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: The typical presentation of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis includes:

 

  1. Hematuria (blood in the urine), which may make the urine appear reddish or brown
  2. Proteinuria (excess protein in the urine)
  3. Edema (swelling), especially around the eyes, hands, feet, and abdomen
  4. Hypertension (high blood pressure)

 

Option D. Hemolytic uremic syndrome: The classic triad of symptoms associated with hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) includes:

 

  1. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (MAHA): This refers to the destruction of red blood cells as they pass through small blood vessels, leading to anemia. Fragmented red blood cells, also known as schistocytes, can be seen on a peripheral blood smear.
  2. Thrombocytopenia: HUS is characterized by low platelet count, which can lead to an increased risk of bleeding.
  3. Acute kidney injury (AKI): HUS can cause damage to the glomerular capillaries in the kidneys, leading to acute kidney injury. This can result in symptoms such as decreased urine output, swelling, and high blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:


Henoch-Schoenlein purpura is a small vessel vasculitis characterized by the clinical triad of palpable purpura, abdominal pain, and arthritis, with potential renal involvement.

questions.text: A young male presented with slight dragging sensation in the scrotum. On examination a bag of worm feel was noted in the left side of scrotum. However, testes were normal. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Left varicocele

 

A left varicocele is an enlargement of the veins within the loose bag of skin that holds the testicles (scrotum). It feels like a "bag of worms" and is often described as such during clinical examinations. It's typically benign and more commonly found on the left side. On standing, these veins fill up, leading to the characteristic feeling. The condition can cause a slight dragging sensation in the scrotum but does not affect the testes themselves.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left hydrocele: A hydrocele is a fluid-filled sac surrounding a testicle that causes swelling in the scrotum. The fluid collection can be felt as a fluctuant mass in the scrotum. It doesn't give a "bag of worms" feel but more of a smooth swelling.

 

Option B. Inguinal hernia: This condition occurs when tissue, like part of the intestine, protrudes through a weak spot in the abdominal muscles. This protrusion can descend into the scrotum, leading to a noticeable bulge. Although it may cause a dragging sensation, the feel on examination would be different from the described "bag of worms".

 

Option C. Epididymo-orchiditis: This is inflammation of the testicle and epididymis, often due to an infection. It typically presents with pain, swelling, and redness of the affected testicle. On examination, the testis and epididymis would be tender and enlarged, but it wouldn't feel like a "bag of worms".

 

Educational Objective:

 

A varicocele is characterized by a "bag of worms" feel in the scrotum and is often found on the left side, causing a slight dragging sensation without affecting the testes.

questions.text: Cotton swabs are discarded in which bin? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Yellow

 

  • Cotton swabs are discarded in the yellow bin. The yellow bin is designated for infected waste, which includes soiled anatomical waste, chemical liquid, cytotoxic waste, laboratory waste, expired and discarded medicines, and other similar materials. The disposal method for items in the yellow bin typically involves incineration to ensure the complete destruction of potentially hazardous materials.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Red Bin: Incorrect. The red bin is used for discarding infected plastics such as syringes, gloves, and plastic waste. The disposal method for items in the red bin often involves autoclaving to sterilize the materials before final disposal.

 

Option C. Blue Bin: Incorrect. The blue bin is intended for glassware such as antibiotic vials, metallic implants, and glassware material except cytotoxic. Items in the blue bin are often sent for recycling or treated using plasma pyrolysis or incineration.

 

Option D. Black Bin: Incorrect. The black bin is typically used for general waste, such as kitchen waste, paper, tissues, water bottles, and cans. This waste is generally disposed of through secured landfilling.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: A 45-year-old urban health administrator is planning to set up a new Primary Health Centre (PHC) in an underserved urban area to cater to the healthcare needs of the local population. She is familiarizing herself with the human resource guidelines for urban PHCs. She understands that it is crucial to have the right number of staff for optimal functioning. Among the following staff requirements, she reviewed, which does NOT correctly represent the standard guidelines for staffing at an urban PHC? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 2 Staff nurses

 

According to the IPHS 2022 Guidelines for urban PHCs, the recommended staffing includes only 1 staff nurse, not 2 as listed in option D. Ensuring adherence to these guidelines is crucial for the optimal setup and functioning of the PHC.

 

Other 3 options are correct as per guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urban - Primary Health Centre is designed to consist: (IPHS 2022 Guidelines)

 

  • 2 Doctors
  • 1 Staff nurse
  • 1 Pharmacist
  • 1 Lab technician
  • 1 Lady health visitor
  • 5 ANM
  • 1 Public Health Manager

 

U-PHC (Urban - Primary Health Centre):

 

  1. 1 per 50,000 population (near or within a slum)
  2. OPD (consultation), basic lab diagnosis, drug/ contraceptive dispensing and delivery of RCH services, as well as preventive and promotive aspects of all diseases

questions.text: A laborer’s younger child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kwashiorkor


The clinical presentation described in this scenario is typical of Kwashiorkor, a form of acute severe malnutrition (SAM) characterized by edema, apathy, and specific changes in appearance. Kwashiorkor commonly affects infants and young children, particularly between the time of weaning and the age of 5 years. The hallmark features of Kwashiorkor include:

 

  • Edema: The presence of generalized edema, which often begins in the feet and lower legs, and eventually spreads to other parts of the body, including the abdomen, leading to the characteristic swollen belly.
  • Facial appearance: Children with Kwashiorkor often have a "moon face" appearance, with facial edema and a dull expression.
  • Hepatomegaly: The enlarged abdomen can also be due to liver enlargement (hepatomegaly) with fatty infiltration.
  • Skin changes: The child may present with skin lesions known as "flaky paint dermatosis," characterized by dark, peeling, cracked patches with pale skin underneath.
  • Hair changes: The hair becomes fine, thin, and brittle, and can be easily pulled out. There may be color changes in the hair, known as the "flag sign," where bands of depigmented (lighter) hair alternate with normal-colored hair.
  • Diet: The history of being primarily fed rice water, which lacks adequate protein, is a common contributing factor to the development of Kwashiorkor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Marasmus: Marasmus is another form of severe malnutrition, but it is caused by a deficiency of both calories and protein. Children with Marasmus typically appear very thin with a "baggy pants" appearance due to the loss of subcutaneous fat and muscle wasting. Unlike Kwashiorkor, there is no edema or swollen belly in Marasmus.

 

Option C. Indian childhood cirrhosis: This condition is related to chronic liver disease and is not associated with the acute severe malnutrition signs like edema and "moon face." It also presents with different clinical features such as jaundice and hepatomegaly, which are not mentioned in this case.

 

Option D. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease is characterized by fever, irritability, conjunctivitis, strawberry tongue, and edema of the hands and feet. It does not present with the swollen belly or the nutritional deficiencies described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:


Kwashiorkor is a form of severe malnutrition characterized by edema, a swollen belly, apathy, and specific skin and hair changes due to a deficiency of protein in the diet.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is palpated in the image shown below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior tibial artery

 

The posterior tibial artery pulse can be felt against the heel bone calcaneum about 2 cm below and behind (postero-inferior) the medial malleolus. The artery is felt in front (anterior) of the medial border of the tendocalcaneus, between the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus.

 

Note: Posterior tibial artery lies deep to the flexor retinaculum, hence, the patient is asked to 'invert' (turn the sole inside) his foot to relax the flexor retinaculum, before palpating the artery.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery terminates at the level of the ankle joint, where it gives off its terminal branch, the dorsalis pedis artery. The anterior tibial artery pulse can be palpated near the origin of the dorsalis pedis artery on the dorsum of the foot lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon.

 

Option C. Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is a major artery that supplies blood to the dorsum of the foot. It can be palpated by gently pressing your fingers along the midline of the foot, usually just lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon, between the first and second metatarsal bones.

 

Option D. Popliteal artery: The popliteal artery is a major blood vessel located in the popliteal fossa, which is the hollow area at the back of the knee joint. This artery is a continuation of the femoral artery, which runs down the thigh, and it plays a crucial role in supplying blood to the lower leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery is palpated just posterior to the medial malleolus and can be most readily felt by curling the fingers around the medial aspect of the ankle, pressing into the space between the medial malleolus and the Achilles tendon, above the calcaneum.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with history suggestive of liver disease. Hepatocytes showing ground glass appearance comment on the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hepatitis B

 

Hepatitis B: The presence of ground-glass hepatocytes is a characteristic histological finding in chronic Hepatitis B infection. These cells have a homogeneous, eosinophilic, ground-glass cytoplasm due to the accumulation of hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) within the endoplasmic reticulum. Chronic hepatitis B infection can lead to end-stage liver disease, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rotor syndrome: A benign hereditary condition characterized by jaundice, similar to Dubin-Johnson syndrome, but without liver cell pigmentation. There is no specific histological finding of ground-glass hepatocytes.

 

Option C. Hemochromatosis: An iron overload disorder where iron deposits in the liver, leading to a characteristic appearance on biopsy (Prussian blue staining), but not ground-glass hepatocytes.

 

Option D. Hepatitis A: An acute, self-limiting viral infection that does not typically cause the chronic histological changes seen with hepatitis B, such as ground-glass hepatocytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of ground-glass hepatocytes is a histological hallmark of chronic Hepatitis B infection.

questions.text: In the context of health education and behaviour change, consider a situation where a local health department in a city decided to address the rising cases of communicable diseases. They identified inadequate hand hygiene as a significant contributing factor. To address this, they organized a mass gathering to promote hand wash awareness. During this event, they employed a systematic approach to ensure maximum impact. They started by making people aware of the importance of hand hygiene, followed by sparking interest through demonstrations and interactive sessions. Subsequently, they gauged the audience's understanding and openness to the idea, and finally, they encouraged and supported the adoption of these practices in their daily routine. Based on this description, which of the following sequences of events in the behaviour change process is most appropriate? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Awareness-interest-evaluation-adoption 

 

The behavior change process typically follows these stages:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Awareness: Making people aware of the importance of a behavior (hand hygiene).

 

  • Interest: Sparking interest through engaging methods like demonstrations.

 

Option C. Evaluation: Assessing the audience's understanding and willingness to adopt the behavior.

 

Option D. Adoption: Encouraging and supporting the adoption of the behavior in daily routines.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5 stages are included in this process

 

  • Awareness
  • Interest
  • Evaluation
  • Trial
  • Adoption

choices.text: Downs syndrome
Klinefelter’s syndrome
Edward syndrome

questions.text: A young couple is trying for child for past 2 years. After unsuccessful trials they went for respective examinations. The investigations for female came out to be absolutely normal but male shows presence of (1) gynecomastia, (2) scanty pubic hairs, (3) atrophied testes. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Klinefelter’s syndrome

 

Klinefelter syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects males. It is caused by the presence of one or more extra copies of the x chromosome, resulting in a karyotype of 47, XXY. This extra genetic material can lead to a variety of physical, hormonal, and developmental differences.

 

Physical features: people with Klinefelter syndrome may have a tall and thin body type, with long legs, arms, and fingers. They may also have a small penis, undescended testicles, and enlarged breast tissue (gynecomastia).

 

Hormonal features: Klinefelter syndrome can cause low levels of testosterone and increased levels of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH). This can lead to infertility, decreased muscle mass, and reduced facial and body hair growth.

 

Developmental features: Klinefelter syndrome can affect cognitive and behavioral development. Boys with Klinefelter syndrome may have difficulty with language, reading, and social skills. They may also be at higher risk for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and other learning disorders.

 

Diagnosis: Klinefelter syndrome can be diagnosed through genetic testing, typically performed after puberty when physical and hormonal differences become more apparent.

 

Treatment: treatment for Klinefelter syndrome may include hormone replacement therapy to address low testosterone levels, speech therapy or educational interventions to address developmental differences, and surgery to address gynecomastia or undescended testicles.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Most common- genotype: 47xxy
  • Most common cause of male hypogonadism
  • More x chromosome—more mental retardation
  • Increase paternal/increase maternal age—increase Klinefelter syndrome
  • MC tumor with KFs—breast ca
  • MC CVS abnormality with KFs—MVP

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obesity: Not associated with the described symptoms.

 

Option B. Down's syndrome: Characterized by a different set of physical and developmental features, not related to gynecomastia or atrophied testes.

 

Option D. Edward syndrome: Also known as trisomy 18, characterized by distinct physical features and developmental delays, not related to the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome (47, XXY) and leads to features such as gynecomastia, scanty pubic hair, and atrophied testes, causing male hypogonadism and infertility.

questions.text: An orthopedic surgeon consults with a patient who recently lost both hands in an industrial accident, severely affecting his ability to perform daily tasks and work. Which term best categorizes the patient's condition given the profound impact on his life and role within society? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Handicap

 

The term "Handicap" most accurately describes the patient's condition. It refers to the disadvantage arising from an impairment or disability, which significantly limits the ability to fulfill roles or activities that are normally expected in society. Here, the loss of hands not only impacts physical capabilities but also severely hampers professional life and social roles, encompassing both the physical and socio-economic effects of the condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Disability: Any restriction or inability to perform an activity in a range considered normal for human being. (Inability to write and do machine work in this example)

 

Option B. Impairment: Any loss or abnormality of psychological, physiological, anatomical structure or its function. (As loss of both the hands in this case)

 

Option C. Disease: Any abnormal condition of an organism that impairs function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Handicap: A disadvantage for a given individual resulting from an impairment or disability that limits/ prevents fulfilment of a role considered normal for that individual. (Loss of job in this example)

questions.text:
An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On exam, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. Her labs showed the following findings: (FMGE JUNE 2022)

 

Hb – 6.9 g/dL,

 

WBC 4000/cm³ with normal DC,

 

S.Ca 13,

 

S.Cr 2.3 mg/dL,

 

Total protein 9 g/dL,

 

S. Albumin 2.4 g/dL.

 

Urinalysis shows Bence-Jones proteins.

 

An X-ray of her skull is shown.

 

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Multiple myeloma

 

The patient presents with hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, and bone lesions (CRAB criteria). The presence of Bence-Jones proteins in the urine and lytic bone lesions on the X-ray further support the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Metastatic breast cancer: Can cause bone lesions and hypercalcemia but does not usually present with Bence-Jones proteins.

 

Option C. Primary hyperparathyroidism: Causes hypercalcemia but typically does not present with anemia, renal failure, or bone lesions.

 

Option D. Milk-alkali syndrome: Can cause hypercalcemia but does not explain the other findings such as Bence-Jones proteins or lytic bone lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple myeloma is characterized by hypercalcemia, renal failure, anemia, and bone lesions, along with the presence of Bence-Jones proteins.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with fatigue, pallor, weight loss, and heaviness in the left hypochondrium for the past 2 months. Abdominal palpation reveals splenomegaly. His hemogram and peripheral smear results are given below. (FMGE JUNE 2022)

 

Hemogram: Hb – 10 gm/dL,

 

WBC count – 1,65,000,

 

Platelet count – 3 lakhs,

 

PS: Metamyelocytes – 15%, Promyeloblasts – 30%, Myeloblasts – 45%.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute myeloid leukemia

 

The presence of more than 20% blasts (myeloblasts) in the peripheral smear indicates acute myeloid leukemia (AML). AML is characterized by the rapid increase of abnormal white blood cells, which accumulate in the bone marrow and interfere with the production of normal blood cells.

 

Diagnostic Steps:

 

  • Bone Marrow Aspiration: This is essential to examine the types and numbers of cells in the bone marrow.
  • Flow Cytometry: Used to identify cells by their molecular markers, which is crucial for classifying the type of leukemia.
  • Cytogenetic Testing: Analyzes the chromosomes of cells from samples of bone marrow to identify genetic abnormalities associated with AML.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chronic lymphocytic leukemia: Characterized by the accumulation of mature but dysfunctional lymphocytes.

 

Option B. Chronic myeloid leukemia: Typically shows a lower percentage of blasts (<20% & in chronic cases <5%) and may progress to a blast crisis.

 

Option C. Acute lymphoblastic leukemia: More common in children and involves lymphoblasts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute myeloid leukemia is diagnosed when there is a high percentage of myeloblasts (>20%) in the blood or bone marrow.

questions.text: A patient presents to ophthalmology clinic with pain in eye. On examination and investigations, it was found to be a case of open angle glaucoma. History of the person reveals that he is also suffering from Bronchial asthma. Which of the following anti glaucoma drug should be avoided in this patient? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Timolol

 

Timolol is a non-selective beta blocker, which means it blocks both beta-1 and beta-2 adrenergic receptors. In patients with bronchial asthma, the blockade of beta-2 receptors can lead to bronchospasm, a potentially severe and life-threatening condition. Therefore, timolol should be avoided in patients with bronchial asthma to prevent exacerbation of their respiratory condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Apraclonidine: Apraclonidine is an alpha agonist. It primarily acts on alpha-2 adrenergic receptors and does not have the bronchoconstrictive effects associated with beta blockers. Therefore, it can be safely used in patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option C. Latanoprost: Latanoprost is a prostaglandin F2α (PGF2) analog. It is the drug of choice for the treatment of primary open angle glaucoma and does not have any bronchoconstrictive properties. It is safe for use in patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Option D. Brimonidine: Brimonidine is another alpha agonist. Similar to apraclonidine, it acts on alpha-2 adrenergic receptors and does not affect the bronchial smooth muscles. Thus, it is also safe for use in patients with bronchial asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Timolol, a non-selective beta blocker, should be avoided in patients with bronchial asthma due to the risk of precipitating bronchospasm.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman complaints of inability to conceive, dysmenorrhea, and pelvic pain. She has a history of frequent pelvic inflammatory disease. Hysterosalpingogram shows an absence of peritoneal spillage on the right side. Identify the given clinical scenario: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tubal block

 

  • The above clinical scenario is of a tubal block
  • Tubal block commonly happens secondary to
    • PID - Salpingitis (Chlamydia)
    • Genital tuberculosis
    • Adhesions due to previous surgery
    • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • If tubal block on HSG; next best step is Hysteroscopy-Laparoscopy
  • Treatment of proximal tubal block: hysteroscopic cannulation OR IVF
  • Treatment of distal tubal block: Fimbriectomy OR IVF

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endometriosis: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue at locations other than uterine cavity. It typically presents with dysmenorrhoea, dyspareunia, and infertility. This option is ruled out because of the HSG findings and presence of PID in the above question.

 

Option C. Asherman syndrome: It refers to the formation of intrauterine adhesions (synechiae) and presents with hypomenorrhea, amenorrhoea and infertility. It occurs following genital TB, PID or due scarring caused by repeated curettage. It may appear as a distorted or obliterated cavity with adhesions upon imaging.

 

Option D. Bilateral hydrosalpinx: It occurs following genital infections such as Tuberculosis and PID. Imaging shows dilated distended fluid filled fallopian tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tubal block commonly occurs secondary to PID, genital tuberculosis, adhesions due to previous surgery, and salpingitis isthmica nodosa. The absence of peritoneal spillage on HSG indicates a tubal block, and the next best step is hysteroscopy-laparoscopy.

 

Ref: D.C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology page247, Williams textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg441

questions.text: A 32-year-old lady presents with mobile breast lump which feels like a mouse in breast. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroadenoma

 

A fibroadenoma, often referred to as a "breast mouse," is a benign breast tumor commonly seen in young women between the ages of 16-25. It is characterized by a painless, slowly growing, solitary mobile lump that feels rubbery and can easily move under the skin. This mobility is why it is described as feeling like a "mouse" in the breast.

 

Fibroadenoma:

 

  • Commonality: A benign breast tumor commonly seen in young women.
  • Features: Described as rubbery and mobile under the skin, hence the term "breast mouse."
  • Age Group: Typically affects young women between 16-25 years of age.
  • Diagnosis Fit: Given the patient's age and the description of the lump, fibroadenoma is the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phyllodes tumor:

 

  • Nature: Rare breast tumors that can be benign, borderline, or malignant.
  • Growth: They tend to grow rapidly and can become quite large.
  • Age Group: They typically occur in women after the age of 40.
  • Distinguishing Feature: Rapid growth and potential to become large differentiate it from a fibroadenoma.

 

Option C. Invasive ductal carcinoma:

 

  • Nature: The most common type of breast cancer.
  • Presentation: Begins in the ducts and invades nearby tissues in the breast.
  • Mobility: Less likely to be as mobile or rubbery as a fibroadenoma.
  • Age Group: While it can occur in younger women, the mobility and description of the lump make this less likely.

 

Option D. Breast abscess:

 

  • Nature: A pocket of pus due to bacterial infection.
  • Symptoms: Associated with inflammation, redness, warmth, and tenderness.
  • Presentation: Would not be described as mobile or rubbery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibroadenomas are common, benign breast tumors in young women, characterized by a mobile, rubbery lump that can easily move under the skin, often described as feeling like a "mouse" in the breast.

questions.text: Which of the following radioactive isotopes is not used for brachytherapy?(FMGE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Iodine-131

 

I131 is a gamma plus beta-emitter used primarily as a systemic radiotherapy agent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Iodine-125: Used in brachytherapy for treating prostate cancer and eye plaques.

 

Option. C. Cesium-131: Used in brachytherapy for prostate cancer, brain tumors, and other malignancies.

 

Option. D. Palladium-103: Used in brachytherapy for prostate cancer and other localized tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brachytherapy implants:

 

Permanent implants trick: “GIPCY”

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿It can be given by oral route
﻿﻿﻿It is secreted by anterior pituitary
﻿﻿﻿All of the following are correct

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding oxytocin?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. It is responsible for Galactokinesis

 

Oxytocin is indeed responsible for galactokinesis, which refers to the milk ejection reflex in lactating women. This hormone plays a crucial role in the contraction of myoepithelial cells around the mammary glands, facilitating the ejection of milk.

 

Function of oxytocin –

 

  • Milk ejection (Galactokinesis)
  • Uterine contraction during Parturition

 

Oxytocin activates milk let down Reflex – Suckling by baby triggers touch receptors of mother’s breast, which further stimulate hypothalamus and posterior pituitary to release Oxytocin. It causes contraction of myoepithelial cells of breast tissue, leads to compression of lobules followed by ejection of milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. It can be given by oral route: Oxytocin cannot be administered orally as it would be broken down in the gastrointestinal tract before it could be effective.

 

Option C. It is secreted by anterior pituitary: Oxytocin is actually secreted by the posterior pituitary, not the anterior pituitary.

 

Option D. All of the following are correct: This option is incorrect because only statement A is true.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is critical for galactokinesis, or milk ejection, and is secreted by the posterior pituitary. It plays a vital role in both uterine contractions during parturition and the milk let-down reflex during lactation.

questions.text: Which of the following would help in explaining the mechanism of action of atrial natriuretic peptide?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. cGMP

 

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) operates through the second messenger cGMP, which are mainly concerned with dilation and relaxation (E.g., NO, Natriuretic peptide). ANP is involved in reducing blood volume, blood pressure, and sodium concentration, largely by increasing the excretion of sodium by the kidneys. The pathway via cGMP facilitates these effects by promoting vasodilation and increasing renal sodium excretion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: cAMP is a second messenger in pathways primarily concerned with metabolism, electrolyte secretion, and water reabsorption, but not directly involved with the action of ANP. (cAMP is increased by activation of adenyl cyclase)

 

Option C. IP3-DAG: The IP3-DAG pathway is associated with vasoconstriction and contraction, such as in the action of oxytocin during parturition, and does not explain the action of ANP. (eg; oxytocin act via IP3-DAG calcium second messenger during parturition)

 

Option D. JAK/STAT: This pathway is typically engaged by cytokines and growth factors like insulin or growth hormones, not by natriuretic peptides. Tyrosine kinase receptors act via the JAK/STAT pathway (e.g., insulin, insulin like growth factor, platelet derived growth factor)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The action of atrial natriuretic peptide is mediated through the second messenger cGMP, which promotes vasodilation and enhances sodium excretion in the kidneys, effectively reducing blood pressure and blood volume.

questions.text: Which of the following can reduce the risk of endometrial cancer in a post-menopausal woman on hormone replacement therapy (HRT)? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adding progesterone to Estrogen

 

Explanation:

 

  • Adding progesterone to estrogen in HRT can reduce the risk of potential endometrial cancer.
  • For women with a uterus, it is recommended to add progesterone to prevent endometrial hyperplasia which can occur with continued estrogen therapy.
  • For women without a uterus just estrogen therapy is sufficient.
  • Hormone therapy is only indicated for the treatment of osteoporosis, vasomotor symptoms, and vaginal atrophy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Combined oral contraceptive pills: These may be used for women with premature menopause or premature ovarian failure but are not specifically for reducing the risk of endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women on HRT.

 

Option B. Clonidine: It is an alpha-adrenergic agonist used to treat post-menopausal hot flushes when estrogen is contraindicated, such as with hypertension, but does not reduce the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Option C. Vitamin E: It may be useful in treating genitourinary symptoms but does not have a role in reducing the risk of endometrial cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adding progesterone to estrogen in hormone replacement therapy reduces the risk of endometrial cancer in post-menopausal women with an intact uterus.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition Page: 62,63

questions.text: Levels of D5–hydroxy Indole Acetic Acid (5-HIAA) in urine are raised: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carcinoid syndrome

 

This is the correct answer. Carcinoid syndrome occurs due to carcinoid tumors, which are neuroendocrine tumors that typically originate in the gastrointestinal tract or lungs. These tumors often secrete excessive amounts of serotonin. 5-HIAA is a major metabolite of serotonin, and its elevated levels in urine are a hallmark of carcinoid syndrome, reflecting the overproduction of serotonin by the tumor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hartnup’s Disease: Hartnup disease is a metabolic disorder characterized by abnormal absorption of amino acids in the kidneys and intestines. It specifically affects neutral amino acids, including tryptophan, but does not typically result in elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine. Instead, it can lead to symptoms resembling niacin deficiency (pellagra), due to the body's inability to convert tryptophan into niacin.

 

Option C. Phenylketonuria (PKU): PKU is a metabolic disorder characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of phenylalanine and its metabolites, but not to an increase in 5-HIAA levels. The primary concern in PKU is the neurotoxicity associated with high levels of phenylalanine.

 

Option D. Alkaptonuria: Alkaptonuria is a metabolic disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate dioxygenase. This deficiency leads to the accumulation and excretion of homogentisic acid, not 5-HIAA. It is characterized by darkening of the urine upon exposure to air and can lead to ochronosis (dark pigmentation of connective tissues) and arthritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Elevated urinary levels of 5-Hydroxyindoleacetic Acid (5-HIAA) are indicative of carcinoid syndrome, a condition resulting from serotonin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors, and are not associated with Hartnup’s disease, Phenylketonuria (PKU), or Alkaptonuria.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 310

questions.text: A person was brought to emergency with history of snake bite 8 hours ago. The patient had low respiratory rate and bradycardia with drooping of eyelids noted. 10 vials of antivenom were administered. What is the next line of management? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Give atropine + neostigmine

 

The above symptoms of drooping of eyelids indicates the venom was neurotoxic in nature and the snake venom has acted on the neuromuscular junction.

 

Apart from Anti-snake venom (ASV), for neurotoxic snakes also use Neostigmine (along with atropine).

 

  • Mechanism of Neostigmine: Neostigmine is the inhibitor of acetylcholinesterase enzyme. So, it will act as an antidote to acetylcholinesterase enzyme component of neurotoxic  venom
  • Why Atropine used with Neostigmine: As neostigmine increases the amount of acetylcholine, both nicotinic and muscarinic effects occur. But to treat snake bite we need only nicotinic effects at neuromuscular junction. Atropine is an antimuscarinic agent and helps to counter the muscarinic effects of nicotine, especially bradycardia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Check for blood coagulation profile: This is important in hemotoxic snake bites (like viper bites) where coagulopathy is a concern. However, the symptoms here are more indicative of neurotoxicity.

 

Option C. IV hydrocortisone: This could be used for allergic reactions to antivenom or severe inflammation, but it is not a first-line treatment for neurotoxic snake bite symptoms.

 

Option D. Inj epinephrine: This is used in anaphylaxis or severe allergic reactions but is not specifically indicated for managing neurotoxic effects of snake venom.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of neurotoxic snake bites where symptoms like ptosis (drooping eyelids), bradycardia, and low respiratory rate are present, the administration of atropine and neostigmine is crucial in addition to the antivenom to counteract the effects on the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: Identify the type of psoriasis in the given picture? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Guttate

 

The picture shows a classical picture of guttate psoriasis.
