  • Following a pharyngitis attack, the clinical stem of small red drop-like lesions on the trunk and arms (illustrated in the image) is suggestive of Guttate psoriasis.
  • HLA C 06:02 is associated with it.
  • A type of psoriasis known as guttate manifests as a sudden onset shower of small lesions that are more prominent on the trunk and proximal limbs. Following infection with group A Streptococcus, it is more prevalent in children and young adults and frequently the first sign of psoriasis. It can also happen in adults who have plaque psoriasis that first manifested in childhood.
  • Usually, lesions disappear after three months. Future plaque psoriasis development is a possibility in some patients with acute guttate psoriasis.

 

Guttate psoriasis Treatment:

  • Topical steroids
  • Antimicrobials - recurrent episodes may be linked to the patient's or a close relative's pharyngeal carriage of the culpable streptococcus. To eliminate chronic streptococcal carriage, a course of semi-synthetic penicillin and rifampin may be necessary.
  • In phototherapy, broadband UVB has a better response than NBUVB.

 

Note:

  • Plaque and follicular psoriasis both have a chronic course.
  • Patients with pustular psoriasis may experience cachexia, hypocalcemia, erythroderma, and fever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Erythrodermic Psoriasis:

  • This is a severe form of psoriasis where the skin appears extensively red and inflamed.
  • The skin sheds in sheets rather than scales.
  • It lacks the distinct drop-shaped papules of guttate psoriasis.

 

Option C. Pustular Psoriasis:

  • Characterized by white blisters of non-infectious pus surrounded by red skin.
  • The main feature is the presence of pustules, which are not described in your picture.

 

Option D. Inverse Psoriasis:

  • Found in the folds of the skin, such as under the armpits, in the groin, under the breasts, and other areas.
  • Appears as very red, smooth, and shiny lesions.
  • Unlike other forms, it lacks the classic scales seen in the "rain drop" pattern of guttate psoriasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Guttate Psoriasis is identified by its classic presentation of numerous small, drop-like papules, often appearing after a streptococcal infection, which is distinct from other psoriasis types that have different presentations and localizations.

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 35.4, 35.15 & 35.16

Andrew’s diseases of skin clinical dermatology – 12 edition page no 188-189

Online resources - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482498/

questions.text: What is the pattern of inheritance in neural tube defects? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multifactorial Inheritance


Neural tube defects (NTDs) are congenital malformations that arise from the improper closure of the neural tube during embryonic development. The pattern of inheritance for neural tube defects is multifactorial. This means that the disorder results from the interaction of multiple genes and environmental factors rather than following a simple Mendelian inheritance pattern.

 

Most cases of neural tube defects are sporadic, occurring in individuals without any family history of the disorder. Although a small percentage of cases have been observed to run in families, there is no clear pattern of inheritance, which further supports the multifactorial nature of the disorder.

 

Environmental factors that are known to contribute to the risk of NTDs include insufficient folic acid intake during pregnancy, maternal diabetes, and the use of certain anticonvulsant medications during pregnancy. The genetic component of NTDs involves multiple genes, although only a few environmental factors have been well-characterized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal dominant: This pattern of inheritance is characterized by the transmission of a single mutant gene from an affected parent, which is not the case in NTDs. Neural tube defects do not follow an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

 

Option B. X-linked dominant: In X-linked dominant inheritance, the gene responsible for the disorder is located on the X chromosome, and only one copy of the gene is sufficient to cause the disorder. NTDs do not follow this pattern of inheritance.

 

Option C. Autosomal recessive: This pattern requires two copies of a mutant gene (one from each parent) for the disorder to manifest. While autosomal recessive inheritance is seen in some genetic disorders, NTDs are not primarily inherited in this manner.

 

Educational Objective:


Neural tube defects are inherited through a multifactorial pattern, involving multiple genes and environmental factors.

 

 

Option A, B and C are not the most common type of inheritance of neural tube defects.

 

Conditions with autosomal dominant inheritance are:

 

AUTOSOMAL DOMINANT INHERITENCE

 

D – Dystrophia Myotonica

 

O – Osteogenesis Imperfecta

 

M – Marfan syndrome

 

I – Intermittent porphyria

 

N – Noonan syndrtome

 

A – Achondroplasia

 

N – Neurofibromatosis

 

T – Tuberous sclerosis / treacher collin syndrome

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition Page No-4226.

questions.text: Infer the extent of the thyroid gland from the given image?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A to D

 

The thyroid gland extends from vertebral levels C5 to T1. This corresponds from A to D in the given image.

The marked structure in the above given X- ray are :

 

A – At the level of C5 vertebrae

B- At the level of C6 vertebrae

C- At the level of C7 vertebrae

D- At the level of T1 vertebrae.

 

The thyroid gland is a butterfly-shaped endocrine gland located in the neck, just below the Adam's apple (thyroid cartilage). It extends from approximately the level of the fifth cervical vertebra (C5) to the first thoracic vertebra (T1). This means that the thyroid gland spans the region of the neck from about the base of the neck to the upper part of the chest.

 

It's important to note that the size and shape of the thyroid gland can be influenced by factors such as age, gender, hormonal changes, and health conditions. Additionally, some individuals may have variations in the size or location of their thyroid gland, but the general anatomical location remains consistent within the neck and upper chest region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyroid gland typically extends from the fifth cervical vertebra (C5) to the first thoracic vertebra (T1), covering the region from the base of the neck to the upper chest.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child post-tonsillectomy comes to you with complaints of snoring, palpitations, mouth breathing and a slight decrease in hearing. On examination, you notice a high arched palate. His school performance is deteriorating as well. His mother is worried. What is the next line of management for this child?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Adenoidectomy with grommet insertion

 

The child's symptoms suggest the presence of adenoid hypertrophy, which is contributing to eustachian tube dysfunction, leading to serous otitis media. This condition can result in conductive hearing loss, which may be contributing to his school performance issues. Additionally, the presence of snoring and mouth breathing indicates that the adenoids may be sufficiently enlarged to obstruct the airway, particularly during sleep.

 

Next Steps in Management: Adenoidectomy with Grommet Insertion: This surgical intervention is recommended to address both the adenoid hypertrophy and the associated middle ear effusion. Removing the adenoids can help open up the airway and improve nasal breathing, while grommet insertion (myringotomy with tube placement) helps ventilate the middle ear and prevent fluid accumulation, improving hearing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenoidectomy Alone: While this would address the nasal obstruction, it might not adequately resolve the middle ear effusion without the addition of grommets.

 

Option B. Myringoplasty: This is a repair procedure for a perforated eardrum, not relevant to this case as the main issue is middle ear effusion, not tympanic membrane perforation.

 

Option D. Conservative Management: Given the impact on the child’s hearing and school performance, plus the physical symptoms, conservative management would likely be insufficient in providing relief.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Reinfection with which of the following virus can lead to more severe disease with complications? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dengue

 

Dengue virus infection can be caused by any of the four serotypes (DEN-1, DEN-2, DEN-3, DEN-4). A primary infection with one serotype usually results in immunity to that specific serotype. However, reinfection with a different serotype can lead to more severe disease due to a phenomenon known as antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE). This process can cause a more severe form of the disease, such as Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF) or Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS), especially with Dengue virus serotype 2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rabies: Rabies is almost always fatal once clinical symptoms appear, but it does not exhibit increased severity upon reinfection as it is typically a once-in-a-lifetime infection.

 

Option C. Measles: Reinfection with measles is rare due to the strong, long-lasting immunity conferred by initial infection or vaccination. Complications are generally more severe during the initial infection.

 

Option D. Mumps: Reinfection with mumps is uncommon due to the immunity developed after the first infection or vaccination. Complications are not typically more severe upon reinfection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reinfection with Dengue virus can lead to more severe disease due to antibody-dependent enhancement, especially with Dengue virus serotype 2, leading to conditions such as Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever (DHF) and Dengue Shock Syndrome (DSS).

 

Note -

 

﻿﻿Serotype: 1, 2, 3, 4

 

﻿﻿Most dangerous serotype: type 2

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman with complaints of mass per vaginum, as shown in the below image was posted for operative repair. During the pre-anesthetic check-up, she was found to be unfit for major surgery. Which of the following procedures is recommended for her? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Le Fort's repair

 

Explanation:

 

  • The given scenario suggests uterine prolapse in an elderly woman found to be unfit for major surgery.
  • Le Fort's repair is recommended in this case. It is a colpocleisis procedure that involves obliterating the vagina.
  • Indications for Le Fort's repair include:
    1. Patients who do not wish to retain sexual function.
    2. Very elderly menopausal patients with advanced prolapse.
    3. Patients medically unfit for major surgeries.
  • This procedure can be performed under regional anesthesia.
  • During Le Fort's repair, vaginal flaps from the anterior and posterior vaginal walls are excised, and the raw areas are opposed in the midline with sutures, preventing the uterus from prolapsing.
  • Before colpocleisis, a pap smear and endometrial biopsy are necessary, as once the vagina is obliterated, access to the cervix or endometrium will no longer be possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal wall Cervicopexy: Purandare's sling used strips of rectus sheath and fixed them to the anterior surface of the uterus. This was later modified using a Mersilene tape fixed to the anterior uterine surface.

 

Option B. Shirodkar's sling procedure: This procedure involves the fixation of tape to the posterior uterine surface, with the ends fixed to the sacrum. It is surgically complicated and increases the risk of sigmoid injury.

 

Option D. Khanna's sling procedure: This procedure involves the fixation of the ends of the tape to the anterior superior iliac spines.

Sling surgeries may be useful in patients with nulliparous prolapse or congenital uterine descent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Le Fort's repair, a colpocleisis procedure, is recommended for very elderly menopausal patients with advanced uterine prolapse who are medically unfit for major surgeries.

 

Ref: D C Dutta’s textbook of Gynaecology 3rd edition pg 221

questions.text: A mother complains of breast cramps during breastfeeding her child. Which hormone is responsible for this? (FMGE JUNE 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Oxytocin

 

Explanation:

 

Oxytocin helps in milk ejection by causing myoepithelial contraction, which is responsible for the cramps during breastfeeding. Oxytocin activates the Milk Let Down Reflex—suckling by the baby triggers touch receptors on the mother's breast, which stimulate the hypothalamus and posterior pituitary to release oxytocin. Oxytocin causes the contraction of myoepithelial cells in the breast tissue, leading to the compression of lobules and the subsequent ejection of milk.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Progesterone: Incorrect. Progesterone is responsible for alveolar growth in the breast but does not play a role in causing cramps during breastfeeding.


Option B. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen is responsible for ductal growth in the breast but does not cause cramps during breastfeeding.


Option C. Prolactin: Incorrect. Prolactin is responsible for milk production. It stimulates the breast alveolar epithelial cells to synthesize milk components, including lactose, casein, and lipids, but does not cause cramps.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin helps in milk ejection by myoepithelial contraction which is responsible for cramp during breastfeeding

 

  1. Function of oxytocin – milk ejection (Galactokinesis)
    • Uterine contraction
    • Oxytocin activates Milk Let down Reflex – Suckling by baby triggers touch receptors of mother’s breast, which further stimulate hypothalamus and posterior pituitary to release Oxytocin. Oxytocin causes contraction of myoepithelial cells of breast tissue, leads to compression of lobules followed by ejection of milk.
  2. Function of prolactin – milk production
    • Prolactin stimulates the breast alveolar epithelial cells to synthesize milk components, including lactose (i.e., the carbohydrate of milk), casein (i.e., the protein of milk), and lipids.
    • The prolactin receptors are down-regulated on mammary glandular tissue during periods of elevated progesterone levels (i.e., during pregnancy).
  3. Progesterone is responsible for alveolar growth
  4. Estrogen is responsible for ductal growth

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia and infertility. A diagnosis of endometriosis was made, and she was posted for laparoscopy surgery. During the procedure, dense pelvic adhesions were seen with the bowel stuck to the fundus and cystic ovaries stuck to each other. What is the next step in managing this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystectomy and adhesiolysis

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical scenario describes a case of endometriosis, characterized by severe dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility. During the laparoscopic surgery, the presence of dense pelvic adhesions and cystic ovaries suggests advanced endometriosis. The optimal management for this condition involves:

 

  • Cystectomy: Surgical removal of the cysts (endometriomas) from the ovaries.
  • Adhesiolysis: Surgical removal of the adhesions to restore the normal anatomy and improve fertility.

 

For patients with endometriosis, especially those desiring future fertility, surgical management to remove endometriomas and adhesions is the preferred approach. This can help alleviate pain and improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LUNA for chronic pelvic pain (Laparoscopic Uterine Nerve Ablation): This procedure involves cutting the nerves to the uterus to reduce chronic pelvic pain. However, it has not been found effective in treating chronic pain associated with endometriosis.

 

Option B. Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge: This medication has antiprogesterone, antiestrogenic, and androgenic properties. It may help in reducing symptoms by decreasing the LH surge but is not a definitive treatment for severe cases with extensive adhesions and endometriomas.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy and oophorectomy: This is a definitive treatment for endometriosis in women who do not desire future fertility. It involves the removal of the uterus and ovaries, thus eliminating the source of endometriosis. However, it is not suitable for a young woman desiring future fertility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of severe endometriosis with dense pelvic adhesions and cystic ovaries, the preferred surgical management involves cystectomy and adhesiolysis to alleviate symptoms and improve fertility.

 

Ref: Williams Textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg 243

questions.text: Which of the following is strongly associated with "Mucormycosis"? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic ketoacidosis

 

Mucormycosis, also known as zygomycosis, is a serious fungal infection caused by molds of the order Mucorales. This infection is strongly associated with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) because the acidic environment and elevated glucose levels in DKA favor the growth and proliferation of Mucorales.

 

In diabetic ketoacidosis, there is also the high level of free iron due to the acidosis, which facilitates the growth of Mucorales fungi. The compromised immune system in diabetes also makes individuals more susceptible to infections, including mucormycosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pregnancy: Pregnancy is generally not associated with an increased risk of mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Pneumocystis: Pneumocystis jirovecii causes a different type of infection, pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), primarily in immunocompromised individuals. It is not associated with mucormycosis.

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis is caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, which is different from the fungi causing mucormycosis. It is primarily associated with exposure to bird or bat droppings and does not have a strong link to mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a significant risk factor for mucormycosis due to the favorable conditions it creates for the growth of Mucorales fungi, highlighting the need for vigilance in managing patients with DKA to prevent this serious fungal infection.

 

﻿Other causes include:

 

  • ﻿﻿Covid-19
  • ﻿Excessive iron overload
  • ﻿﻿Chronic dialysis

questions.text:
A 49-year-old Indian male presents with splenomegaly and following CBC findings are as follows.

 

TLC is 1,20,000/µL, myeloblasts, promyelocytes, metamyelocytes = 45% basophils = 2%. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CML

 

Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is a type of blood cancer that affects the bone marrow, where blood cells are produced. It is characterized by the overproduction of abnormal white blood cells called myeloid cells, which can crowd out normal blood cells and lead to a range of symptoms.

 

key points about CML leukemia:

 

Cause: CML is caused by a genetic mutation in the bone marrow cells that produce white blood cells. This mutation creates an abnormal protein called bcr-abl, which triggers the overproduction of myeloid cells.

 

Symptoms: in the early stages of cml, there may be no symptoms. As the disease progresses, symptoms may include fatigue, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and abdominal discomfort. In some cases, cml may be diagnosed incidentally during routine blood tests.

 

Diagnosis: CML is typically diagnosed through a blood test (FISH)that detects the presence of the bcr-abl protein or abnormal white blood cells. Further testing, such as a bone marrow biopsy, may be performed to confirm the diagnosis and determine the stage of the disease.

 

Treatment: Treatment for cml may include medications called tyrosine kinase inhibitors  imatinib, which target the BCR-ABL protein and can help control the growth

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AML (Acute Myeloid Leukemia): Typically presents with more rapid onset of symptoms and a higher percentage of blasts in the blood and bone marrow.

 

Option C. ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): Involves lymphoid cells, not myeloid cells, and has a different clinical presentation.

 

Option D. CLL (Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia): Involves lymphoid cells and typically presents with different blood cell findings and clinical symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML) is characterized by the presence of the BCR-ABL protein and an overproduction of myeloid cells, leading to symptoms such as splenomegaly and elevated white blood cell counts.

questions.text: 74-year-old man presents with history of significant weight loss, and loss of appetite. There is no associated cough or hemoptysis. Chest X-ray was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Metastasis

 

The X-ray depicts the typical cannon ball appearance, suggestive of lung metastasis.

 

Other differential diagnosis to be considered for multiple nodules:

 

  • Septic emboli (Feeding vessel sign)
  • Fungal infection (Halo sign)
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (Cavitation within nodules)
  • Wegner's granulomatosis (Cavitation within nodules)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bronchogenic carcinoma: Typically presents as a single mass or nodule, which may cause obstruction leading to post-obstructive pneumonia, not multiple nodules as seen here.

 

Option B. Mesothelioma: Often manifests with a pleural effusion and thickening that encases the lung rather than multiple round nodules.

 

Option D. Pneumoconiosis: Results from the inhalation of dusts causing diffuse fibrotic changes and nodularity, but the nodules are usually more uniform in size and distribution compared to the "cannonball" pattern seen in metastatic disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiple round opacities on a chest X-ray in a patient with significant systemic symptoms such as weight loss should prompt consideration of metastatic disease. Further diagnostic investigations, including a CT scan of the chest and biopsy, are recommended to confirm the origin and nature of the nodules.

choices.text: Tinea corporis
Malassezia furfur

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple asymptomatic scaly patches varying in color from white to tan to brown to pink. On potassium hydroxide wet mount spaghetti and meat ball appearance is seen. Which of the following is causative organism for this disease? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Malassezia furfur

 

Malassezia furfur is a type of yeast that is commonly found on the skin of humans and animals. While it is a normal part of the skin microbiome, overgrowth of Malassezia furfur can contribute to several skin conditions.

 

Malassezia furfur is most commonly associated with seborrheic dermatitis, a chronic inflammatory skin condition that causes flaky, itchy, and inflamed skin on the scalp, face, and other areas of the body. It is also associated with pityriasis versicolor, a common fungal skin infection that causes light or dark patches on the skin.

 

  • Scales are mixed with 10% KOH - Spaghetti and Meat ball appearance

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tinea corporis: Also known as ringworm of the body, this condition is caused by dermatophytes such as Trichophyton, Microsporum, or Epidermophyton species. It presents with ring-shaped, red, scaly patches with a clearer center. It does not show a "spaghetti and meatball" appearance on KOH mount.

 

Option C. Sporotrichosis: This is a fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii. It typically presents with nodular lesions following lymphatic drainage pathways, often related to traumatic inoculation from vegetation. It does not present with asymptomatic scaly patches nor the "spaghetti and meatball" appearance on KOH mount.

 

Option D. Blastomycosis: Caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, this fungal infection can affect the skin but usually presents with verrucous, ulcerative, or nodular lesions. It does not present with asymptomatic scaly patches nor the "spaghetti and meatball" appearance on KOH mount.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malassezia furfur is the causative organism for pityriasis (tinea) versicolor, characterized by asymptomatic, scaly patches of varying colors and a distinctive "spaghetti and meatball" appearance on KOH wet mount.

questions.text: A Patient comes with symptoms of lead poisoning. The antidote is? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Dimercaprol + Calcium EDTA

 

The most effective treatment for lead poisoning involves the use of chelating agents that bind to the lead and facilitate its excretion from the body. The combination of dimercaprol and calcium EDTA (CaNa2 EDTA) is considered the best treatment for severe lead poisoning.

 

Chelating Agents for Lead Poisoning:

 

  1. Dimercaprol (British Anti-Lewisite, BAL):
    • It is administered intramuscularly (IM).
    • Dimercaprol is effective in crossing the blood-brain barrier and can help remove lead from the brain, preventing lead encephalopathy.
  2. Calcium EDTA (CaNa2 EDTA):
    • It is administered intravenously (IV).
    • CaNa2 EDTA alone should not be used as it can redistribute lead from soft tissues to the brain. This can worsen lead encephalopathy if not used in combination with dimercaprol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Succimer (Dimercaptosuccinic Acid, DMSA):

 

  • Effective in mild to moderate lead poisoning.
  • Administered orally.

 

Option B. Dimercaprol:

 

  • Alone, it is not sufficient for treating lead poisoning as effectively as the combination with CaNa2 EDTA.

 

Option C. Calcium EDTA:

 

  • Should not be used alone due to its inability to cross the blood-brain barrier and its potential to redistribute lead into the brain.

 

Treatment Protocol:

 

  • For Severe Lead Poisoning:
    • Start with dimercaprol IM to address any lead in the brain.
    • Follow with CaNa2 EDTA IV to chelate lead from the bloodstream and soft tissues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of dimercaprol and calcium EDTA is the most effective treatment for severe lead poisoning because it addresses lead in both the brain and the rest of the body.

 

Chelating agents for Lead poisoning:

 

  1. British Anti Lewisite (BAL, aka dimercaprol, dimercaptopropanol): available in IM route.
  2. CaNa2 EDTA available by IV route
  3. Dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA, aka succimer): available Orally
  4. Dimercaptopropanesulfonic acid (DMPS, aka Dimerval): available Oral, IM and IV.
  5. Penicillamine available orally

choices.text: Exanthem subitum
Erythema infectiosum
Hand foot mouth disease

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is characterized by a lacy or reticular rash on the extremities and "slapped cheek" appearance as shown in the image? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythema infectiosum

 

  • ﻿﻿Caused by parvo B19
  • ﻿﻿SSDNA virus
  • ﻿﻿Non enveloped
  • ﻿﻿Non enveloped DNA virus

 

The initial symptoms of erythema infectiosum include a low-grade fever, headache, and a runny nose. After a few days, a characteristic rash appears on the face, which gives the appearance of "slapped cheeks". The rash then spreads to the trunk, arms, and legs, and can be itchy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exanthem subitum (Roseola infantum): Roseola is caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and sometimes HHV-7. It typically presents with a sudden high fever that lasts for a few days, followed by a rash that appears as the fever subsides. The rash usually starts on the trunk and spreads to the extremities but does not have the characteristic "slapped cheek" appearance.

 

Option C. Hand, foot, and mouth disease: This disease is caused by enteroviruses, commonly coxsackievirus. It presents with fever, sores in the mouth, and a rash on the hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks. The rash is usually vesicular rather than lacy or reticular.

 

Option D. Mumps: Mumps is caused by the mumps virus, a paramyxovirus. It typically presents with swelling of the parotid glands, fever, and muscle aches, but it does not cause a lacy or reticular rash or the "slapped cheek" appearance.

 

Educational objective:

 

Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease) is characterized by a "slapped cheek" rash on the face, followed by a lacy or reticular rash on the extremities. It is caused by parvovirus B19, a non-enveloped, single-stranded DNA virus.

questions.text: Identify the anatomical structure marked in the given image? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Extensor pollicis longus

 

The marked structure in the given image is extensor pollicis longus.

 

Extensor pollicis longus is also located in the forearm, not in the palm. This muscle extends the thumb at the carpometacarpal (CMC) joint and the MCP joint farthest from the thumb. It helps in straightening the thumb when it is bent, allowing for actions like grasping objects.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abductor pollicis brevis:  Abductor pollicis brevis is a short muscle located in the thenar eminence. Action of this muscle is to abduct the thumb. Abduction of the thumb is essential for grasping objects and performing various hand movements.

 

Option B. Extensor pollicis brevis:  Extensor pollicis brevis is another muscle found in the thenar eminence of the hand. This muscle extends the thumb at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint and the interphalangeal (IP) joint closest to the thumb.

 

Option C. Abductor pollicis longus: is located in the forearm, not in the palm of the hand. This muscle's primary function is to abduct the wrist and thumb. While it doesn't directly move the thumb away from the palm like the abductor pollicis brevis, it does play a role in the abduction of the thumb by controlling the movement of the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The extensor pollicis longus is key in extending the thumb and is located in the forearm, distinct from other thumb-related muscles which are primarily found in the hand itself.

choices.text: Type A PHC conducts < 20 deliveries per month
Provides maternal and child health care, family planning and MTP
Acts as a first referral unit
There is 1 PHC per 30000 population in plain areas

questions.text: A 32-year-old medical officer recently posted to a remote area to oversee the functioning of a Primary Health Centre (PHC) participates in workshops to familiarize herself with PHC mandates. Which of the following statements about PHCs is NOT accurate based on standard guidelines? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Acts as a first referral unit

 

Primary Health Centres (PHCs) are not designed to act as first referral units. The first referral level of healthcare in India is provided by Community Health Centres (CHCs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Type A PHC conducts < 20 deliveries per month: Correct as per guidelines.

 

Option B. Provides maternal and child health care, family planning, and MTP: Accurate description of PHC services.

 

Option D. There is 1 PHC per 30000 population in plain areas: Correct population norm for PHCs in plain areas.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Primary Health Centres (PHCs) serve as the first point of contact in the healthcare system, but the first referral unit is the Community Health Centre (CHC).

 

Additional Information

 

 

Levels of Primary Health Care System in India

 

  • Primary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘first level of contact between population and health care system’ in India.
    • Health services are delivered through:
      • Sub-centre
      • Primary Health Centre
  • Secondary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘First referral level of health care’ in India.
    • Health services are delivered through: Community Health Centre
  • Tertiary Level of Health Care:
    • Is ‘Second referral level of health care’ in India.
    • Health services are delivered through: Medical Colleges and Hospitals

choices.text: Vitamin D intoxication

questions.text: The dystrophic calcification is seen in? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Atherosclerosis

 

Dystrophic calcification occurs in dying or dead tissues where serum calcium levels are normal. It is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts in damaged tissues.

 

Example:

 

  • Atherosclerosis
  • Rheumatic nodule
  • Tumor (psammoma bodies)
  • Papillary cancer thyroid, papillary renal cell cancer
  • Serous cyst adenocarcinoma ovary
  • Meningioma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperparathyroidism: Associated with metastatic calcification due to hypercalcemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin D intoxication: Leads to hypercalcemia and metastatic calcification.

 

Option D. Hypercalcemia: Leads to metastatic calcification, not dystrophic calcification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dystrophic calcification occurs in damaged tissues with normal serum calcium levels and is commonly seen in conditions like atherosclerosis.

choices.text: Bence jones protein

questions.text: The most abundant plasma protein? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albumin

 

The most abundant plasma protein in the body is albumin, constituting approximately 60% of plasma proteins. Albumin is crucial for maintaining osmotic pressure, transporting various substances (e.g., hormones, fatty acids), and regulating pH.

 

Table summarizing major plasma proteins:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Globulin: Less abundant than albumin, globulins have various functions including immune response, transport, and clotting. Abnormal levels may indicate immune disorders, liver disease, or multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Creatinine: A waste product formed by the normal breakdown of muscle tissue and excreted in urine, creatinine is not a plasma protein.

 

Option D. Bence Jones protein: Not a normal constituent of blood plasma, Bence Jones protein refers to the abnormal presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin light chains in the urine of individuals with multiple myeloma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Albumin is the most abundant plasma protein, crucial for maintaining osmotic pressure, transporting substances, and regulating pH.

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice in a 55-year-old woman who presents with post-menopausal bleed? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Endometrial biopsy

 

Explanation:

 

The investigation of choice for a 55-year-old woman presenting with post-menopausal bleeding is an endometrial biopsy. Post-menopausal bleeding can be a symptom of endometrial cancer, hyperplasia, or other abnormalities of the endometrial lining. An endometrial biopsy allows for direct sampling and histopathological examination of the endometrial tissue, which can help identify the underlying cause of the bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pap smear: A Pap smear is primarily used for cervical cancer screening. It is not suitable for evaluating post-menopausal bleeding, as it does not provide information about the endometrium.

 

Option C. Fractional curettage: Fractional curettage involves scraping the endometrial lining and the cervical canal. It can be used if the endometrial biopsy is inconclusive or if there is a strong suspicion of cancer. However, it is more invasive compared to an endometrial biopsy.

 

Option D. CA-125 estimation: CA-125 is a tumor marker that may be elevated in ovarian cancer and other conditions. It is not specific or sensitive for diagnosing endometrial cancer and is not the first-line investigation for post-menopausal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate investigation for evaluating post-menopausal bleeding is an endometrial biopsy, as it can detect abnormalities in the endometrial lining, including hyperplasia and cancer.

 

Ref: Williams gynecology 3rd edition pg 708

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is exhibiting symptoms of a low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and a barking cough that have persisted for the last 5 days. Upon examination, he displays a hoarse voice, a moderately inflamed pharynx, and a slightly elevated respiratory rate. The chest X-ray reveals subglottic narrowing, resembling a steeple shape. Among the listed treatment options, which one is NOT recommended for managing this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Parenteral cefotaxime

 

The presence of the steeple sign on the x-ray indicates a diagnosis of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis).

 

However, it is important to note that parenteral cefotaxime (antibiotic) is not recommended for its treatment as the causative organisms are most commonly viral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulized Racemic Epinephrine: Recommended in severe cases of croup for its ability to reduce swelling in the airway and improve symptoms quickly.

 

Option C. Helium Oxygen Mixture (Heliox): Used to ease the work of breathing in severe cases of croup by reducing airway resistance.

 

Option D. Intramuscular Dexamethasone: A corticosteroid that reduces airway inflammation and is a standard treatment for croup to alleviate symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with painless cervical lymphadenopathy. During the examination, the right ear shows conductive hearing loss, and the tympanic membrane appears dull. Additionally, reduced mobility of the soft palate is noted. What could be the likely diagnosis for these findings?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma

 

Given clinical condition is suggestive of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adenoid cystic cancer: Typically involves salivary glands, not commonly associated with the described ear and nasopharyngeal symptoms.

 

Option C. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Mostly affects adolescent males and is a benign tumor, which would not usually present with the described range of symptoms including lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Quinsy: Refers to a peritonsillar abscess, primarily presenting with severe throat pain, unilateral sore throat, fever, and difficulty swallowing, differing significantly from the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a serious condition requiring prompt diagnosis and comprehensive treatment, given its potential for significant morbidity due to local invasion and distant metastasis. The clinical findings provided are strongly indicative of this diagnosis and warrant further confirmatory diagnostics, such as imaging and biopsy, followed by an appropriate oncological treatment regimen.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 284,285

questions.text: The neural tube defects show which type of inheritance? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multifactorial

 

Neural tube defects (NTDs) exhibit a multifactorial pattern of inheritance. This means that both genetic and environmental factors contribute to the development of NTDs.

 

Examples of conditions with multifactorial inheritance:

 

  • Congenital heart defects: Various genetic variations in multiple genes, along with environmental factors such as maternal smoking or exposure to certain medications, can contribute to the development of congenital heart defects.
  • Type 2 diabetes: Multiple genetic variations across different genes, combined with lifestyle factors like obesity and sedentary behavior, contribute to the risk of developing type 2 diabetes.
  • Cleft lip and palate: Genetic factors in multiple genes, as well as environmental factors like maternal smoking or folate deficiency during pregnancy, influence the risk of cleft lip and palate.
  • Neural tube defects: As discussed earlier, neural tube defects result from a combination of genetic variations in multiple genes involved in neural tube development, as well as environmental factors like folic acid intake.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AD (Autosomal Dominant): Refers to a single gene inheritance pattern, not typically associated with neural tube defects.

 

Option B. XLR (X-linked Recessive): Refers to disorders linked to the X chromosome and typically affecting males, not the pattern seen in neural tube defects.

 

Option C. XLD (X-linked Dominant): Refers to disorders linked to the X chromosome that can affect both males and females, not the pattern seen in neural tube defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neural tube defects have a multifactorial inheritance pattern, meaning they are influenced by a combination of genetic and environmental factors.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the image given below? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bronchiectasis

 

The image shows dilated medium-sized bronchi, a characteristic feature of bronchiectasis. The signet ring appearance and tram track sign on imaging further support this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary tuberculosis: Would show cavitary lesions or miliary nodules.

 

Option B. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease: Shows hyperinflation and flattened diaphragms.

 

Option C. Bronchial asthma: Typically shows normal imaging or hyperinflation during an acute attack.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bronchiectasis is diagnosed by the presence of dilated bronchi and characteristic imaging signs.

choices.text: Wide bore needle insertion in intercostal space

questions.text: What should be the treatment in a patient who presented in the emergency with respiratory distress, dilated neck veins and an Xray chest showing large amount of air on the left side along with mediastinal shift as shown? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wide bore needle insertion in intercostal space

 

The chest X-ray findings in this patient indicate a tension pneumothorax. The hallmarks on the X-ray include a large amount of air on the left side, a depressed diaphragm, an ipsilateral collapsed lung, a shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side, and the absence of bronchovascular markings on the affected side. These signs, combined with the patient's clinical presentation of respiratory distress and dilated neck veins, confirm the diagnosis.

 

Management of tension pneumothorax involves immediate decompression to relieve the pressure. This is achieved by inserting a wide bore needle into the 2nd intercostal space at the midclavicular line in children, or in the 5th intercostal space at the anterior axillary line in adults. This procedure allows the trapped air to escape, relieving the pressure on the lung and the mediastinum, thereby stabilizing the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Endotracheal intubation: While endotracheal intubation is utilized in severe respiratory distress cases, it does not address the underlying cause of tension pneumothorax. The primary intervention required is immediate decompression.

 

Option C. Open thoracotomy: Open thoracotomy is a surgical procedure used for various thoracic conditions, including cardiac tamponade, but it is not the first-line treatment for tension pneumothorax. Immediate needle decompression is necessary for tension pneumothorax.

 

Option D. Pericardiocentesis: Pericardiocentesis involves the removal of fluid from the pericardial sac and is indicated for cardiac tamponade. It is not an appropriate treatment for tension pneumothorax, which requires decompression of the pleural space.

 

Educational Objective:
 

In the case of a tension pneumothorax, immediate decompression with a wide bore needle in the appropriate intercostal space is essential to relieve pressure and stabilize the patient.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with a skin lesion over elbow as shown below. Biopsy shows the presence of multiple neutrophilic foci in the stratum corneum. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Psoriasis

 

  • The case scenario given in this question is suggestive of psoriasis which is supported by the presence of silvery white scaly plaques on the extensor aspect of the elbow, & Munro microabscess (collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum).
  • Psoriasis: It is an inflammatory noninfectious disease. There is an increased number of activated Th1, Th17 & Th22 cells with a deficiency of Th2 cells.
  • Genetic predisposition is present in type 1 plaque psoriasis & guttate psoriasis with HLA C 06: 02

 

Histopathological features of psoriasis:

 

  • Thickening of stratum spinosum (Acanthosis)
  • Hyperkeratosis & Parakeratosis
  • Suprapapillary thickening

 

Clubbing of rete ridges at the base. Regular Elongation of rete ridges, gives a camel foot or clubbed appearance to the epidermal rete ridges.

 

  • Kogoj spongiform pustules (collection of neutrophils in Malpighian layer
  • Munro microabscess (collection of neutrophils in stratum corneum)
  • Absence of stratum granulosum
  • Dilated tortuous blood vessels in the dermis
  • Suprapapillary mononuclear leucocytic infiltrates

 

 

Regular acanthosis with rete peg elongation giving rete ridges a "camel foot" appearance.

 

Remember: M (Munro microabscess) is seen in P (Psoriasis) & P (Pautriers microabscess) seen in M (Mycosis fungoides)

 

The image below shows histopathology of psoriasis:

 

 

Psoriasis - epidermis shows psoriasiform hyperplasia with markedly elongated rete ridges, with bulbous thickening and fusion of their lower portions with thin suprapapillary epidermal plates, edema and dilated vessels in the dermal papillae

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atopic dermatitis:

 

  • Atopic dermatitis, or eczema, typically presents with itchy, red, and inflamed skin.
  • The histological findings in atopic dermatitis do not typically show neutrophilic foci in the stratum corneum. Instead, you might find spongiosis (intercellular edema in the epidermis).

 

Option C. Pemphigus vulgaris:

 

  • Pemphigus vulgaris is an autoimmune blistering disorder.
  • It is characterized histologically by acantholysis (loss of cell-cell adhesion) in the suprabasal layer, leading to intraepidermal blisters.
  • Neutrophilic foci in the stratum corneum is not a characteristic finding for pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option D. Pemphigus Foliaceous:

 

  • Pemphigus foliaceus is another type of autoimmune blistering disorder.
  • It is histologically characterized by acantholysis in the uppermost layers of the epidermis, but again, not by neutrophilic foci in the stratum corneum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psoriasis is diagnosed by recognizing the characteristic clinical presentation of erythematous plaques with silvery scales and the histopathological finding of Munro micro abscesses.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 4.17-18, 35.6-7, 41.1, 41.21

questions.text: A patient with long history of CHF with maintained ejection fraction and no signs of hypervolemia comes to you with long QRS waves in ECG and cardiac wall hypertrophy. Which of the following drug is best to be started to prolong survival? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lisinopril

 

The scenario involves a patient with chronic heart failure (CHF) with a preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), indicated by the absence of hypervolemia and the presence of cardiac wall hypertrophy. The presence of long QRS waves in the ECG suggests electrical conduction abnormalities, possibly related to the hypertrophy. Among the options given, Lisinopril is the most appropriate drug for this condition to potentially prolong survival:

 

Lisinopril is an ACE inhibitor, a class of drugs known to be beneficial in patients with HFrEF. In HFpEF, the evidence is less clear, but ACE inhibitors can be helpful, especially in patients with hypertension, as they reduce afterload and can improve ventricular remodeling.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Digoxin: While digoxin is used in heart failure, it is more commonly associated with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF). It can help improve symptoms and reduce hospitalizations but has not been shown to prolong survival in patients with HFpEF.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Furosemide is a diuretic used to manage fluid overload in heart failure. However, since the patient has no signs of hypervolemia, starting furosemide would not be indicated and could potentially lead to adverse effects like electrolyte imbalances and dehydration.

 

Option D. Nifedipine: Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker used primarily to treat hypertension. It's not typically used in heart failure and can sometimes worsen the condition, particularly immediate-release nifedipine, due to its negative effects on cardiac contractility.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient with chronic heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF), an ACE inhibitor like Lisinopril is the best choice to start treatment as it helps in reducing afterload, improving ventricular remodeling, and potentially prolonging survival. Digoxin, furosemide, and nifedipine are not appropriate for this specific patient scenario.

choices.text: Normal saline

questions.text: A 9-year-old child came to the clinic. Her mother gave the history of repeated blood transfusion over the past. She is presently worried about her son as earlier he got good grades in class but now from past few months his grades are decreasing and he remains lethargic. His blood investigations show crescent shaped RBC. What should be the next step in management of this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood transfusion

 

  • The history of repeated blood transfusion in the child, along with the presence of crescent-shaped red blood cells, suggests a possible diagnosis of sickle cell disease.
  • The child's decreasing grades and lethargy are concerning and could be related to inadequate oxygen supply to the brain due to anaemia. Blood transfusion is an essential component of the management of sickle cell disease to alleviate symptoms and improve oxygen-carrying capacity. Transfusion therapy can help increase the haemoglobin level and improve the overall well-being of the child.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV antibiotics: Not indicated unless there is an infection.

 

Option C. Normal saline: Hydration is important in sickle cell disease but does not address the primary issue of anemia.

 

Option D. Observation: Inadequate as active management is required to prevent complications related to severe anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with sickle cell disease presenting with symptoms of severe anemia and crescent-shaped RBCs, blood transfusion is the appropriate next step to manage the condition and improve the child's overall well-being.

questions.text: A patient who is a primipara is experiencing an aggravation of hearing impairment during her pregnancy. Rinne's test yields negative results in both ears, and Weber's test indicates lateralization to the right side. Upon otoscopy, the tympanic membranes appear normal. Audiometry reveals a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz. What treatment would be most suitable for this particular condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Stapedotomy

 

The given clinical presentation strongly indicates otosclerosis as the diagnosis, and the preferred treatment for this condition is stapedotomy an effective surgical treatment for otosclerosis, often preferred over stapedectomy due to a lower risk of complications and similar efficacy in restoring hearing

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sodium fluoride: Once a common medical treatment for otosclerosis, though now largely considered obsolete due to less satisfactory long-term outcomes compared to surgical interventions.

 

Option B. Tympanoplasty: This procedure is used to reconstruct the tympanic membrane and middle ear ossicles but is not indicated for otosclerosis, which does not typically affect the tympanic membrane integrity.

 

Option C. Stapedectomy: surgical treatment for otosclerosis, but less preferred over stapedotomy due to high risk of complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with otosclerosis, especially during pregnancy, stapedotomy is the recommended treatment to address conductive hearing loss effectively. These surgical options are typically preferred over medical management with sodium fluoride due to better auditory outcomes and more definitive resolution of conductive hearing impairments.

questions.text: State the action of the muscle marked in the given image: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Abduction of shoulder joint

 

Explanation

 

The muscle marked in the given image is supraspinatus and the action of the muscle is abduction of the shoulder joint. It steadies the head of the humerus during movements, and abducts the shoulder joint from 0-15°

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Retraction of scapula: The retraction of the scapula involves pulling the scapula (shoulder blade) toward the midline of the body. This action is primarily performed by the rhomboid muscles and the middle fibers of the trapezius muscle. The supraspinatus muscle is not involved in scapular retraction.

 

Option B. Protraction of scapula: Protraction is the opposite of retraction and involves moving the scapula away from the midline of the body. This movement is primarily performed by the serratus anterior muscle. The supraspinatus muscle is not responsible for scapular protraction.

 

Option D. Adduction of shoulder joint: Adduction is the opposite of abduction and involves bringing the arm back toward the midline of the body. Muscles responsible for shoulder adduction include the pectoralis major and the latissimus dorsi. The supraspinatus muscle does not perform shoulder adduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary action of the supraspinatus muscle is the abduction of the shoulder joint especially during the initial phase of shoulder abduction

questions.text: A patient who was being given intercostal nerve block  for rib fracture suddenly collapsed while the block was being performed. He Is diagnosed to have local anesthetic systemic toxicity. What is the treatment of this condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 20% intralipid emulsion

 

Explanation:

 

Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) is a severe and potentially fatal complication that can occur when local anesthetics are accidentally injected into the bloodstream or absorbed in excessive amounts. It can present with a range of symptoms including neurological signs (e.g., dizziness, tinnitus, seizures) and cardiovascular symptoms (e.g., arrhythmias, bradycardia, cardiovascular collapse).

 

Treatment for LAST:

 

  • 20% intralipid emulsion: This is the recommended treatment for LAST. The administration of a 20% intralipid emulsion acts as a lipid sink, which helps to sequester the lipophilic local anesthetic, reducing its free plasma concentration and toxicity.
    • Initial Bolus: 1.5 mL/kg over 1 minute
    • Continuous Infusion: 0.25 mL/kg/min, which can be increased if there is no improvement in the patient's condition

 

Other Options:

 

Option B, C & D Other concentrations such as 15%, 35%, or 100% intralipid emulsion are not used for this specific purpose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first-line treatment for Local Anesthetic Systemic Toxicity (LAST) is the administration of a 20% intralipid emulsion, which acts by creating a lipid sink to reduce the free plasma concentration of the local anesthetic, thereby mitigating its toxic effects.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the conversion of T4 to T3, in the peripheral tissue?(FMGE JUNE  2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Iodothyronine deiodinase I

 

Peripheral T3 conversion from T4 is catalyzed by the enzyme Iodothyronine deiodinase I. This enzyme is crucial for converting the prohormone thyroxine (T4) into the active hormone triiodothyronine (T3), primarily in peripheral tissues like the liver, kidney, and thyroid gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iodothyronine deiodinase II: This enzyme mainly converts T4 into T3 in the brain and thyroid gland, rather than in peripheral tissues.

 

Option C. Iodothyronine deiodinase III: Known as type 3 iodothyronine deiodinase (D3), this enzyme acts as the major physiological inactivator of thyroid hormones, not a converter of T4 to T3.

 

Option D. Iodotyrosine deiodinase: Also known as iodotyrosine dehalogenase, this enzyme is involved in the recycling of iodine during thyroid hormone synthesis by catalyzing the removal of iodine atoms from iodotyrosine, thus releasing free iodide that can be reused in thyroid hormone synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Iodothyronine deiodinase I is the enzyme responsible for the conversion of T4 to T3 in peripheral tissues, playing a crucial role in activating thyroid hormones.

choices.text: Shaving with razor night before operation

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method for hair removal to avoid surgical site infection? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hair clippers on table

 

The sequence of hair removal methods in terms of the least risk of infection is:

 

  • On-table clipping of hair > on-table use of depilatory creams > razor

 

Hair clippers on table:

 

  • Mechanism: Hair clippers trim hair close to the skin without causing micro-abrasions associated with shaving or chemical irritation from depilatory creams. The action is mechanical rather than chemical, minimizing skin irritation.
  • Timing: "On table" means that the hair removal is done immediately before the surgical procedure, leaving minimal time for any bacterial colonization, thus reducing the chances of infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Shaving with a razor night before operation:

 

  • Risk: Shaving can create micro-abrasions (tiny cuts) in the skin, serving as potential entry points for bacteria. These small wounds might get infected, leading to surgical site infections.
  • Timing: Shaving the night before also provides time for bacteria to colonize these micro-abrasions, increasing the risk of infection.

 

Option B. Depilatory cream before operation:

 

  • Mechanism: Depilatory creams break down hair and do not create the same abrasions as razors.
  • Risk: They can cause skin irritation, potentially leading to a weakened skin barrier. A compromised skin barrier can increase the risk of bacterial invasion and infection.
  • Timing: Using it immediately before the surgery reduces the colonization time for bacteria, but there is still some risk due to potential skin irritation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method for hair removal to avoid surgical site infection is using hair clippers immediately before the surgical procedure.

questions.text: Long lasting results in CABG are obtained when graft is harvested from which blood vessel? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Internal mammary artery

 

Natural arterial grafts last longer than venous or synthetic grafts. The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is the most preferred vascular graft for Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) due to its superior long-term patency rates. This is because the LIMA has a muscular wall that resists atherosclerosis, making it more durable and less prone to occlusion compared to other grafts.

 

Internal mammary artery:

 

  • Location: Runs along the inside of the chest wall.
  • Benefits: The LIMA is often used in CABG because of its proximity to the heart and its superior long-term patency rates. It has a muscular wall that resists atherosclerosis, ensuring longer-lasting results.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Long saphenous vein:

 

  • Usage: Commonly used due to its length, making it suitable for multiple grafts.
  • Longevity: Vein grafts tend to have higher rates of occlusion over time compared to arterial grafts. They do not have the same durability as arterial grafts and are more prone to developing atherosclerosis.

 

Option C. Poly tetra fluoroethyl:

 

  • Material: Synthetic graft.
  • Usage: Synthetic grafts are generally not the first choice for CABG due to concerns about patency and the risk of complications compared to natural grafts. They are less favored due to a higher risk of thrombosis and occlusion.

 

Option D. Gastroepiploic artery:

 

  • Usage: Less commonly used than the IMA or saphenous vein.
  • Indication: Typically reserved for situations where other preferred graft sources are not available or viable. Its long-term patency rates are not as favorable as the LIMA.

 

Arterial grafts, like the LIMA, are preferred over venous grafts because they have non-collapsible lumens, reducing the risk of thrombosis and occlusion, and providing better long-term outcomes in CABG.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The left internal mammary artery (LIMA) is the preferred graft for CABG due to its superior long-term patency rates and resistance to atherosclerosis.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for Legionnaire's disease? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Azithromycin

 

Azithromycin is the preferred treatment for Legionnaire's disease due to its effectiveness and better side effect profile compared to erythromycin. Levofloxacin can also be used as an alternative.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vancomycin: Not effective against Legionella.

 

Option C. Streptomycin: An aminoglycoside used for different bacterial infections.

 

Option D. Erythromycin: Historically used for Legionnaire's but less preferred due to side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Azithromycin is the drug of choice for treating Legionnaire's disease.

 

Additional Information

 

There are 4 atypical Organism – Legionella, Mycoplasma, Chlamydia and Rickettsia:

questions.text: Identify the pathology? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hollow viscus perforation

 

The chest X-ray in the image shows air under the diaphragm, which is indicative of perforation peritonitis. This condition, commonly referred to as a hollow viscus perforation, occurs when there is a hole in the gastrointestinal tract, allowing air to escape into the peritoneal cavity. The presence of free air under the diaphragm on an erect chest X-ray is a classic sign of this condition. The treatment of choice involves fluid resuscitation of the patient, intravenous antibiotics, and emergency laparotomy.

 

The hallmark radiographic finding for a hollow viscus perforation is "free air" or "air under the diaphragm" on an erect chest X-ray or abdominal X-ray. This sign indicates the escape of air from a perforated gastrointestinal organ into the peritoneal cavity, necessitating urgent surgical intervention.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute pancreatitis: Acute pancreatitis is typically diagnosed with clinical findings and imaging such as a CT scan of the abdomen. On imaging, the pancreas may appear swollen, and there might be evidence of associated complications like pancreatic necrosis or fluid collections. However, air under the diaphragm is not a characteristic feature of acute pancreatitis.

 

Option B. Liver abscess: A liver abscess is usually identified on imaging modalities like ultrasound or CT scan, showing a well-defined hypoechoic or cystic lesion within the liver. The presence of air under the diaphragm is not associated with liver abscess.

 

Option C. Acute cholecystitis: Acute cholecystitis is primarily diagnosed using ultrasound, which would show a thickened gallbladder wall, pericholecystic fluid, and possible gallstones. Air under the diaphragm is not a typical finding in acute cholecystitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of free air under the diaphragm on an erect chest X-ray is indicative of a hollow viscus perforation, which is a medical emergency requiring immediate surgical intervention.

choices.text: Superior vena cava
Inferior vena cava

questions.text: The image shows the cross-section of the abdominal cavity. Identify the structure marked 'A'. (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Descending aorta

 

Explanation

 

In the given image, the structure marked 'A' corresponds to the descending aorta.

The descending aorta is a continuation of the aortic arch and begins at the level of the fourth thoracic vertebra (T4). It descends through the thoracic and abdominal cavities and eventually branches into smaller arteries to supply blood to various organs and tissues throughout the body.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option B) Superior vena cava:  The superior vena cava is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the upper half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. It collects blood from the head, neck, upper limbs, and part of the chest. The superior vena cava plays a crucial role in returning blood to the heart for oxygenation.

 

Option C) Inferior vena cava:  The inferior vena cava is another significant vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. It collects blood from the lower limbs, abdomen, and pelvis. Like the superior vena cava, the inferior vena cava is essential for venous return to the heart.

 

Option D) Ascending aorta: is the initial segment of the aorta that originates from the left ventricle of the heart. It carries oxygenated blood away from the heart and delivers it to the coronary arteries (for heart muscle oxygenation) and the rest of the body. The ascending aorta then curves to form the aortic arch, which gives rise to various branches, including the brachiocephalic artery, left common carotid artery, and left subclavian artery.

 

Educational Objective

questions.text: ETC complex IV is inhibited by:(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cyanide

 

Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the iron within the heme group of cytochrome a3, which is a critical component of Complex IV. This binding prevents the transfer of electrons to molecular oxygen, the final electron acceptor, thereby blocking the production of water and halting mitochondrial ATP synthesis via oxidative phosphorylation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antimycin A: This inhibits Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) of the electron transport chain by binding to the Q_i site and blocking electron transfer between cytochrome b and c1.

 

Option C. Oligomycin: It inhibits ATP synthase (Complex V), blocking the proton flow through the enzyme and thereby preventing the synthesis of ATP from ADP and inorganic phosphate.

 

Option D. Rotenone: An inhibitor of Complex I (NADH dehydrogenase), rotenone binds to the site on Complex I that accepts electrons from NADH, thus preventing the transfer of electrons to ubiquinone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibitors of ETC

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 116

questions.text: A 32-year-old public health researcher is analyzing maternal health data. She mentions a metric that represents the number of maternal deaths for every 100,000 live births in a specific year. Which term best describes this metric? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Maternal Mortality Ratio

 

Maternal mortality Ratio (MMR): Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births where a ‘maternal death’ is defined as ‘death of a women while pregnant of during delivery or within 42 days (6 weeks) of termination of pregnancy, irrespective of duration or site of pregnancy, from any cause related to or aggravated by the pregnancy or its management but not from accidental or incidental causes.

 

  • Maternal deaths expressed as per 100,000 live births (earlier it was expressed per 1000 live births but that yielded fractions like 4.08 maternal deaths per 1000 LB; so, denominator was extrapolated to 100,000 to make MMR value more sensible)
  • MMR is a ratio

 

 

ADDITIONAL INFORMATION

 

MMR World: 216 per 100,000 live births; Causes of MMR (globally):

 

  • Hemorrhage (25%)
  • Indirect causes (20%)
  • Infection (15%)
  • Unsafe abortion (13%)
  • Eclampsia (12%)
  • Obstructed labour (8%)

 

MMR India: 97 per 100,000 live births [2023]; Causes of MMR (India) [SRS 2023]:

 

  • Hemorrhage (38%)
  • Other conditions (34%)
  • Sepsis (11%)
  • Abortion (8%)
  • Obstructed labour (5%)
  • Hypertensive disorders (5%)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maternal mortality rate (MM Rate): Dividing the average annual number of maternal deaths in a population by the average number of women of reproductive age (typically those aged 15 to 49 years) who are alive during the observation period. 

MM Rate reflects not only the risk of maternal death per pregnancy or per birth, but also the level of fertility in a population

 

Option C. Infant Mortality Rate (IMR): The IMR measures the number of deaths of infants under one-year-old per 1,000 live births in a given year.

 

Option D. Perinatal Mortality Rate: This measures the number of stillbirths and deaths in the first week of life per 1,000 total births (live and still) in a given year.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maternal Mortality Ratio (MMR) is a critical metric representing the number of maternal deaths per 100,000 live births in a specific year and is vital for assessing the quality of obstetric care.

questions.text: A patient present with multiple episodes or bloody diarrhea. On investigation of blood sample Enterohemorrhagic strain of E. Coli was isolated. On which of the following media this organism can be cultured? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sorbitol MacConkey agar

 

EHEC

 

  • ﻿﻿O157: H7
  • ﻿﻿O: somatic antigen
  • ﻿﻿H: Flagellar antigen
  • ﻿﻿Causes Haemolytic uremic Syndrome & haemorrhagic colitis in children

 

EHEC is primarily transmitted through the consumption of contaminated food, particularly undercooked ground beef, raw vegetables, and unpasteurized dairy products. Person-to-person transmission can also occur through contact with fecal matter.

 

In severe cases, EHEC infection can lead to a complication known as hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS), which can cause kidney failure and other serious health problems. HUS is more likely to occur in children, older adults, and individuals with weakened immune systems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TCBS (Thiosulfate-citrate-bile salts-sucrose agar): This medium is selective for Vibrio species and is not suitable for the isolation of E. coli, including EHEC.

 

Option B. Selenite F broth: This is an enrichment medium used primarily for the isolation of Salmonella species. It is not specific for E. coli.

 

Option C. Robertson cooked meat media: This is an enrichment medium used for the cultivation of anaerobes. It is not suitable for the isolation of E. coli.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sorbitol MacConkey agar is the preferred medium for the isolation and differentiation of Enterohemorrhagic E. coli (EHEC) strains such as O157, which do not ferment sorbitol, resulting in colorless colonies on this medium.

choices.text: Dose at which 50% animal mortality is seen in an experiment, after exposure to the drug
50% reduction of infection in the given population of experimental animals
Dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50 individuals
Range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low

questions.text: LD50 stands for? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dose at which 50% animal mortality is seen in an experiment, after exposure to the drug

 

LD50 (median lethal dose) is a key measure in toxicology studies used to determine the dose of a substance that causes death in 50% of the experimental animals after exposure. It provides an indication of the acute toxicity of the substance:

 

LD50 (median lethal dose): It represents the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die after exposure. The larger the LD50, the safer the drug is considered to be because it means a higher dose is required to cause death in 50% of the population.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 50% reduction of infection in the given population of experimental animals: This description is incorrect for LD50. It might refer to an efficacy measure rather than a toxicity measure.

 

Option C. Dose of the drug that causes adverse effects in 50 individuals: This would describe the median toxic dose (TD50) rather than the median lethal dose (LD50). The TD50 is the dose at which 50% of individuals experience a specified adverse effect.

 

Option D. Range of concentrations at which the likelihood of efficacy is high and the probability of adverse effects is low: This describes the therapeutic window or therapeutic index, not LD50. The therapeutic index is calculated as the ratio of LD50 to ED50 (the effective dose for 50% of the population) and indicates the safety margin of a drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • LD50 (median lethal dose) is the dose of the drug at which 50% of the experimental animals die, after exposure to the drug. Larger the LD50, the safer is the drug.

  • ED50 is the dose required to produce the effect in 50% of the population. It is the marker of drug potency.

  • Therapeutic Index or TI = LD50/ED50

  • Therapeutic index is the margin of safety for a drug.

choices.text: 24 hours - 12 weeks after delivery
Shortly after the delivery of placenta

questions.text: When does secondary post-partum hemorrhage develop? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 24 hours - 12 weeks after delivery

 

Explanation:

 

  • Secondary postpartum hemorrhage occurs between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery.
  • Primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) occurs within 24 hours of childbirth with the most common cause being atonic PPH.
  • Causes of secondary PPH include:
    • Retained placenta
    • Endometritis
    • Placental polyp
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • AV malformations

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Within 6 hours of delivery: This falls within the timeframe of primary PPH, not secondary.

 

Option B. Within 24 hours of delivery: This also describes the period for primary PPH.

 

Option D. Shortly after the delivery of placenta: This timing is also associated with primary PPH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary postpartum hemorrhage develops between 24 hours and 12 weeks after delivery.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Page 483, 484

questions.text: A patient has undergone surgery as shown in the image below.  After this surgery, the patient presents with pallor, dizziness and sweating whenever he has a large meal. What could this be? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dumping syndrome

 

In a patient following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, who develop pallor, dizziness and sweating after a large meal, dumping syndrome is most likely.

 

Dumping syndrome is complication following gastric reconstructions and vagotomy

 

Dumping syndrome is of two types

 

  • Early dumping syndrome 
    1. Occurs due to rapid influx of fluid due to hyperosmolar contents in bowel
    2. Starts within 10 mins of meals intake
    3. Clinical features: epigastric fullness, bloating, nausea & vomiting, symptoms of hypotension: light-headedness, fainting
  • Late dumping syndrome
    1. Sweating, tachycardia, dizziness after 45 mins to 1 hour of eating food
    2. Worsens with exercise
    3. It is due to rebound hypoglycemia seen due to excessive Insulin release

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reflux gastritis presents with heartburn, regurgitation, chest pain.

 

Option C. Post-vagotomy diarrhea presents with loose watery stools, increased frequency of bowel movements and abdominal cramps.

 

Option D. Frey’s syndrome presents with gustatory sweating. It is seen after parotid surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dumping syndrome, a common complication following Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery, presents with pallor, dizziness, and sweating after a large meal due to rapid influx of fluid and hyperosmolar contents in the bowel.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿FSH secretion by anterior pituitary

questions.text: Cervical dilation and delivery on uterine contraction is similar to which of the following mechanisms? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Milk ejection by oxytocin

 

Explanation

 

Cervical dilation and delivery on uterine contraction is similar to the mechanism of Milk ejection by oxytocin. It helps in milk ejection by myoepithelial contraction, it also helps in Parturition. Both the times it works via positive feedback mechanism.

 

When the foetal body part start to descend during delivery → cervical dilatation → stimulate Hypothalamus → stimulate posterior pituitary →causes the release of oxytocin → contraction of the uterus → further descent of the foetus → more cervical dilatation → more release of oxytocin.

 

This cycle continues until delivery of a baby and placenta take place. This is known Parturition Reflex.

 

Oxytocin activates Milk Let down Reflex – Suckling by baby triggers touch receptors of mother’s breast, which further stimulate hypothalamus and posterior pituitary to release Oxytocin. Oxytocin causes contraction of myoepithelial cells of breast tissue, leads to compression of lobules followed by ejection of milk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Water retention by ADH: This process involves antidiuretic hormone (ADH) affecting the kidneys to retain water, unrelated to muscle contractions or feedback mechanisms similar to those in labor or milk ejection.

 

Option C. FSH secretion by anterior pituitary: Follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) stimulates the growth of ovarian follicles but does not involve feedback-driven contractions or similar physical processes as parturition or milk ejection.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect because the mechanism of milk ejection by oxytocin is indeed similar to that of cervical dilation and uterine contraction.

 

Educational objective:

 

Cervical dilation and uterine contractions during labor are similar to the mechanism of milk ejection, both mediated by oxytocin and driven by positive feedback loops, enhancing the respective processes until completion.

questions.text: Rahul, a diligent hospital staff member in New Delhi, is responsible for ensuring the proper disposal of biomedical waste. Every day, he's faced with a myriad of items that need to be correctly sorted to maintain the hospital's adherence to waste management guidelines. Today, he encountered an array of items, and he had to determine which of these should be placed in the yellow bin, designated for specific biomedical wastes. Which of the following items should Rahul discard in the yellow bin? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Blood bag

 

The yellow bin in biomedical waste management is designated for items such as human anatomical waste, soiled waste, and certain clinical wastes that include microbiological collections and used blood bags. Blood bags, which contain remnants of blood and other bodily fluids, are categorized under this type because of the high risk of contamination and the need for incineration or deep burial as per management guidelines.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A female presented with pain and redness of the left breast. She is lactating for the last 3 months. On examination, local temperature is raised and cracked nipple is noted. Ultrasound of breast was suggestive of significant liquid collection. What should be the next line of management? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Incision and drainage
