The clinical presentation of a postpartum female with fever, pain, and swelling of the breast, along with an ultrasound showing fluid collection, is indicative of a breast abscess.

 

Breast abscesses are more common in lactating women due to faulty breastfeeding techniques, with cracked nipples being a significant risk factor. The most common causative organism is Staphylococcus aureus, often sourced from the oropharynx of the child.

 

This is the definitive treatment for a breast abscess, especially when there is a significant collection of fluid, as indicated by the ultrasound.

 

Diagnosis:


Diagnosis is based on clinical examination and confirmed by ultrasound, which shows fluid collection indicative of an abscess.

 

Treatment:

 

  • Primary Treatment: Incision and drainage (I&D) is the mainstay of treatment for a confirmed breast abscess.
  • Antibiotics: While antibiotics (such as Amoxiclav) are important, they are adjunctive to the drainage procedure.
  • Needle Aspirations: Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration can be attempted, especially if the abscess is small. However, if multiple attempts fail, incision and drainage become necessary.
  • Suction Catheter Drainage: For large abscesses (>3 cm or >30 cc), suction catheter drainage is an effective management strategy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics: Antibiotics alone are not sufficient to treat a breast abscess as they do not address the pus collection. They are used in conjunction with drainage procedures.

 

Option B. Multiple needle aspirations: Ultrasound-guided needle aspiration can be attempted, but if it fails after at least two attempts, incision and drainage are indicated.

 

Option D. Breast support: While providing breast support is important for comfort and to help reduce pain, it is not a primary treatment method for a breast abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for a breast abscess in a lactating woman is incision and drainage, along with the use of antibiotics to manage infection.

choices.text: Alizarin red
Methylene blue
Prussian blue
Von kossa

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient is suffering from iron deficiency anemia. Which stain is used to confirm the iron stores? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Prussian blue

 

Hemosiderin is a hemoglobin-derived brownish pigment that accumulates in cases of repeated blood transfusions and hemolytic anemia. The Prussian blue stain, also known as Perl's stain, is used to detect iron deposits and demonstrate iron deficiency or overload in tissues.

 

Table listing some stains commonly used to diagnose various deficiencies and abnormalities:

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alizarin red: Used for assessing mineralization of bones and calcium levels, not iron stores.

 

Option B. Methylene blue: Commonly used as a general stain in microscopy, not specific for iron detection.

 

Option D. Von Kossa: Highlights calcium deposits in tissues, not used for iron detection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Prussian blue stain is used to confirm the presence of iron stores, particularly in cases of iron deficiency or overload.

choices.text: Para hydroxyl phenyl pyruvate
Phenyl acetic acid

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy with black discoloration of eye, skin and ear pinna. The urine also turned black at room (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Homogentisic acid

 

Alkaptonuria is a rare genetic disorder that affects the way the body breaks down certain amino acids. This disorder is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisic acid oxidase, which is necessary to break down the amino acids phenylalanine and tyrosine.

 

As a result, people with alkaptonuria accumulate a substance called homogentisic acid in their bodies. This can lead to a number of health problems, including darkening of the skin, joint pain, and damage to the heart, kidneys, and other organs.

 

There is currently no cure for alkaptonuria, but treatment options are available to help manage symptoms. These may include medications to relieve joint pain, dietary changes to limit the intake of certain amino acids, and surgery to repair or replace damaged joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Para hydroxyl phenyl pyruvate: Not related to the symptoms described.

 

Option B. Phenylalanine: Accumulated in phenylketonuria, not associated with black discoloration of urine.

 

Option D. Phenyl acetic acid: Not related to the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaptonuria is characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid, leading to dark urine and pigmentation of connective tissues.

questions.text: A patient suffering from Bronchial asthma comes to you in hospital. All of the following drugs are used in acute exacerbation; EXCEPT: (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Leukotriene antagonist

 

Leukotriene antagonists, such as montelukast, are typically used as long-term, controller medications in asthma and are not usually used in the acute setting. They work by blocking the effects of leukotrienes, which are substances in the body that cause inflammation and constriction of airways in asthma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nebulization by Salbutamol: Salbutamol, a short-acting β2 agonist (SABA), is commonly used in the acute management of asthma exacerbations. It works by relaxing bronchial smooth muscle, thereby relieving bronchospasm. Nebulization is an effective method of delivery during an acute asthma attack.

 

Option B. Oxygen Therapy: Oxygen therapy is crucial in the management of acute asthma exacerbations, especially if there is evidence of hypoxemia. Asthma exacerbations can lead to significant reductions in oxygenation, and supplemental oxygen is used to maintain adequate oxygen saturation.

 

Option C. IV Magnesium Sulphate: Intravenous magnesium sulphate is used as an adjunct therapy in severe asthma exacerbations, particularly when the response to initial treatment is inadequate. Magnesium has bronchodilating and anti-inflammatory effects, making it beneficial in severe cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leukotriene antagonists are not typically used in the acute management of asthma exacerbations but are instead used as long-term controller medications.

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Permeability of glucose across cell membrane
﻿﻿﻿Reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules

questions.text: Insulin stimulates the entry of glucose into cells by:(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Facilitated diffusion

 

Insulin stimulates the entry of glucose into cells via facilitated diffusion with the help of GLUT 4 transporter that’s why GLUT 4 is also known as insulin dependent glucose transporter.

 

It is present in skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle, and adipose tissues.

 

[Note- GLUT-2 Is known as glucose sensor]

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Permeability of glucose across cell membrane: Incorrect. Insulin does not directly increase the permeability of glucose across cell membranes but rather facilitates its entry through specific transporters.


Option C. Reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules: Incorrect. Reabsorption of glucose from renal tubules is not stimulated by insulin; it occurs via sodium-glucose linked transporters (SGLT), primarily SGLT2 in the kidneys.


Option D. Glucose reabsorption from intestine: Incorrect. Glucose reabsorption from the intestine involves SGLT1 and is not directly stimulated by insulin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of glucose transporter -

 

Secondary active transport – SGLT (sodium glucose link transport)

 

E.g.,

 

  • SGLT 1 PRESENT IN SMALL INTESTINE
  • SGLT 2 Mainly PRESENT IN KIDNEY

 

Facilitated diffusion - GLUT

 

E.g.,

 

  • GLUT1 – RBC, BLOOD BRAIN BARRIER, placenta
  • GLUT2 - Beta cells of pancreas
  • GLUT3 - Brain, placenta, kidneys

questions.text: Gram positive alpha hemolytic cocci with catalase negative and optochin resistant causing endocarditis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Streptococcus sanguis

 

Streptococcus sanguis is part of the Viridans group of streptococci. These bacteria are Gram-positive, alpha-hemolytic cocci that are catalase negative and optochin resistant. Viridans streptococci, including Streptococcus sanguis, are commonly found in the oral cavity and are known for their ability to cause endocarditis, particularly in individuals with preexisting heart conditions or damaged heart valves. They adhere to damaged heart valves and form biofilms, which are difficult for the immune system to clear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumonia: Alpha-hemolytic and catalase negative but is optochin sensitive and primarily causes pneumonia, otitis media, and meningitis rather than endocarditis.

 

Option B. Streptococcus agalactiae: Group B Streptococcus is beta-hemolytic, not alpha-hemolytic, and is a common cause of neonatal infections.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus epidermidis: A Gram-positive cocci that is catalase positive and coagulase negative. It is commonly associated with infections related to indwelling medical devices but not typically alpha-hemolytic or optochin resistant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Streptococcus sanguis, part of the Viridans group of streptococci, is a Gram-positive, alpha-hemolytic, catalase-negative, and optochin-resistant bacterium that is a common cause of endocarditis, particularly in individuals with preexisting heart conditions.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the OPD for a regular check-up. His growth chart shows his BMI between 85th and 95th percentile. Which of the following categories would you place him in? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Overweight

 

The child's BMI-for-age percentile falls between the 85th and 95th percentile, which corresponds to a BMI-for-age that is between >2 standard deviations (SD) and ≤3 SD above the median according to World Health Organization (WHO) growth standards. This range categorizes the child as overweight.

 

In pediatric practice, the BMI-for-age is a crucial measure used to assess nutritional status. When a child's BMI-for-age is between 85th and 95th percentile (or >2 SD and ≤3 SD), the child is considered overweight. This classification is important for early identification of children at risk of developing obesity and related health problems.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Severe acute malnutrition: This is defined by a BMI-for-age that is below -3 SD. Children with severe acute malnutrition present with significant weight loss and may exhibit symptoms like wasting, edema, and other signs of malnutrition. The child in this case does not meet these criteria.

 

Option B. Moderate wasting: Moderate wasting is characterized by a weight-for-height/length between -2 SD and -3 SD, indicating moderate acute malnutrition. This child’s BMI does not fall within this range, and there is no mention of weight loss or wasting.

 

Option D. Obese: Obesity is classified when a child’s BMI-for-age is above the 95th percentile (or >3 SD). The child in this case has a BMI-for-age between 85th and 95th percentile, so they do not meet the criteria for obesity.

 

Educational Objective:


A child with a BMI-for-age between 85th and 95th percentile (or >2 SD and ≤3 SD) is classified as overweight.

questions.text: The arterial blood gas findings of a patient are pH = 7.12, pCO2 = 50, HCO3 = 28. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation

 

The patient’s pH of 7.12 indicates acidosis. The elevated pCO2 (normal ~40 mmHg) suggests a primary respiratory cause. The slightly elevated HCO3 indicates a compensatory metabolic response. Thus, the primary disorder is respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation: Would show low HCO3 and low pCO2.

 

Option C. Respiratory alkalosis with metabolic compensation: Would show high pH and low pCO2.

 

Option D. Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory compensation: Would show high pH and high HCO3.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation is characterized by low pH, high pCO2, and a compensatory increase in HCO3.

questions.text: Which among the following is an ideal treatment for a 55-year-old with simple hyperplasia of endometrium with atypia? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Simple hysterectomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Simple hysterectomy is the best treatment in the above clinical scenario.
  • The best treatment for atypical hyperplasia in a post-menopausal woman is hysterectomy as the risk of malignancy is very high.

 

For Perimenopausal/Postmenopausal Women:

 

  • Hyperplasia with Atypia: Hysterectomy is recommended.
  • Hyperplasia without Atypia: Progestins may be considered, but hysterectomy is best as the age-risk is high.

 

For Young Patients with Hyperplasia:

 

  • Continuous or cyclic progesterone therapy may be tried with endometrial sampling every 6 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Medroxyprogesterone acetate: While progestins can be used to treat endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, in postmenopausal women, especially with atypia, a hysterectomy is the preferred treatment.

 

Option C. Levonorgestrel: Levonorgestrel is used in intrauterine devices for contraception and in some cases of hyperplasia without atypia, but is not the ideal treatment for postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy: Radiotherapy is not a standard treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. It is generally reserved for certain cases of endometrial carcinoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ideal treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia in a post-menopausal woman is a hysterectomy due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.

 

Ref: D. C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition page 331, Williams gynecology 3rd edition pg 706

questions.text: Ritodrine, which prevents premature labour, causes all of the following maternal complications, except: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoglycemia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Ritodrine is a beta-agonist used to prevent preterm labor by relaxing uterine muscles. It has several maternal side effects.
  • Maternal hyperglycemia is a known complication of ritodrine because it stimulates glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.
  • Maternal side effects include:
    • Headache, palpitations: Common side effects due to beta-agonist action.
    • Tachycardia and hypotension: These cardiovascular effects are due to beta-agonist properties.
    • Hyperglycemia: Caused by increased glucose production and decreased insulin sensitivity.
    • Hypocalcemia: Resulting from increased calcium excretion.
    • Hypomagnesemia: Due to increased renal excretion of magnesium.
    • Pulmonary edema: A serious complication caused by fluid retention and increased capillary permeability.
  • Neonatal side effects:
    • Hypoglycemia: Occurs due to high insulin levels in response to maternal hyperglycemia.
    • Intraventricular hemorrhage: Related to hemodynamic instability caused by tocolytic therapy.
  • Fetal side effects:
    • Tachycardia: Due to beta-agonist crossing the placenta.
    • Heart failure: Resulting from sustained tachycardia and cardiac workload.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tremors: A common side effect of beta-agonists due to stimulation of beta-2 receptors in skeletal muscle.

 

Option B. Tachycardia: A direct effect of beta-agonist therapy, increasing heart rate.

 

Option D. Pulmonary oedema: A serious and potentially life-threatening side effect of ritodrine due to fluid retention and increased capillary permeability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ritodrine, used to prevent preterm labor, causes maternal hyperglycemia, not hypoglycemia, and is associated with several side effects, including headache, palpitations, tachycardia, hypotension, hypocalcemia, hypomagnesemia, and pulmonary edema.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Page 583

questions.text: What is the most common side effect of Lamotrigine? (Fmge June 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Skin rash

 

  • The most common adverse effect of lamotrigine is a mild skin rash, which occurs in up to 10% of patients taking the medication. The rash usually appears within the first few weeks of treatment and is generally not serious. However, in rare cases, it can progress to a more severe form of skin reaction called Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis, which can be life-threatening.

  • It is important to note that the risk of developing a rash is higher in people who start on high doses of lamotrigine or who increase the dose too quickly, particularly if they have a history of rash with other antiepileptic drugs. Therefore, it is recommended that lamotrigine be started at a low dose and increased gradually over several weeks to reduce the risk of rash.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Weight Gain: Unlike some other medications used in the treatment of bipolar disorder and epilepsy, lamotrigine is generally not associated with significant weight gain. It is often chosen for its favorable weight profile.

 

Option B. Tremors: While tremors can be a side effect of some antiepileptic drugs, they are not typically associated with lamotrigine. Other medications, like valproate and lithium, are more commonly linked to this side effect.

 

Option C. Neutropenia: Neutropenia, a decrease in neutrophil count, is a potential side effect of many medications but is not commonly associated with lamotrigine use.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common side effect of lamotrigine is a mild skin rash, which occurs in up to 10% of patients. Although usually not serious, the rash can occasionally progress to severe reactions like Stevens-Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis. Therefore, lamotrigine should be started at a low dose and increased gradually to minimize this risk.

questions.text: Which among the following aids in supination and pronation of the forearm? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Pivot joint

 

Explanation

 

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

 

 

The forearm has two pivot joints: the proximal radioulnar joint and the distal radioulnar joint.

 

  • The proximal radioulnar joint - located near the elbow and allows for rotation of the radius around the ulna. This joint is responsible for supination (rotating the palm up) and pronation (rotating the palm down) of the forearm. The joint consists of the head of the radius, which rotates within the annular ligament and the radial notch of the ulna.
  • The distal radioulnar joint - located near the wrist and also allows for rotation of the radius around the ulna. This joint is responsible for rotation of the hand, and works in conjunction with the proximal radioulnar joint to allow for fine motor movements of the hand and wrist. The joint consists of the ulnar notch of the radius, which rotates within the ulnar head and the triangular fibrocartilage complex.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Saddle joint: Saddle joints, like the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb, allow for a wide range of motion, including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and opposition. However, they are not primarily responsible for supination and pronation of the forearm.

 

Option C. Ellipsoid joint (Condyloid joint): Ellipsoid joints, such as the wrist joint (radiocarpal joint), allow for flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and circumduction, but they are not the primary joints involved in forearm supination and pronation

 

Option D. Ball and socket joint: Ball and socket joints, like the shoulder and hip joints, permit a wide range of motion, including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, rotation, and circumduction. While they allow rotation, they are not the primary joints responsible for the specific rotational movements of forearm supination and pronation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pivot joint (also known as the trochoid joint) is the type of joint found between the radius and ulna bones of the forearm. This joint allows for rotational movements, specifically supination and pronation of the forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best drug for treatment of tobacco addiction?(FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Varenicline

 

Varenicline is a partial agonist of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor and is specifically designed for smoking cessation. It has been found to be more effective than bupropion (D) and nicotine replacement therapies in helping individuals quit smoking.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option D. Bupropion: Bupropion is an atypical antidepressant that can also help with smoking cessation, but it is generally considered to be less effective than varenicline.

 

Option B. Naloxone: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to reverse opioid overdose and is not used for tobacco addiction.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist used in alcohol dependence and opioid dependence, but it is not first-line for tobacco addiction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Varenicline is an anti-smoking agent that works by reducing the craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with tobacco use. It is a partial agonist at alpha4 beta2 nicotinic acetylcholine receptors. It is started a week before the quit date.

 

Reference: The Maudsley Prescribing Guidelines in Psychiatry, 14th edition, Page No 505.

questions.text: Pre-conceptional use of ____ leads to reduced incidence of neural tube defects: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Folic acid

 

Explanation:

 

  • Folic acid used in the pre-conceptional period significantly reduces the incidence of neural tube defects (NTDs) such as spina bifida, encephalocele, and anencephaly.
  • Folic acid is the commonly used active form of vitamin B9.
  • Folic acid deficiency is directly implicated in the occurrence of these defects.
  • The recommended pre-conceptional dosage of folic acid is 0.4 mg/day (400 mcg/day) for low-risk women. For those at high risk of NTDs, the recommended dosage is 4 mg/day.
  • High-risk factors for NTDs include:
    • History of a previous baby with NTD
    • Pre-gestational Diabetes Mellitus
    • Folic acid deficiency
    • Obesity
    • Epilepsy or use of Antiepileptic Drugs (AED)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Iron: Iron supplementation needed in pregnancy is 60-100 mg per day. While important for preventing anemia, it does not specifically reduce the incidence of neural tube defects.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium supplementation needed in pregnancy is around 1000 mg per day, important for maternal and fetal bone health but not linked to reducing NTDs.

 

Option D. Vitamin A: The recommended daily allowance of vitamin A in pregnancy is 6000 IU/day. However, excessive intake can be teratogenic and it is not specifically used for preventing NTDs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-conceptional folic acid supplementation at a dosage of 0.4 mg/day (400 mcg/day) is essential to reduce the incidence of neural tube defects.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition Page 117

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman visits the infertility clinic with complaints of recurrent abortions. On investigations, she is found to have a septate uterus. Which of the following corrective procedures has the best obstetric outcome? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Transcervical resection of septum

 

Explanation:

 

  • Septate uterus is the most common Mullerian anomaly.
  • It is associated with infertility, abortions, preterm labor, fetal growth restriction (FGR), and malpresentations.
  • Transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum has the best obstetric outcome.
  • Hysteroscopic resection prevents any laparotomy scar and is thus associated with better future obstetric outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jones metroplasty: Jones & Jones's metroplasty involves wedge-shaped fundal resection for a partial septate uterus.

 

Option B. Strassmann metroplasty: This is the surgical unification of a bicornuate uterus by excision of the septum.

 

Option C. Tompkins metroplasty: Modified Jones procedure where an incision is made on the posterior surface of the uterus over the septum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The best corrective procedure for a septate uterus with recurrent abortions, which has the best obstetric outcome, is the transcervical hysteroscopic resection of the septum.

 

Ref: Dutta textbook of Gynecology 3rd edition pg 47

questions.text: A 38-year-old public health officer is deployed to a rural area where there is increasing concern regarding the consumption of Khesari dal by the local community for the past year. In a meeting with the local healthcare team, various preventive measures are discussed to counteract the potential outbreak of lathyrism associated with Khesari dal. Which of the following interventions is NOT recommended in this context? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. DEC

 

Lathyrism is a neurological disease caused by consuming the pulse Khesari dal (Lathyrus sativus), which contains the toxin beta-oxalyl-amino-alanine (BOAA). Preventive measures to counteract lathyrism focus on removing the toxin, banning the crop, using Vitamin C as a prophylactic measure, and other strategies. Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) is not related to the prevention of lathyrism and is primarily used in the treatment of filariasis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toxin Removal: Steeping and parboiling methods are recommended to remove the toxin from Khesari dal.

 

Option B. Crop Ban: Banning the cultivation of Khesari dal is a recommended intervention to prevent lathyrism.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Vitamin C is used as a prophylactic measure to prevent lathyrism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lathyrism

 

  • Lathyrism is of two types:
    • Neurolathyrism: in human beings
    • Osteolathyrism (odoratism): In animals 
  • Neurolathyrism is caused by eating the pulse ‘khesari dal (lathyrus sativus)’. Diets containing over 30% of this dal   consumed over a period of 2-6 months result in neurolathyrism
  • Lathyrism affects 15-45 years of age
  • Toxin: present in lathyrus seed is ‘beta oxalyl amino alanine (BOAA)
  • It manifests as following stages:
    • Latent stage
    • No-stick stage
    • One-stick stage
    • Two-stick stage
    • Crawler stage
  • Interventions for prevention and control of lathyrism:
    • Vitamin C prophylaxis
    • Banning the crop
    • Removal of toxin: steeping method and parboiling
    • Education
    • Genetic approach
    • Socio-economic changes

choices.text: NPO (nil per oral) 8 hours before surgery
No need for NPO in an elective Laparoscopic surgery

questions.text: What are the fasting guidelines given to a patient posted for laparoscopic surgery? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NPO (nil per oral) 8 hours before surgery

 

Explanation:

 

Fasting before surgery is crucial to reduce the risk of aspiration and related complications during anesthesia. The guidelines vary based on the type of food and drink consumed.

 

Fasting Guidelines for Surgery:

  • Clear Fluids: 2 hours
  • Light Solid Food: 6 hours
  • Heavy Meal including fried or fatty foods: 8 hours

For Neonates:

  • Breast Milk: 4 hours
  • Formula Milk: 6 hours

 

For a laparoscopic surgery, which is typically an elective procedure, it is recommended that the patient adheres to a fasting period of 8 hours for heavy meals. This ensures that the stomach is empty, thereby minimizing the risk of aspiration during the procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. NPO 48 hours before surgery: This is excessively long and unnecessary.

 

Option C. NPO 3 hours before surgery: This is too short for solid foods and does not align with standard guidelines.

 

Option D. No need for NPO in an elective laparoscopic surgery: This is incorrect as fasting is essential for all types of surgeries requiring anesthesia to prevent aspiration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients scheduled for elective laparoscopic surgery should follow fasting guidelines to reduce the risk of aspiration during anesthesia. The standard recommendation is NPO (nil per oral) for 8 hours before surgery if they have had a heavy meal.

 

Fasting guidelines for surgery:

 

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 990

questions.text: A child presented with bilious vomiting. What will be the most appropriate test to diagnose the condition in this baby? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CECT abdomen

 

Bilious vomiting in a child suggests an obstruction distal to the second part of the duodenum. The appropriate diagnostic test should provide a comprehensive view of the entire abdominal region to pinpoint the site of obstruction or other causes.

 

CECT abdomen (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography of the abdomen):

 

  • Relevance: A CECT abdomen provides a detailed study of the entire abdominal region, helping to pinpoint the site of obstruction or other causes of bilious vomiting. It offers a comprehensive view of both the gastrointestinal tract and surrounding structures, making it the most appropriate test in this scenario.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Barium swallow:

 

  • Description: A barium swallow is used to evaluate the structure of the esophagus by having the patient swallow a barium sulfate drink and then taking X-ray images.
  • Relevance: This test is appropriate for assessing abnormalities in the esophagus such as strictures or tumors but is not typically used for diagnosing conditions that result in bilious vomiting in children.

 

Option B. Barium meal:

 

  • Description: A barium meal evaluates the structure and function of the stomach and the proximal part of the small intestine.
  • Relevance: While it can visualize the stomach and the beginning of the small intestine, it might not provide a full picture of a distal obstruction or other causes of bilious vomiting.

 

Option C. Barium meal follow through:

 

  • Description: This test involves swallowing barium sulfate and then taking X-ray images at intervals as the barium moves through the entire small intestine.
  • Relevance: It allows visualization of the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum. This would be more comprehensive than a simple barium meal for identifying sites of obstruction or other abnormalities in the small intestine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For diagnosing bilious vomiting in a child, a CECT abdomen is the most appropriate test as it provides a comprehensive view of the entire abdominal region, helping to pinpoint the site of obstruction or other causes.

questions.text: A newborn is brought to the OPD with a large mass in the lower back. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Meningocele

 

  • The MRI image shows a T2 hyperintense mass (s/o fluid) herniating from the spine and represents a meningocele.
  • A fluctuant midline mass with transillumination positive is suggestive of meningocele.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Meningomyelocele involves the protrusion of the spinal cord with the meningeal covering.

 

Option C. Spina bifida occulta will have unfused posterior arch with no associated mass.

 

Option D. A bone cyst would be within the vertebra without associated mass.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meningocele is indicated by a T2 hyperintense mass on MRI showing fluid herniation from the spine and presents as a fluctuant midline mass with positive transillumination.

choices.text: Adenocarcinoma lungs
Squamous cell carcinoma
Small cell carcinoma
Large cell carcinoma

questions.text: What is the most common lung cancer in India? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Adenocarcinoma lungs

 

  • Adenocarcinoma of the lungs: This is the most common type of lung cancer in India and many other parts of the world. It originates in the peripheral lung tissue and is often associated with non-smokers and women. Adenocarcinoma is known for its glandular formation and mucin production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Squamous cell carcinoma: Typically associated with smoking and tends to occur centrally in the larger bronchi. It was once the most common type but has been surpassed by adenocarcinoma.

 

Option C. Small cell carcinoma: Highly malignant, associated with smoking, and tends to present with extensive disease due to its rapid growth and early metastasis.

 

Option D. Large cell carcinoma: A less common type of lung cancer that is often diagnosed when other specific types are ruled out.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenocarcinoma is currently the most common type of lung cancer in India, often linked to non-smokers and peripheral lung origin.

choices.text: Increased cyclin D and CDK4
Increased cyclin E and CDK2
Increased cyclin A and CDK2
Increased cyclin K and CDK1

questions.text: Which of the following is required for the transition of the cell from G1 to M phase? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Increased cyclin D and CDK4

 

Increased cyclin D and CDK4 are important for transition of cell from G1 to M phase.

 

  1. The cell enters the G1 phase after completing the previous M phase (mitosis).
  2. In the early G1 phase, the levels of cyclin D increase.
  3. Cyclin D binds to CDK4, forming the cyclin D-CDK4 complex.
  4. The cyclin D-CDK4 complex phosphorylates target proteins, leading to the activation of transcription factors.
  5. The activated transcription factors promote the expression of genes required for DNA replication.
  6. As a result, the cell progresses from the G1 phase to the S phase, where DNA synthesis occurs.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased cyclin E and CDK2: Involved in the transition from G1 to S phase.

 

Option C. Increased cyclin A and CDK2: Involved in the transition from S phase to G2 phase.

 

Option D. Increased cyclin K and CDK1: Not typically associated with a specific phase transition in the cell cycle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased levels of cyclin D and CDK4 are essential for the transition of the cell from the G1 phase to the M phase, facilitating DNA replication and cell division.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 12-year-old child who presents with lower abdominal pain, rashes over lower extremities, and pain in joints? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Henoch Schönlein purpura

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a small vessel vasculitis that commonly affects children. It is characterized by:

 

  • Skin purpura: Typically, on the lower extremities, with platelets being normal.
  • Joints: Arthralgia or arthritis.
  • Kidneys: IgA deposition leading to renal involvement, such as hematuria or nephritis.
  • Abdomen: Abdominal pain due to gastrointestinal involvement.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alport syndrome: A genetic disorder affecting the basement membrane of the kidneys, ears, and eyes, leading to progressive renal failure, hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities.

 

Option C. Takayasu arteritis: A large vessel vasculitis primarily affecting the aorta and its branches, more common in young women.

 

Option D. Temporal arteritis: Also known as giant cell arteritis, it typically affects older adults and involves inflammation of the temporal arteries, leading to headaches, jaw claudication, and vision problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Henoch-Schönlein purpura is a small vessel vasculitis in children characterized by lower extremity purpura, joint pain, abdominal pain, and renal involvement.

questions.text: Which of the following Dural venous sinuses receives the great cerebral vein of Galen as its tributary? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B

 

The venous sinus marked with 'B' in the given image is the straight sinus. The great cerebral vein of Galen drains into the straight sinus.

 

The straight sinus is positioned at the junction between the falx cerebri and the tentorium cerebelli, near the confluence of sinuses. It receives blood from several veins, including the inferior sagittal sinus and the great cerebral vein of Galen. The straight sinus also drains into the confluence of sinuses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. superior sagittal sinus - This dural venous sinus is located along the midline of the brain's superior surface, within the superior border of the falx cerebri. It receives blood from the cerebral veins and drains into the confluence of sinuses (torcular herophili).

 

Option C.  superior petrosal sinus - The superior petrosal sinus is not mentioned in the options you've provided, but it is located within the petrous part of the temporal bone. It plays a role in draining blood from the cavernous sinus and superior ophthalmic vein, ultimately leading to the transverse sinus.

 

Option D.  transverse sinus - The transverse sinuses are found within the tentorium cerebelli and run horizontally. They receive blood from the straight sinus and superior petrosal sinus. These sinuses then continue into the sigmoid sinuses as they exit the posterior cranial fossa.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The vertebral level marked as 2 is in which abdominal plane? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Upper border of L3

 

Explanation

 

The structure marked 2 in the given image is the subcostal plane. It is at the level of the upper border of the third lumbar vertebra (L3).

 

 

From the diagram shown in question the structure marked are as follows:

 

Mark 1 – The plane passing through the upper border of L2 vertebrae

Mark 2 – The plane passing through the upper border of L3 vertebrae

Mark 3 – The plane marked is intertubercular plane , at the level of L5 vertebrae

Mark 4 – The plane passing through the Midclavicular point.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The subcostal plane, significant for dividing abdominal regions, is located at the upper border of the L3 vertebra.

questions.text: Identify the fistula labelled below: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Vesico-vaginal fistula

 

Explanation:

 

  • The fistula shown in the image is a vesico-vaginal fistula. It is a pathological connection between the bladder and the vagina.
  • Vesico-vaginal fistulas typically present with continuous leakage of urine from the vagina.
  • Causes can include obstetric trauma, surgical injury, radiation therapy, or malignancy.
  • Diagnosis is usually confirmed through clinical examination, dye tests, cystoscopy, and imaging studies.
  • Management often involves surgical repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vesico-cervical fistula: This is a fistula connecting the bladder and the cervix. It is less common and would present differently.

 

Option B. Urethro-vaginal fistula: This is a fistula connecting the urethra and the vagina. It results in urine leakage that increases with physical activity or position changes.

 

Option C. Uretero-vaginal fistula: This is a fistula connecting the ureter and the vagina, often resulting in continuous leakage of urine due to the passage of urine directly from the ureter to the vagina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A vesico-vaginal fistula is a pathological connection between the bladder and the vagina, leading to continuous leakage of urine from the vagina.

 

Ref: Dutta’s text of Gynecology 6th edition Page 417

questions.text: A patient has undergone cholecystectomy few days back and now the patient has presented with upper Abdominal pain. MRCP was done which showed leak of bile from the cystic duct stump. Pt is hemodynamically stable which of the following should be the next line of management? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ERCP and stenting

 

The correct option is Option B. ERCP (Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) and stenting

 

ERCP is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure used primarily to diagnose and treat conditions of the bile and pancreatic ducts. In the context of a known bile leak, as revealed by the MRCP, ERCP can be employed both to visualize the site of the leak and to deploy a stent. This stent can bridge the gap where the leak is, allowing the bile to flow normally into the intestine and simultaneously giving the leaky site a chance to heal. This makes it a less invasive option than surgical intervention for managing bile leaks.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): This is a diagnostic imaging tool. A CECT provides detailed imaging of internal structures and can help in diagnosing a variety of conditions. However, in the context of the given scenario where the patient has had an MRCP that already shows a bile leak, a further CECT might not provide additional useful information for direct management.

 

Option C. Exploratory laparotomy: While it can be used to directly visualize and repair a bile leak, it's a major surgical procedure with potential complications. It's generally considered when other less invasive options are not viable or have failed.

 

Option D. Conservative treatment with antibiotics: While antibiotics can help to prevent or treat infections, they won't directly address a bile leak. Hence, relying solely on antibiotics wouldn't solve the main problem. However, antibiotics might be used in conjunction with other treatments if there's a concern about bile-related infection or sepsis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a hemodynamically stable patient with a bile leak post-cholecystectomy, as shown by MRCP, the next line of management is ERCP and stenting to bridge the leak and allow healing.

choices.text: Sideroblastic anemia
Anemia of chronic disease
Chronic liver disease

questions.text: Macrocytic anemia seen is in which of the following condition? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chronic liver disease

 

Macrocytic anemia is characterized by larger than normal red blood cells (>9 microns)/ (>100 fL).

 

It can occur in various conditions, including:

 

  • Megaloblastic anemia: Caused by deficiencies in vitamin B12 or folate.
  • Liver disease: Chronic liver disease can lead to macrocytic anemia due to alterations in lipid metabolism affecting the red blood cell membrane.
  • Hypothyroidism: Can also result in macrocytic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sideroblastic anemia: Typically presents with microcytic anemia.

 

Option B. Anemia of chronic disease: Usually presents with normocytic or microcytic anemia.

 

Option C. Thalassemia: Characterized by microcytic anemia due to defects in hemoglobin production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrocytic anemia can occur in chronic liver disease due to changes in red blood cell morphology, along with other conditions like megaloblastic anemia and hypothyroidism.

questions.text: Which phase of the menstrual cycle features vacuolation as a histological feature? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secretory phase

 

Explanation:

 

  • Secretory phase: Subnuclear vacuolation is a histological feature of the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle. In this phase, the endometrial glands increase in size, become tortuous and corkscrew-shaped, and exhibit subnuclear vacuolation in the columnar epithelial cells. There is marked spiraling of blood vessels, and stromal cells become swollen and polyhedral. The endometrial thickness reaches 6-8 mm due to the changes brought about by progesterone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Proliferative phase: The proliferative phase extends from the 5th-6th day to the 14th day till ovulation. The epithelium becomes columnar, stromal cells become spindle-shaped, and glands become tubular and perpendicular to the surface. However, vacuolation is not a characteristic histological feature of this phase.

 

Option C. Menstrual phase: The menstrual phase is characterized by the shedding of the endometrium due to the fall in estrogen and progesterone levels following the regression of the corpus luteum. It does not feature vacuolation as a histological characteristic.

 

  • Endometrial cycle phases:
    1. Regenerative phase: Begins even before menstruation stops and is completed 2-3 days after the end of menses. Glands and stroma are regenerated from the remnants in the basal zone.
    2. Proliferative phase: Extends from the 5th-6th day to the 14th day till ovulation. The epithelium becomes columnar, and stromal cells become spindle-shaped. Glands become tubular and perpendicular to the surface.
    3. Secretory phase: Characterized by changes due to progesterone, including glandular enlargement, tortuosity, corkscrew shape, and subnuclear vacuolation. The stromal cells become swollen and polyhedral, and the endometrial thickness reaches 6-8 mm.
    4. Menstrual phase: Involves the shedding of the endometrium due to decreased estrogen and progesterone levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Subnuclear vacuolation is a histological feature of the secretory phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Ref: D. C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition page 91

questions.text: A 35-year-old man visited the clinic, reporting intermittent episodes of vertigo, a feeling of pressure and fullness in the ear, reduced hearing, and a low-tone roaring tinnitus. What potential clinical condition could be considered as a diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Meniere’s disease

 

The most likely conclusion points to Meniere's disease, alternatively referred to as endolymphatic hydrops.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV): Characterized by brief episodes of vertigo related to changes in head position. It does not typically involve hearing loss or tinnitus.

 

Option C. Labyrinthitis: Involves continuous, not episodic vertigo that usually lasts for days and is accompanied by more pervasive auditory and balance disturbances.

 

Option D. Syncope: Refers to a sudden loss of consciousness and posture, generally caused by a decrease in blood flow to the brain, not typically associated with auditory symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Meniere’s disease is a complex inner ear disorder that requires careful management to control symptoms and prevent progression. Treatment strategies focus on relieving the symptoms and, in severe cases, may involve surgical interventions to reduce the endolymphatic pressure or decompress the endolymphatic sac. Patients benefit from a multi-disciplinary approach involving audiologists, otolaryngologists, and sometimes neurologists.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman with a history of type 1 DM is brought to the ER with confusion, vomiting, and abdominal pain. Investigations show blood glucose – 520 mg/dl and urine tests positive for ketone bodies. A diagnosis of DKA is made. Which of the following is the drug of choice for the management of hyperglycemia? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Regular insulin

 

In diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), the drug of choice for managing hyperglycemia is intravenous regular insulin, which helps lower blood glucose levels rapidly.

 

  • Treatment Approach: Both DKA and HHS (hyperglycemic state) are treated with intravenous insulin as a critical component of their management.
  • Type of Insulin: The gold standard for IV administration in these cases is regular insulin, specifically noted as recombinant human insulin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lente insulin: Intermediate-acting, not suitable for acute management.

 

Option C. Glyburide: Oral hypoglycemic agent, not used in DKA.

 

Option D. 70/30 insulin: Combination insulin, not used for immediate control.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regular insulin is the preferred treatment for hyperglycemia in DKA.

questions.text: A 60-year-old individual with diabetes presented with intense ear pain and otorrhea that did not improve with antibiotics. During the examination, granulation tissue was observed in the external auditory canal (EAC), and the person also exhibited facial nerve palsy. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Malignant otitis externa

 

Severe otalgia in an elderly diabetic patient with granulation tissue in the external ear canal points to a diagnosis of Malignant (Necrotizing) otitis externa.

 

ETIOLOGY – More common in elderly, diabetic and immunocompromised patients.

 

CAUSATIVE ORGANISM - Pseudomonas aeruginosa (most common), Staphylococcus aureus, Proteus species, and fungi.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES

 

  • Excruciating ear pain
  • Granulations in the ear canal
  • Facial paralysis is common.
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple lower cranial nerve palsies
  • Anteriorly, infection spreads to temporomandibular fossa
  • Posteriorly to the mastoid and medially into the middle ear and petrous bone.

 

DIAGNOSIS

 

  • Gallium-67 is more useful in diagnosis and follow-up of the patient. It is taken up by monocytes and reticuloendothelial cells, and is indicative of soft tissue infection. It can be repeated every 3 weeks to monitor the disease and response to treatment.          
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection but test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease.

 

TREATMENT

 

  • Control of diabetes
  • Aural toilet
  • Antibiotic treatment against causative organism, which in most commonly P. aeruginosa (or any other causative organism) for 6-8 weeks.
  • Antibiotics commonly used are anti-pseudomonal antibiotics ; Third-generation cephalosporins ; Ciprofloxacin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otomycosis: Typically presents with itching and a fungal ear discharge, without the severe pain or systemic complications seen in MOE.

 

Option B. Serous otitis media: Involves fluid accumulation in the middle ear, generally without the severe external ear pain or granulation tissue.

 

Option D. Eczematous otitis externa: Characterized by itching and skin changes, but not the deep infection or severe complications associated with MOE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant otitis externa is a critical condition requiring aggressive management due to its potential to cause widespread damage and severe complications, including cranial nerve involvement. Prompt and appropriate treatment is essential to prevent potentially life-threatening outcomes.

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 55

questions.text: Split skin graft is composed of? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Epidermis & partial dermis

 

A split-thickness skin graft (STSG) includes both the epidermis and a portion of the dermis. The dermis is the thick layer of living tissue below the epidermis that forms the true skin, containing blood capillaries, nerve endings, sweat glands, hair follicles, and other structures.

 

Partial/split Thickness Skin Grafting:

 

  • Composition: Epidermis + superficial dermis.
  • Common Donor Site: Thigh (anteromedial or anterolateral aspect).

 

Full Thickness Skin Grafting:

 

  • Composition: Epidermis + complete dermis.
  • Common Donor Site: Supraclavicular area.

 

The key difference between split-thickness and full-thickness skin grafts lies in the amount of dermis included. Split-thickness grafts are easier to take and more likely to survive because they can obtain nourishment from the underlying tissue more easily. Full-thickness grafts, which include all of the dermis, provide a more durable and aesthetically pleasing result but are more challenging to manage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Only epidermis: This option is incorrect as split-thickness skin grafts include both the epidermis and part of the dermis, not just the epidermis.

 

Option C. Epidermis & deep dermis: While this option is closer, it inaccurately describes the composition of a full-thickness skin graft rather than a split-thickness skin graft.

 

Option D. Epidermis, dermis, subcutaneous fat: This describes a composite graft, not a split-thickness skin graft. Split-thickness grafts do not include the subcutaneous fat.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A split-thickness skin graft includes both the epidermis and part of the dermis, commonly harvested from the thigh.

 

 

 

Humby’s Knife (for harvesting partial thickness graft)

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclera but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection 10 days ago which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back when the patient had long hours of basketball practice. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin is 2.1 mg/dL, and conjugated bilirubin is 0.3 mg/dL. Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gilbert syndrome

 

Gilbert syndrome is a common, benign condition characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. It often presents during times of stress, such as illness or strenuous exercise. Normal liver enzyme levels (AST and ALT) and the presence of predominantly unconjugated bilirubin support this diagnosis.

 

Note - Gilbert syndrome is often discovered incidentally during routine tests. Because bilirubin levels in Gilbert syndrome do not exceed 3 milligrams per decilitre. The condition involves a mild deficiency of the UDP-glucuronyl transferase enzyme, specifically UGT1A1, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin in the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson syndrome: Causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Option B. Crigler-Najjar type 1 syndrome: Causes severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia from birth due to complete deficiency of the UGT1A1 enzyme, often leading to kernicterus. Highly fatal disease.

 

Option D. Rotor syndrome: Similar to Dubin-Johnson but without liver pigmentation, causes conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gilbert syndrome presents with mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, often triggered by stress, fasting, or illness, and normal liver enzyme levels.

questions.text: A patient suffered from an injury to right lower limb 3 days ago following which he was brought to hospital. The injury is as shown in the image. What would be the likely treatment in this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Debridement & hyperbaric oxygen

 

The given image shows gangrenous patches of the skin spread throughout the lower limb, with patchy erythema, likely indicative of necrotizing fasciitis. Extensive debridement with hyperbaric oxygen to hasten healing is recommended. Primary closure should not be done in the presence of necrotic tissue.

 

Debridement & hyperbaric oxygen:

 

  • Hyperbaric oxygen therapy: Increases the oxygen concentration in the blood, which can help wounds heal more quickly and fight certain types of infections.
  • Suitability: For necrotizing fasciitis, prompt and aggressive debridement is crucial. After debridement, hyperbaric oxygen can be beneficial. It can suppress the growth of anaerobic bacteria, enhance white blood cell function, and improve tissue oxygenation – all of which are beneficial in treating necrotizing fasciitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Debridement & rotational advancement flap:

 

  • Debridement: Involves removing dead, damaged, or infected tissue to facilitate healing.
  • Rotational advancement flap: Involves moving nearby healthy skin and tissue to cover a wound.
  • Suitability: While debridement is crucial for necrotizing fasciitis, a rotational flap might not be the best immediate solution, especially if there's extensive tissue damage or ongoing infection. The primary focus should be on controlling the infection.

 

Option B. Debridement & primary closure:

 

  • Primary closure: Means directly suturing or closing the wound after debridement.
  • Suitability: In the case of necrotizing fasciitis, primary closure is not recommended initially. It's essential to ensure that all necrotic tissue is removed and the infection is under control before thinking about wound closure. Closing a wound with any lingering infection can lead to the infection being trapped and can worsen the patient's condition.

 

Option D. Amputation:

 

  • Amputation: Involves surgically removing a body part, typically an extremity.
  • Suitability: In some severe cases of necrotizing fasciitis, especially if the infection has rapidly progressed and threatens the patient's life, amputation might be a consideration. However, it's a last-resort treatment and would be considered only if other treatments fail and the limb is non-salvageable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For necrotizing fasciitis, the initial treatment should include extensive debridement and hyperbaric oxygen therapy to control the infection and promote healing.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man on urine examination shows Bence jones proteins. On x-ray, multiple lytic lesions are seen. Which of the following is most expected in his urine? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kappa light chain

 

The presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine is indicative of multiple myeloma. Bence Jones proteins are free light chains of immunoglobulins, which can be classified as either kappa or lambda light chains. In the case of light chain myeloma, these light chains are overproduced by the cancerous plasma cells and can be detected in the urine.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Light Chain Myeloma: It can be classified as either kappa or lambda light chain myeloma, depending on the type of light chains produced by the malignant cells.
  • X-ray Findings: Multiple lytic lesions are characteristic of multiple myeloma and indicate bone destruction caused by the proliferation of abnormal plasma cells.

 

Other 3 options: are not type of immunoglobulin light chain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Bence Jones proteins in the urine, specifically kappa light chains, is indicative of multiple myeloma, especially when associated with multiple lytic lesions on x-ray.

questions.text: A 28-year-old epidemiologist is tasked with visually representing the current outbreak of diarrhea in a district. She wants to showcase the trends and fluctuations of the cases over a period of time to the local health authorities. Which type of graphical representation would be the most appropriate for her to use in order to display these temporal trends effectively? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Line chart

 

Line chart or graph is a frequency polygon presenting variations by time.

 

 

It shows the trend of an event over a period of time. Like diarrhea cases in an epidemic area over a period of given time.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bar Diagram: it is for visual comparison of magnitude of different frequencies in a data.

 

 

Option C. Pie Diagram: it is for presentation of discrete data of qualitative characteristics.

 

 

Option D. Spot Map: is prepared to show geographical distribution of frequencies of characteristic.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For displaying temporal trends and fluctuations of disease cases over time, a line chart is the most effective and appropriate graphical representation.

choices.text: Aspirin loading dose should be commenced immediately
Glycoprotein IIB/IIIA inhibitors are useful adjuncts
Fibrinolytic therapy is useful in acute coronary syndrome without ST elevation

questions.text: Identify the false statement regarding the management of NSTEMI. (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fibrinolytic therapy is useful in acute coronary syndrome without ST elevation

 

Fibrinolytic therapy is NOT recommended for NSTEMI (non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction) as it is only indicated for STEMI (ST-elevation myocardial infarction). The other statements are correct and reflect current guidelines for NSTEMI management.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin: Should be given immediately.

 

Option B. P2Y12 inhibitors: Such as clopidogrel, are added to aspirin for dual antiplatelet therapy.

 

Option C. Glycoprotein IIB/IIIA inhibitors: May be used as adjuncts in certain cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fibrinolytic therapy is not used for NSTEMI.

questions.text: A patient gets a surgical removal of foreign body from stomach. The foreign body is shown in the below given image. Whom should this patient be referred to? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Psychiatrist

 

The picture given above is of a trichobezoar, a mass composed of ingested hair, often associated with trichotillomania (compulsive hair pulling) and trichophagia (compulsive eating of hair). These conditions are psychiatric disorders that require proper mental health management. After the surgical removal of the trichobezoar, it is crucial to address the underlying behavioral issue to prevent recurrence. Therefore, referral to a psychiatrist is essential to manage and treat the underlying compulsion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pediatrician: While a pediatrician may be involved if the patient is a child, the primary issue in this case is a psychiatric disorder requiring specialized mental health treatment.

 

Option C. Cardiologist: A cardiologist specializes in heart-related conditions and is not relevant to the treatment of trichobezoars or underlying psychiatric conditions.

 

Option D. Dermatologist: Although dermatologists treat skin and hair conditions, the compulsive behavior leading to trichobezoar formation is psychiatric in nature, requiring intervention from a mental health professional rather than a dermatologist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After the surgical removal of a trichobezoar, patients should be referred to a psychiatrist to address underlying psychiatric conditions like trichotillomania and trichophagia to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: A known hypertensive patient is brought to the ER with palpitations and breathlessness. On examination, his BP was 220/140 with signs of encephalopathy. Which of the following is used as a 1st line drug? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Nicardipine

 

In hypertensive emergencies, particularly with signs of encephalopathy, IV Nicardipine, a calcium channel blocker, is often used due to its effectiveness in quickly lowering blood pressure.

 

Alternative T/t – IV Labetalol

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Phentolamine: Used for pheochromocytoma.

 

Option C. Mannitol: Used for cerebral edema.

 

Option D. Prazosin: An alpha-blocker used for hypertension but not first-line in emergencies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nicardipine is the first-line drug for hypertensive emergencies with encephalopathy.

questions.text: The patient exhibited surgical emphysema following an urgent tracheostomy. What is the probable cause behind this occurrence? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tear in posterior tracheal wall

 

Subcutaneous emphysema is a relatively uncommon complication that can arise from a tracheostomy procedure. However, it poses a significant threat to the patient's well-being, as it can lead to severe morbidity and even mortality, particularly if it advances to pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum. This condition occurs when the tissues surrounding the tracheostomy tube are tightly sealed or when there are tears in the posterior tracheal wall.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. High Tracheostomy: While a high tracheostomy can cause other complications (like damage to the laryngeal nerves or cricoid cartilage), it is less likely to cause surgical emphysema unless associated with a tear or improper technique.

 

Option C. Block in Tracheostomy Tube: A blocked tracheostomy tube typically leads to respiratory distress from inadequate ventilation, rather than surgical emphysema.

 

Option D. Pulmonary Oedema: Pulmonary oedema involves fluid accumulation in the lungs and does not cause surgical emphysema. It presents with different symptoms such as difficulty breathing, coughing up pink frothy sputum, and increased work of breathing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Surgical emphysema following tracheostomy is a serious complication, often due to a tear in the posterior tracheal wall. This condition requires immediate attention to manage the airway, assess the extent of air spread, and prevent further complications. Effective management includes careful monitoring, possibly surgical repair of the tear, and measures to control the air leakage and its sequelae.

questions.text: Artificial bruise and true bruise can be differentiated by which of the following appearance? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Presence of vesicles

 

Artificial bruise is caused by irritant plants (Semi carpus Anacardium (marking nut), Calotropis, and plumbago). Since it is produced by irritant plant hence, vesicles and itching are unique features of artificial bruise.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Color changes: The typical color changes occur in true bruise, not in artificial bruise

 

Option C. Diffuse margins: The margins are diffuse in true bruise as the blood extravasates gradually in nearby areas.

 

Option D. Swelling: The swelling can be seen in both artificial bruise (due to inflammation), as well as true bruise (due to blood accumulation and inflammation). 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In a tertiary care hospital, health professionals gather to observe WHO Day. An event features 4-8 experts seated in front of an audience. The Director starts with a welcome and introduction, then invites speakers to share their perspectives without a set order or structured presentation. Audience participation is encouraged at the end. How would you categorize this mode of interaction? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Panel discussion

 

Panel discussion takes place between experts on a common topic. There is no structure/order and it takes place in front of an audience.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Symposium: There is no discussion between experts, there are lectures set in series in front of an audience.

 

Option C. Workshop: Involves hands on training in order to attain skills.

 

Option D. Seminars: Take place on a specific topic/theme for 6-8 hours/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A panel discussion is characterized by unstructured, spontaneous interaction among experts in front of an audience, with opportunities for audience engagement.

questions.text: Which is the most common bilateral benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benign teratoma

 

Explanation:

 

  • A benign teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the most common benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group.
  • It is also the:
    1. ﻿﻿﻿﻿Most common germ cell tumor (overall)
    2. Bilateral in 10-15% cases
    3. ﻿﻿Most common benign tumor of ovary diagnosed in pregnancy
    4. ﻿﻿Most common tumor to undergo torsion.
  • Rokitansky's protuberances are projections consistingof skin, sebaceous glands, sweat glands, teeth & bones.
  • Thyroid tissues seen on histopathological study within a dermoid is known as Struma Ovarii.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Epithelial cell tumor: These are very common ovarian tumors and cells mimic different types of mullerian ductal epithelium, including serous cystadenoma (endosalpinx), mucinous cystadenoma (endocervical epithelium), Brenner tumour (transitional epithelium) and endometrioid (endometrium)

 

Option B. Follicular cysts: These are the most common functional ovarian cysts. Rarely causes any symptoms or vague pain if size is large.

 

Option C. Sex cord stromal tumor: They produce hormones. They include granulosa cell tumour, theca cell tumour, androblastoma etc

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A benign teratoma (dermoid cyst) is the most common bilateral benign tumor of the ovary in the reproductive age group.

 

Ref: D.C Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology page 293

questions.text: Researchers are monitoring two groups to assess the health impacts of an environmental factor, one exposed to the factor and the other not. They aim to compare the disease rates between these groups. Which study design is best for calculating the 'Relative Risk' or 'Risk Ratio'? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cohort

 

A cohort study is most appropriate for calculating the Relative Risk (RR), as it follows individuals over time to observe the incidence of disease in both exposed and non-exposed groups. This design allows for a direct comparison and quantification of the risk associated with the exposure.

 

RR (Relative Risk/ Risk Ratio):

 

  • RR= Incidence among exposed/Incidence among Non-exposed
  • Indicates strength of association.
  • Interpretation of RR:
    • RR = 1 No association
    • RR > 1 Positive association (The assessing factor is a risk factor)
    • RR < 1 Negative association (The assessing factor is a protective factor)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Using a cohort study enables researchers to effectively determine the effects of environmental exposures on health by tracking and comparing disease incidence over time in different groups.

questions.text: Tumbling motility is seen in: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Listeria

 

Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive facultative anaerobic bacterium known for its distinctive tumbling motility. This motility is due to its peritrichous flagella, which allows it to move in a characteristic tumbling motion when viewed under a microscope.

 

Tumbling motility [Peritrichous Flagella]

 

Cultured on selective media like Palcam agar or Oxford agar.

 

Differential stains like crystal violet or modified acid-fast stains can be used to highlight Listeria.

 

Enrichment broths like Fraser broth or Half Fraser broth are employed to enhance Listeria recovery from samples.

 

Cold enrichment at 4°C can promote Listeria growth

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Vibrio species, such as Vibrio cholerae, are motile due to a single polar flagellum and exhibit a rapid, darting movement rather than tumbling motility.

 

Option C. Proteus: Proteus species are known for their swarming motility, which involves rapid and coordinated movement across solid surfaces, not tumbling motility.

 

Option D. Treponema pallidum: Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, is a spirochete with corkscrew motility. It moves in a spiral motion rather than a tumbling motion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tumbling motility is a characteristic feature of Listeria monocytogenes, a gram-positive facultative anaerobic bacterium with peritrichous flagella. This distinctive movement can help in the identification of this pathogen.

questions.text: A young boy with fatigue is found to have a haemoglobin of <9 g/di. Peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBs. What is the next best step in managing this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood transfusion

 

  • Based on the clinical features given, the diagnosis is sickle cell anemia.
  • The pathology of sickle cell anemia is due to a missense mutation of the beta-6 globin chain, which changes glutamic acid into valine.
  • The best next course of action is blood transfusion.
  • Hydroxyurea is recommended for managing sickle cell anemia in children as it can reduce the frequency of painful crises and acute chest syndrome.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer IV antibiotics: While antibiotics are important in the management of sickle cell patients, especially during febrile episodes or infections, they are not the primary treatment for anemia or sickle cell crisis. Antibiotics would be indicated if there was evidence of infection, which is not mentioned in this case.

 

Option C. Administer desferrioxamine: Desferrioxamine is an iron chelator used to treat iron overload, typically in patients receiving chronic blood transfusions, such as those with thalassemia. It is not appropriate for immediate management of sickle cell anemia.

 

Option D. Wait and watch: This approach is not appropriate for this patient, who is symptomatic and anemic. Immediate intervention is necessary to manage the anemia and prevent further complications. "Wait and watch" would delay needed treatment and could worsen the patient's condition.

 

Educational Objective:


Blood transfusion is the appropriate immediate management for a patient with sickle cell anemia presenting with significant anemia and related symptoms.

questions.text: Identify the sign that is seen during 8 weeks of pregnancy resulting in a dusky blue color of the vagina: (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chadwick's sign

 

Explanation:

 

  • This sign is known as Chadwick’s sign. This sign is bluish discoloration of anterior vaginal wall due to local vascular congestion. It is seen in the 8th week period of gestation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palmer's sign: Regular and rhythmic uterine contractions elicited on bimanual exam, seen between 4 – 8 weeks.

 

Option C. Hegar's sign: On bimanual exam, the abdominal and vaginal fingers appose below the body of the uterus, seen between 6 – 10 weeks.

 

Option D. Osiander's sign: Increased pulsation felt through the lateral fornices, seen between 6 – 8 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Named Pelvic signs

 

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics 24th edition pg168, Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 74

questions.text: According to our national immunization schedule, when should the first dose of the Hepatitis B vaccine ideally be administered to a neonate? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. At birth

 

At birth the following vaccines are given: BCG, OPV-0 dose & HEP B.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first dose of the Hepatitis B vaccine is administered at birth as part of the national immunization schedule. This early vaccination is crucial for preventing mother-to-child transmission of the Hepatitis B virus, which can occur during birth or shortly after. Administering the vaccine at birth significantly reduces the risk of the newborn contracting Hepatitis B, a critical intervention in areas with a high prevalence of the disease.

questions.text: A 2-year child is having problems in urination from last 3 months. Contrast dye is introduced from urethra to visualize the fault. The radiological image is shown below. What could be the investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Retrograde urethrogram

Retrograde urethrogram: In this procedure dye is injected through anterior urethra. This is preferred for visualization of Anterior urethral strictures. There is little amount of dye in bladder.

Cystourethrogram: in this the dye is injected into the bladder. It is the investigation of choice for visualizing posterior urethral strictures, posterior urethral valve and vesicoureteric reflux.

questions.text: A 2-year pediatric patient with mild pneumonia and diarrhea was brought to the casualty in an unconscious state. An initial management of ABCDE is done, in which D stands for:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Disability

The approach to all deteriorating or critically ill patients is the same. The underlying principles are: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE) approach to assess and treat the patient.

questions.text: Which of the following isotope is used in the treatment of prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. I 125

Management for prostate cancer includes brachytherapy. I-125, P-103(palladium), cesium-131 are the radioisotopes used in the treatment.

choices.text: Over expression of her-2-neu gene
Mucinous or colloid breast cancer

questions.text: Which of the following is considered as having better prognosis in a lady presenting with breast lump in the lower outer quadrant of the breast with axillary node involvement diagnosed as invasive breast cancer?
questions.solution: Ans. D. Mucinous or colloid breast cancer

choices.text: BMI needed for interpretation

questions.text: A baby is coming for regular checkup in op. his growth chart shows that weight of baby is between 85th –95th percentiles. Child status is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Overweight

BMI classification of child;

BMI < 5th percentile – underweight

BMI b/w 85th -95th percentile – overweight

BMI >95th percentile – obese

questions.text: Which Vaccine given to baby at birth?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. BCG, OPV, Hep B

Vaccines given at birth are:

BCG, OPV, HEP B.

MR given at: 9 months, followed by a second dose at 16-24 months

IPV given at: 6 weeks, 14 weeks and a third dose at 9 months

DPT given at: 6weeks,10 weeks and 14 weeks (As a part of Pentavalent vaccine which has components against Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Hepatitis B AND HiB), followed by the first booster at 16-24 months and the second booster at 5-6 years
